description:
Located in the Marina district, Palace of Fine Arts is one of those must see landmarks whenever in San Francisco. With its beautiful architecture, you'll be mesmerized in admiring each column, pillars, domes, arches, etc. 

A popular backdrop for social media, engagements or weddings for obvious reasons. The Palace was originally built in 1915 using Roman and Greek architecture, it sits around a gorgeous lawn to picnic on. An equally beautiful lagoon with fish, turtles and birds is also a sight to behold. Lots of greenery that provide shades and more characters all around this park. 

Lots of locals and tourists walking around. You can't help marveling at the sight of this breathtaking landmark. I've seen it numerous times during daytime but I've seen photos during nighttime and they were equally stunning. I've added another item in my ever increasing bucket list, to see the Palace at nighttime.
author: Cris I.

description:
This park was so stunningly beautiful.  What a wonderful place to stop by and recharge.

It was really wonderful to take the walking path around the palace to take in the large columns and domes.  Several painters were set up in the park, painting the sights.

I felt like I was transported into a different time.  I didn't feel like I was in the thick of the city at all.

I would definitely recommend this park.
author: Lindsey P.

description:
I've been coming to SF for years and only found out about this place recently. Wow! I guess I must have been living under a rock...hahaha!

We were in the neighborhood and decided to check it out. Its minutes from the Golden Gate Bridge and half mile from the Fisherman's Warf, right off the Marina District.

First of all, anything that offers free parking and free admission is awesome, automatic double star right of the bat. We parked behind the palace and we were within easy walking distance to park grounds. The garden, lagoon and Greek-Roman architecture was breathtaking. I was blown away by enormous size of colonnades and soaring central rotunda, truly spectacular and unique. Definitely offers lots of photo ops. While we were walking around, we noticed lots of photography sessions happening, such as weddings and quinceanera. Of course, there were plenty of tourists too. We walked around park at a leisurely pace and enjoyed the beauty it offered. It was quite relaxing and peaceful. The huge pond even had ducks, swans and turtles.

Definitely a must when you visit SF.
author: Leo C.

description:
This place was pleasantly surprising. We didn't plan to visit here and stumbled upon it which was really nice. They have a huge rotunda and free parking, a beautiful walking area with a park and pond area. The really neat thing about this area was we visited during sunset and the view was amazing and not to mention the people were playing music under the rotunda. 

It was very relaxing and entertaining. I'm not saying they are here all the time but it was really cool to be able to watch the sun go down in a park like atmosphere with live music in the background. Can't beat that experience at all.
author: Krystine S.

description:
FINALLY had the chance to check this beautiful establishment out!  
Highly recommend coming on the weekdays in the morning to avoid crowds, traffic, and tourists. 

It's a beautiful place to take a stroll through here. Absolutely a photo opportunity, but if you want professional shots done I believe you need to pay for that. (Forgive me if I'm wrong!) 

The place speaks for itself. There is minimal parking out front but for the most place you do need to find street parking. Your chances on the weekday in the mornings will be a lot easier than on the weekend.
author: Crystal Grace G.

description:
This place is gorgeous and magical. Nice architectural design and pillars. The pond even has baby turtles and swans. It's like a dream!  

I came from a little stroll/hike and Lands end which is like a ten minute drive away. I got to see the coastal views in the afternoon and came upon this amazing place to end my trip in SF. Highly recommended for photo shoots or a date! Just bring a picnic blanket and sit on the lawn.
author: Linda S.

description:
A must see, this beautiful historical landmark. We were staying at the Grand Hyatt Union Square and we took an Uber to the Marina area where we walked the Marina to the Palace.

Note: While seeing the Palace, walk the Marina and see the Wave Organ all in the same area.
author: Melody K.

description:
Been here so many times to walk around, have lunch, picnic on the lawn or relax on the benches. This one of my favorite places in SF. Parking is free. They have a lot for parking or there is plenty of street parking. Just check the signs for which day you are parking bc SF doesn't mess around with parking tickets. 

This place is nice to have a wedding or an event. Would be costly though. There are normally swans and ducks wading in the pond out front. The lawn is well kept and the trash is always taken care of. Not a lot of homeless in this area and it's a safe area for the family.
author: Angel M.

description:
One word to describe the Place of Fine Arts: Picturesque. You feel like you're in Rome when you visit this place. The architecture of this palace is gorgeous. Perfect place to take wedding, birthday, engagement etc.. You will see couples taking their photos here so just be patient if you want to take a picture in the spot they are at. That's what I did and I loved the way my photos came out. Definitely a great spot to stop at when you're in San Fran. Gorgeous views!

FYI..Apparently the restrooms were under construction for about a month so use the bathroom if you plan on staying here for a couple hours taking pictures. I had to walk about 4 min near Starbucks to use the restroom.
author: Trinh V.

description:
Awesome place to for photo ops.

If you're into architecture and bog pillars then this place will be perfect for you.

The atmosphere is really relaxing and everyones just enjoying the garden pond area or taking pictures.

Definitely check this place out if you're visiting in SF.
author: Steven H.

description:
Palace Of Fine Arts is a giant classical rotunda that was built for the Panama-Pacific International Exposition (PPIE) in 1915 and the structure was originally made from plaster. The city partially demolished the rotunda in 1964 to rebuilt it with concrete and the structure also underwent an earthquake retrofit in early 2009. The Exploratorium used to locate here since 1969, but it was moved to Embarcadero Pier 15 on April 2013.

I really enjoyed walking around the lagoon because I got a sense of tranquility and saw a lot of wild life. A lot of visitors came here for wedding pictures and photo shoots. Palace Of Fine Arts is approximately 15~20 minute walking distance away from the Lyon Street Steps (easy downhill walking path), so make sure to stop by and visit this majestic monument in the Marina District of SF.
author: Luke L.

description: I love taking my visitors here. It is so beautiful. Lots of photo opportunities. There's plenty of grass to lay on and picnic or sun bathe. There's also some benches around. There's turtles, ducks and swans in the lake. Beautiful flowers too. Parking isn't that bad on weekends either. You can find free residential parking near by. However lots of car break ins in the area so be careful. Don't leave backpacks or luggages or purses in the car, especially in a car rental. Almost every time I visit a newly wed is having a photo shoot. A top visit in San Francisco.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
Everything about this place screams beauty, art, love and architecture! So much so, I thought it would be the perfect place for my girlfriend and I to have a cute picnic lunch date. 

When we got there it was crowded but there are perfect opportunities and spots around the place so there's no room for disappointment. 

There were young and older couples there just hanging out, people walking there dog, lots of tourist and last but not least beautiful brides and grooms looking for the perfect lighting to take the perfect wedding picture. 

Overall I love this place, I don't have pictures attached but it's really a must see at night. The lights and the place is just beautiful. You wont be disappointed!
author: LasashaM L.

description: Another great place for some awesome photo opts while in San Francisco. Best time to take pictures is of course during the day, but it is equally beautiful to see during the evenings. This is one thing that needs to be on your list of places to visit while in the Bay Area.
author: Cheryl P.

description:
If you're looking to visit one of San Francisco's true icons, look no further. The Palace of Fine Arts is one of the city's most stunning structures and has a rich history as it was originally constructed for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition in order to exhibit works of art. 

Today you'll find plenty of tourists, tour buses and couples taking wedding photos in front of the lagoon at all hours of the day. I'd highly recommend walking the paths closest to the lagoon as you get amazing views around every corner. Personally, I think it looks best at night. :)

Grab a friend, put on those walking/running shoes, explore the area and get ready for some great people watching.
author: Benjamin F.

description: We really enjoyed our visit here. The palace is much more beautiful than the photos can really capture. We were surprised at how lovely the entire area was. We rested on the grass and had a very lovely afternoon.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
It was cool to see this Palace of Fine Arts up, close & personal. I think we were simply blessed to find street parking at our starting point. Many others had the same idea even though the day started off foggy. Some of it had burned off by the time we arrived so it was a cloudy day.

This Palace located in the Marina district of San Francisco was erected back over 100 years ago in 1915. It's pretty iconic this landmark as a wedding couple was there simultaneously getting photographed for wedding pictures. Obviously this probably is the most popular for wedding couples & is the most instagrammed. You would understand why once you visit this surreal place.

As we started to walk around the lagoon there was a woman there on her own bench feeding the pigeons. She needed the entire bench as there were huge bags of bread. In fact we had to carefully watch where we walked so we would not gingerly step on them. These pigeons were hungry & had a serious agenda! Get out of their way which we did!

As we walked passed the Australian eucalyptus trees I observed geese, ducks & a couple of swans. I thought the swans did a gorgeous job of being picturesque.

If ever you have a chance to come here it is free to walk around & observe the fabulous Roman & ancient Greek architecture. I read in one of the reviews there's a tiny parking lot but don't count on that. There is street parking all around. Come & enjoy. Don't take it for granted as it's pretty amazing.

I've been to San Francisco so much in my lifetime that I was happy to finally get the opportunity to check this out. What have I've been missing? You will see once you arrive. It's so unreal. And. Don't. Forget. Your. Cameras. It's. Totally. Epic. Even. At. Night.
author: Karen K.

description:
Outside of not being able to find the entrance for the life of me. 

Thank you woman jogger 
...and also thank you... 
Two handsome gentleman taking a stroll around the building. 

This place is PRETTY freakin' cool. 

It was originally constructed for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition to show off some fine arts. It has undergone various efforts to save the structure, and the structure that sits on the little late ( a fictional ruins that were inspired by Greek and Roman Ruins) was saved by organizations founded for specifically that reason. Source- Wikipedia, Last Edited 12 June 2018

So, yeah it's pretty freakin' awesome especially the outside. Beautiful during the day and majestic at night. 

We were there for the 29 Rooms art exhibition which was just about the most vain and vapid thing I've ever done. Good thing I had an excuse: "International Selfie Day" of course. 

I'd highly reccomend a visit to sit along it's banks, soak up some sun. When I had parked (which parking is an issue, you definitely have to circle the surrounding streets for parking), I walked along the banks of the little lake past a group fo about 10 woman making floral crowns and drinking Rose. #SanFranciscoReallySanFransHard. 

Definitely a cool site to stop by if you're in San Fran.
author: Mike B.

description:
I didn't know about this place before visiting my friend in San Fran for the weekend. She had been here before and said it's nice to walk through. I think some people came here as a destination, but we were passing through. It was a nice detour, though, and one I was happy we took.
 
I wasn't quite sure what the Palace of Fine Arts was, prior to my visit, but the architecture and the way the building was designed was unreal. It was also a beautiful day outdoors, with great lighting for taking photos. There were lots of other people taking pictures of the building and surrounding gardens. We passed by the Palace of Fine Arts after walking through Golden Gate Park, and while we were on our way back toward the piers.
 
Our visit here was really brief, but I would recommend checking out this fine structure if you have the chance - especially if you're with those who appreciate historical architecture and art.
author: Kelli S.

description: Even if you are not an artsy type you'd surely fall in love with the place. Unique structural buildings with detailed historical designs, classic statues, gorgeous fountains, colorful garden along its peaceful lake. Such a romantic place for lovers, good recreation for families & friends. And it's even lovelier during the night with colorful lights embracing the palace!
author: Terr M.

description:
Let me start by saying I am born and raised in the Bay Area and never knew that this gem existed. I'm currently finished with my work contract and in between moving and looking for a new position so my days have slightly opened up to exploring. I like to work and send out resumes and do interviews the rest of the week but Monday's are MAYA days and that means exploration without robe crowds or traffic. I decided to research great places to visit in the bay area and through Google I was able to find this particular place. I had research this place about forfive months ago but between working and everything else in life I never had the opportunity. Like I said my schedule recently opened and I found myself wanting to finally visit this beautiful place.

A little history I have always been obsessed with Greek mythology. Being part Greek I always enjoyed old architecture with the Greek columns in Roman architecture as well. I definitely wanted to see this place because it seem to embody such beautiful architecture. Arrive there on Monday and what's amazing about that is that the museum is closed so the parking right in front is open. Other than people sitting in the park area or benches just to have lunch it was pretty quiet and I loved it. I have read other reviews and seen so many pictures on different social media sites that show how busy it can get during the rest the week so the first thing that I really liked about this particular adventure was that I picked up Monday and everything was super convenient. (of course if you're not from San Francisco go earlier the better I left around nine and got there at 10 with barely any traffic.)

As you first enter you were totally mesmerized it's as if you stepped into another place and time. The architecture just speaks volumes it's so breathtaking and so amazing that this place is right in the middle of a neighborhood. There's a little Lake area adjacent to it that just makes it so much more beautiful and calm. As soon as I saw the architecture and the ancient style I was taken back and it reminded me of my trip to Greece. I would definitely recommend this place for photographers, people looking for adventures, architecture lovers, and a place to go and relax and have a beautiful view. I took a lot of pictures but I hope that you all will enjoy but the next time you're looking to find a venture go back in time and visit this beautiful gem located in San Francisco!!
author: Maya A.

description:
Beautiful historic monument. Many come here for great photos and to learn about a small part of San Francisco history. Certain times if the year they have shows here. 

Almost daily people come here to take wedding photos. You can take a tour, but I think self guided tour is fine. There are many signs telling you what things are. 

Parking is only available on the street and can be challenging. Most street parking is free for 2 hours. You will have to know how to parallel park.
author: Alan H.

description: Built for the 1915 Panama Pacific Exposition, this Iconic structure in the Marina is one not to miss. It's a great place for pictures. Having lived in SF for 20 years this place has always been one of our favorite places to take a stroll on a nice day. The sidewalks around the lagoon seem to be better maintained. Before there were lots of goose crap everywhere. You'll often find couples doing wedding photos within the structure. The crowds and parking are manageable now that the science museum moved to the pier. After all these years these structures remain one of the flawless and timeless beauties of San Francisco.
author: Gerald H.

description:
A nice place to walk around. 

The work of California architect Bernard Maybeck. It was constructed for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition to exhibit works of art. In addition to hosting art exhibits, it's a popular spot for weddings and wedding pics. We were on a tour bus and our tour guide brought us here. It was nice to walk around, enjoy the pond and take pics.
author: Kimberly J.

description: I have been coming here since I was a kid. We used to come here to visit the Exploratorium. Last night we saw the most beautiful Hula show in the theater. It's like the home of an old friend!!!
author: Martha L.

description: Large campus.I would recommend to show up early if you are coming for an event because they do close off certain areas if there is a performance. Parking is a hassle since there is no parking garage or lot and you will need to find parking in the surrounding neighborhood. We went to see Levar Burton read live and the theater was a little hard to find due to it being a large campus and no signs were placed up besides the one in front of the event. The theater was a little old but everything worked well( lighting,sound,Seats) they had a good stand right outside of the theater.. checking in was super easy and nice. The bathroom had plenty of stalls for everyone. The campus has beautiful statues to take pictures with and a nice pond around the campus to have a nice stroll... I would love to come back to another event here or even to have a model moment for pictures.
author: Trielle R.

description:
One of my favorite landmarks in the city! 

Palace Of Fine Arts is a beautiful spot with amazing architecture that ignites a sense of serenity and peacefulness. Whether you want to explore the area or have a little picnic around the lake, it's a great place to check out during the day and night. It's also a great place to take pictures for prom, engagement and so forth!

Parking can be a hit or miss. I would suggest parking nearby Chrissy Field or Presidio and walk over.

If you have never been to Palace Of Fine Arts or want to explore different areas of the city, I recommend this place!
author: Julia L.

description:
Every time I check in to this glorified golden Palace, I am in awe and wow-ed on its majestic monument.  I stare up at the details and it simply amazes me.

Pleasantly glowing at night and an enjoyable stroll through the trail.  Lovely sounds of ripple effects of the water.  It's great for quiet time and for a drop by.

It is surely a Fine Palace of the Arts!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
A delightful venue on a good weather day. Love the scale and the semi private feel as you wind your way around the structures and garden lake.

It can handle a much bigger crowd than it appears with plenty of complimentary parking.
author: Lu-Shien T.

description:
This was my first time visiting the Palace of Fine Arts. There isn't too much to do here, but the buildings are beautiful to see. While I was there I saw a small wedding happening, which is always a cute moment to see. There is a little museum area where the exploratorium used to be and they have a few things to look at, but it isn't much. Although, close-by is the Walt Disney museum. 

I would say to check it out if you haven't ever been before and have the time. I wouldn't say it's a thing you must do if you don't have the time. Also, the beach area is a close walk and you can see the Golden Gate Bridge from there. A lot of people do picnics around the area, as they have tables set up. I would recommend visiting on a warm day and bringing a picnic so you can explore and then sit near the beach and enjoy.
author: Rithika V.

description:
A hidden gem (for SF standards).
It's not too far from the Golden Gate Bridge, so it's a busy tourist destination, but it's not as busy as other tourist spots. There's people taking lots of photos, wedding pictures, I even saw someone filming an amateur music video. But it's not overcrowded. People are amazed by the beautiful architecture, columns, dome and surrounding lake, take their pictures and leave. No one ever stays that long, so it's never that crowded. So it's definitely worth seeing.
author: Vincent H.

description: My family and I came here to get away from the hot heat in the Central Valley and I'm so glad we did. The parking is on the street along the area so make sure you get there early. Totally a tourist area to take pictures and just have a nice picnic alongside the lake.
author: Nikki V.

description:
Majestic beauties ... these structures are nothing but flawless beauties that carry history and emotion... this place is great to come see a show or enjoy the views walking around the pond... tons of birds and fish...also turtles ... large cascading waterfalls...enjoy a picnic or even a night stroll.

Great place for weddings and photography

Not so great on parking but i always park at the presidio...free parking across the crossfit studios... short walk ...so worth it
author: Cathy C.

description:
I'll keep it brief. JUST GO HERE. 

+ Beautiful architecture with a rich history. Walk around and admire the building and read the informational signs.
+ Walk through quickly or linger. Whatever. 
+ Make sure you do the full loop. We almost turned around and missed out on the wildlife! There is a small lagoon. IT OFFERS FOOD AND SHELTER TO MIGRATING BIRDS! In the middle of the city. How cool is that!? We saw so many cool birds in one place. A bunch of turtles perched on branches. A swan that almost bit a tourist. It was awesome.
author: Maria E.

description: I love coming to the palace whenever I'm in the city. I love taking a walk in the park surrounded with amazing architecture and nature beauties like local plants and trees, and small living creatures like turtles, fishes, and birds. There are swans here as well if you can catch a glimpse.
author: Thuc V.

description: Palace of Fine Arts is THE favorite spot of SF for my fiancee and me. This was our third time coming together (5th for me personally), and it still holds high to our expectation. It's very relaxing here. It has everything - beautiful sight of artistic building/theater, pond, fountain, restaurants couple blocks down, public restroom nearby, beach across the street, view of Golden Gate Bridge across the street free street parking for up two hours until 6pm, and etc. My fiancee and I like to just lie on grass and relax here at the theater. We munch on snacks, listen to music, watch clips on our phones, take pictures of the park, take selfies, you name it. At night, the whole place lights up, and the details that you might miss during the day due to sunlight will come out of the theather. Highly recommended if you're visiting SF and/or if you are resident of SF.
author: Paul L.

description: This a beautiful place. More art installation then anything else today and a great piece of history. Great place to sit, relax, and contemplate.
author: Chris H.

description:
Ahh the Palace of Fine Arts is one of my favorite spots in San Francisco to do absolutely nothing. Just gaze at the pond, the rotunda, the infinite sky... it reminds me of Athens during the dawn of civilization or simply a Bridge to Terabithia. Yet, with all the fantasy & Fabio romance novels running through my brain it's really all about doing absolutely nothing in a city of doing everything. 

Some enjoy the Palace for the art shows and wedding shoots. For me, I simply enjoy a picnic near the pond with the swans, geese and ducks strutting around. Walking around and enjoying "the ruins". Exploring the grounds and admiring the rotunda close and from afar. Allowing your imagination to run free. It's okay to do nothing. It's the type of place to slow down and appreciate the now. 

The Palace was built for the Panama-Pacific International Exposition, a world's fair held in San Francisco, in 1915. It was to celebrate the completion of the Panama Canal, but it was widely seen in the city as an opportunity to showcase its recovery from the 1906 great earthquake. The fair was constructed on a 635 acre site in San Francisco, along the northern shore, between the Presidio and Fort Mason, known as the Marina District.

Most of the surviving Palace and surrounding area is absolutely free, but besides the grounds there's also an arts theater (paid) that features a variety of cultural fare including live theatre, concerts, art exhibitions, and lectures. Wedding events can be held on grounds too, but you must reserve and pay the parks for such an experience. The Palace of Fine Arts is on the National Register of Historic Places and is a San Francisco designated landmark. A place to belch Andrea Bocelli! 

Ahh the Palace of Fine Arts. A photographers dream and a dream for any fairytale. The giant columns, tranquil pond with elegant swans, and of course the greek inspired rotunda make it a place I always look forward to visit. A simple picnic is fine by me. Because sometimes in life doing nothing is everything. Just enjoy the moment...
author: Eric R.

description:
Super historical and beautiful place in the heart of San Francisco. It is surrounded by beautiful victorian houses and Marina. It is a walking distance to Marina, Crissy Field East Beach, Lombard street. 

I came here many times because I live in Bay Area but also its just a cool spot to visit and hangout on the grass in front of Palace of Fine Arts and listen to birds and water. I see many people take their wedding portraits there, which is a great and beautiful back drop of Palace of Fine Arts architecture. 

On my latest visit, i came to an exhibit show held inside Palace of Fine Arts called The UNTITLED. Its was very cool exhibit and fun to just walk around and get inspiration. Its great to know for everyone that there are events held at the Palace of Fine Arts, its not just an exterior appearance. 

If you are visiting San Francisco, you must stop here because it has been here for so long, its not just a beautiful monumental structure its part of Bay Area land mark.
author: Galya T.

description: It was an awesome experience! This was my first time here and it was amazing. Especially seeing Levar Burton live. One of my childhood heroes on stage in a historical place is perfect if you ask me! If you get the chance to check out a live event here be sure to do a little exploring before the show. It has a beautiful landscape!
author: Lamont J.

description:
Yes it is a must see. Yes it is beautiful. And yes, it is worth a trip while visiting especially if it's first time visit. The Place of Fine Arts is gorgeous. Just one of those touristy places that can be slightly underrated. The most you do here as people would tell you is take pictures and walk, then not much else. BUT, it's your appreciation for finer sights that make Palace of Fine Arts just a breath of fresh air and a great place to take a quick minute to yourself. 

We came when the winds and gloom picked up but it was still just as gorgeous as it would be under the sun. 

If you have more time to spare, enjoy some peace, quiet and meditation along with a sketch pad.
author: Julienne D.

description: Beautiful architecture and amazing lake. Made me feel like I was in another era from hundreds of years ago. Location is great, too.
author: Juan M.

description:
Beautiful, absolutely jaw dropping, BEAUTIFUL! I'm in awe every time I visit. Gorgeous architecture surrounded by a lake full of turtles, ducks, swans, and other fowl. There are also tons of benches for you to sit, relax, maybe even have a picnic. The last is one of my fav moments here. Love the comfort of silence, sitting next to someone you love and being able to enjoy your surroundings without the need for chatter. 


"It's not what you look at that matters it's what you see."  
--Henry David Thoreau  


I've been here a few times throughout the years and it never ceases to amaze me. I'm reminded just how small we are in the grand scheme of things. Those problems you're having, the issues you think are going to tear you apart... small potatoes compared to everything else going on in the world. One person can't change the entire world, but you always have the power to change the world for one person. Live, laugh, love; life's too short for anything else. 


- P A R K I N G -
Street parking available in surrounding areas. It's mostly residential, so it may take a while.
author: Grace C.

description:
Can you believe I was born and raised in the SF Bay Area and last week was my very first time coming the Palace of Fine Arts?! It's definitely fun exploring your own backyard once in a while. 

I came on a weekday evening with my friend, we were able to snag a parking spot super close. It was windy as hell!!! ha ha make sure you wear warm clothing if you come here and have your hair tied up! 

It's definitely a romantic place! I can picture this being so beautiful at night. I'm for sure coming back here with my boyfriend and taking cute pics next time ha ha

BTW the houses surrounding the Palace are to die for!!! Seriously my dream homes!
author: Ramona G.

description:
Just like ALL OF SAN FRANCISCO; parking is almost impossible to be found... nonetheless if there is a touristy spot worth visiting for a photo op or simply a picnic underneath the many trees with a nice breeze, add the Palace of Fine Arts onto your sightseeing list! 

*we parked at the Presidio then took a stroll over, it was a nice stroll while looking at all the beautiful 3 story houses that probably are owned by millionaires. 

The agriculture is freaken breath taking! Correct me if I'm wrong but to know that I'm walking on a Greek historical site (for free) was such a blessing. It's a must see for tourists and one the the highlights to my trip..and I wonder what the residents feel when they drive home from work being able to see fine-arts all the time. 

Def. a recommended attraction for those SF TOURISTS or even a romantic pit stop for those that are in budget
author: Trinity P.

description: This place is just beautiful... Great scenery and just such a peaceful place that always puts a smile on my face when I'm there. Today I was just able to park right in front of the lake and just do some paperwork and relax during lunch time. I love coming here from time to time doing that or walking around ....it's just awesome. Anyone that has never been here, should take the time to come as it is worth the trip.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Been wanting to come to this place for so long and I finally got the chance. It was massive and so beautiful. I would live here if I could. The architecture is just so elegant. 

The day my sister and I visited, there were high school students everywhere taking pictures for prom, but since this place is so huge, we were able to find a little corner to ourselves. If you love taking pictures then this is the place to go because there are so many different angles and spots to choose from. 

Parking was easy to find and I'm sure I'll be back the next time I visit.
author: Anh L.

description:
Iconic of San Francisco and great spot for a photog outing.

Find an opportunity to attend an event inside. The theater has character!
author: Yad L.

description:
Took the cable car and got off at Richardson for this beautiful attraction. It was fairly packed with tourists and locals taking pictures and strolling about. It was also close to the bay so the wind was at an all time high at the time I arrived.

I have seen pictures of these beautiful structures, but seeing them in person is better. I didn't look too much into their history and purpose, but I do appreciate its art and the little details. It is worth the trip plus it is nearby Crissy field and the Golden Gate Bridge! Definitely check it out even if you're someone who wants to avoid tourist traps.
author: Heather L.

description: The building is an interesting historical structure. I have come here for events related to the tech world in SF. I went for HackFit once and again for We Work's Creator Awards event. It is a great space for an event for lots of people(young people perhaps). It's a nice atmosphere and you might find parking. It's a structure in San Francisco that stands out well.
author: Denise C.

description:
We had stopped by here on a whim after spotting it in a movie while watching tv at our hotel and we are so glad we did. 

The grounds are beautiful and the architecture is outstanding! Great spot for pictures.

A must see in San Francisco!
author: Michelle B.

description: love this place. surrounding by the lake and trees, great spot for photo taking. But hard to find a parking lot. when you walk around the lake, watch out for a couples of mandarin ducks and two big white swans.
author: Choy T.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is a gorgeous place to walk, jog or even ride bikes to. It is located near the eastern side of the Presidio and just off of Marina Blvd (and Chrissy Field and the Yacht Club harbor). The lake is lovely; and, it is often filled with ducks and other water fowl. 

If you're looking to park your car, you might need to look elsewhere (e.g., Chrissy Field, Yacht Club, etc.). Personally, I would suggest that you park in the Presidio and walk over. It's a wonderful walk through the Presidio anyway.
author: Chris M.

description:
I've always seen this place on the internet but I never got a chance to visit. Just this past April of 2016, I was able to go with my boyfriend. I was jumping for joy when I saw that the parking was frree!!!!! I thought there was lots to do here, but soon realized there wasn't much. At first there was a bunch of oooo aaaa looook, ahhhhh, but then I realized those oooo's and ahhh's ended quickly. Because it's in sf, it was windy the day I came. It was almost impossible for me to take nice pictures without my hair slapping me across the face amillion times. The palace itself is such a beautiful art piece. Too bad I didn't pack a lunch the day I went. My boyfriend didn'y want to sit on the grass because he was afraid there was geese poop everywhere. 

side note: theres no bathrooms!!!!!!! but you can simply walk across the street to the park and use the public bathroom!
author: Emily L.

description:
I've finally made it out here to this place. I've heard plenty of good stuff about this place but never visited. I even got lucky to find a parking spot out front. I kept my car there for 5 hours to maximize my parking lottery.

The arts and view of the bay, bridge, and architecture is pretty. It can get windy so be sure to bring some clothing. I came here during the memorial day weekend and played tourist. It was a good walk where I ended up going to the beach for a nice walk and back. Then I walked to Lucas studios for lunch and then headed back here. From ducks and turtles to the building art you'll enjoy a nice walk around the area. 

Good luck with parking. I would keep an eye out to find some lucky parking spots.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I have come here at least 4-5 times now in a span of 2 months. The place has something to it...a serenity...peacefulness and quietness...whether there are people taking wedding/prom pics, or tourists taking shots of the beautiful building or artists playing live music, or you're just simply walking by and sitting alone with your book. It's a magical place.

Love the ducks and swans...we don't get many swans in Oakland so you get my excitement :)
Haven't been inside yet or for a concert but waiting for a good one to come up and will be running to attend :)
author: Heliana M.

description: His place is Amazing! Really beautiful and relaxing. The stuff that is here is just WOW great place for pictures. I had lots of fun being here
author: Rafael A.

description:
This does nothing but exist to be beautiful. Not only do I find that sentiment endearing, but from the little bit that I got to understand about the city during my visit, it's very San Fransisco. 

We saw one couple getting their wedding photos taken. Another girl celebrating a sweet 16 or quinceanera in the biggest, most glittering pink cake of a dress I've ever seen. Plenty of tourists taking selfies. It's the perfect setting for photos. On a sunny day, the sun illuminates the buildings, hits the water, and it feels like your strolling through a Victorian garden.
author: Luci B.

description:
What a great venue! My hubby and I saw Leela James last night here and let me tell you, it was glorious! This was the first time we ever been to this place and I had no idea they even had live music here. 

What I Loved About This Place:
- Great for photo taking. I think H.S. prom night was going on here last night.
- Great for a walk. There is like a lake you can walk around outside of the venue.
- They have a waiting area just before you enter the theater and it is spacious and clean.
- They serve snacks and drinks in the waiting area. 
- The sound system is wonderful!

Now, there was a drawback and it was my seating. We purchased front row tickets but I found my neck feeling uncomfortable because I had to look right for long periods of time due to the positioning of the artist. That being said, you may want to buy seating tickets in the center of the theater. Regardless, this place is awesome and I would totally come back!
author: Loreto D.

description: Such a gorgeous place with so much history! This is definitely one of my go-to spots to take friends who are visiting from out of town. The perfect time to go would be right before sunset so the sun lights up the structures beautifully. Parking can be a little difficult on the weekends so be aware.
author: Annie N.

description: Great way to start your day touring SF. This place is just two-and-a-half miles away from Fisherman's Wharf, our next stop. Parking was easy since we were here early. With coffee in hand, we started taking in this beautiful place to which I hope they never change. Not a single thing. Pictures after pictures, we just couldn't help ourselves.
author: Marie H.

description: This place was a favorite of mine.  The palace looks like it was imported from Europe.  The architecture and molding are beautiful, and the water adds to the elegance of its entirety.  There are always people there just to enjoy the view, and weddings are held here as well.
author: Bradley S.

description:
What a gorgeous place! I can't believe I've been to San Francisco multiple times and have never visited this beautiful place. The grounds are so well kept and beautiful to just sit at and unwind at for a while. There is a lake with beautiful ducks, lots of green space and of course the actual "palace". 
The architecture is magnificent, so many details to look at, I think I could have spent half a day in this place. Unfortunately I was with some friends and we didn't have a lot of time, but I would definitely recommend spending a good 2+ hrs in this place- it is worth it!!
If you get lucky you will find street parking, we didn't have a problem finding a spot even though we came on a Saturday afternoon. 
Apparently they do a lot of weddings here so be conscientious if there is one going on :). You can still take beautiful pictures and walk around if they are having a wedding. It's a pretty big place.
author: Lucia B.

description:
One of favorite places to go to in San Francisco - I love the pond and the ducks here. 

It's always easy to find parking nearby even on their busy days. 

There is always someone getting married or getting engaged here or just there for the photo shoots. 

Also a nice place for a small sweet date.
author: Rupa S.

description:
This building was designed by Bernard Maybeck in the Beaux-Arts style (Neoclassisism). It was built in 1915 for the Panama-Pacific Exposition.

Maybeck was better known as architect in the arts and crafts movement of that time. His most notable building was the First Church of Christ, Scientist across the bay in Berkeley, California.

This building looks best from across the lake at the eastern edge of the park.
author: Keo N.

description: Beautiful outdoor place to walk around (although very chilly in the evening). The pond has cute swans and mallards. It only takes 10-15 min to stroll around it. There are some benches around the perimeter also.
author: Cece Y.

description: This is easy to get to when taking an uber.  I dont know where the parking is but when you get here you easily go down the steps and there it is.  It is beautiful for wedding and pictures.  We were here in July but bring a sweater cause its windy and chilly.  They also have no signal if you have Sprint but other than than, it's fine.  I love the architecture and the color contrasting from the water and trees and white ducks around.  Come check it out for a nice little stroll and bold pictures.
author: G ..

description:
Palace of the fine arts is a beautiful place with amazing architecture. A must see for any tourist in San Francisco. It's looks beautiful both during the day and night when it's lit up. The lake in front of it adds more beauty to this place. Great place to go to if you love taking pictures or if you just want to relax in a peaceful setting. Even with tons of people here, it still feels peaceful.there are pathways where you can leisurely walk around. 

It's large enough to accommodate many people walking around it. When your walking under and around the pillars, you can't help but to feel so small. I've been here several times and I always see someone taking pictures for a wedding, quinceñera, engagements or photo shoots. I can see why many of the locals come here for pictures.

When parking around here or anywhere in San Francisco be sure to hide all your belongings since there's a lot of vehicle break ins in this city. Be especially careful if you have a rental car because you will be more of a target for a car break in. It's so easy for these criminals to break in since there is little to no repercussion for it and it's usually a misdemeanor. SFPD also won't do much about it.
author: Karen C.

description: Gorgeous with ducks in the lake and the amazing architecture. It is so pretty. Awesome place to come walk around from. Glad our hotel was so close to this place. Awesome place to take photos. It is free to come explore. Not too packed. It is gorgeous must see. If you keep walking you will hit a beach and can see the golden gate bridge from there. Very romantic feels with the whole place.
author: Estefania C.

description: This place is beautiful! come here for a nice stroll around. It's free. On a beautiful, sunny day, it's the perfect place to relax!
author: Cole D.

description: Stopped here en route to somewhere else and had a bit of time to walk around... what a totally otherworldly spot! I wasn't sure if I was somewhere in Europe, or had suddenly stepped back in time by several centuries, or had slipped through a portal and was on some sophisticated alien planet. Maybe all three? Is that possible? The point is: I can see why people host events here. It's stunning, it's unique, the grounds are well manicured, the duck pond is lovely, and the grandeur of it all lends a certain mystical feel. Even if you just bring a cup of coffee and walk around the majestic spot for a half hour, it's worth it to take it all in once and wonder what the sculpted ladies leaning against the square fixtures at the top of the columns might be talking about.
author: Steff D.

description: This is a beautiful venue to walk through when you have a moment to wander on the northwest side of San Francisco. This is a great landmark for photos and near a number of other popular venues. I wouldn't wager that many spend too much time here before moving along, but it's a great place to see as you visit the area.
author: David V.

description:
Wow, the last time I came here was when I was a little girl and learned about outdated science at the Exploritorium (then the exhibits were never updated and were around all throughout my childhood, it was not until the museum was moved to Fisherman's Wharf that they added new exhibits, as I recall).  It was one of those- Been there, done that.  But not anymore.  

Anyhow, I had no idea that there was a theater housed here.  I won tickets to see the Fab Four (a Beatles tribute band).  It was wonderful!  The theater is huge and the seats are standard, what you expect from a theater.  They kind of seats that most theaters built in the 1970s - 1980s have.  My boyfriend and I sat next to the sound editing staff.  The second row from the back.  

The last two rows are the most spacious with plenty of leg room to stretch out.  The other rows are much more narrow.  We found that we preferred the back for the space.  It was also easier to get up and walk past others sitting in the rows as to not step on their feet.  

But there is an advantage of sitting up in front too as for all concert venues.  The Fab Four tribute band gave away one of their t-shirts to whomever could scream the loudest.  - Yah, as if there was some noise meter. LOL!  How could they know who was the loudest? Nah....well anyhow, the people up in front had more of an advantage of being heard and winning as the guys tossed the t-shirt into the audience.  A lady sitting up in front won...it figures.  

Pros:
-great venue for live performances
-was once part of the World's Fair
-attractive architecture with lots of detail
-fun events are held here
-great sound quality
-appears that you can see the stage wherever you sit 
-very helpful and friendly staff

Cons:
-food and souvenirs can be purchased with cash only but ATM is on site
-excessively long lines for food and bathroom during the intermission
-limited parking
author: Irene S.

description: I was here with my wife watching her coworker play in the Bay Area Roller Derby Championship. The derby was cool and the venue served as a good playing surface and audience area in one. There was a food stand that served really good poke bowls and Costco style hotdogs, as well as a full bar. For the event, the bathrooms were gender neutral. Its pretty romantic using stalls right next to your soulmate in public for the first time other than a porta potty. I would go back if another event I were interested was there.
author: Josh H.

description:
Beauty!  

I'm glad I was able to stop in here before I departed the city.  I didn't have much time but I was able to easily find parking in the middle of a weekday and walk around for an hour.  

The sole purpose of this park is to beautify the city and to celebrate nature and the arts.  That is fabulous.  Another thing about San Francisco to love - as if I needed more!  

It is massive, it is ancient-looking and it is beautiful.  It was interesting to learn the history of this place, why it was built, and the restoration and preservation efforts over the years to restore and ensure that it will remain a fixture in the city.
author: Alison M.

description:
Went to see the play Aladdin and his wonderful magical lamp it was put on by children's theater of San Francisco.  It was done really well after the show all of the actors sign autographs for the kids.  It was only $15 a ticket which is a great price for Live theater.  My favorite character in the play was the evil Jammal played by Peggy Haas.
We got there early so parking was not a problem and it was free
author: Anita V.

description: I visited the Palace of Fine Arts at night and it was absolutely beautiful! Parking was free and it was a quiet time to visit. I highly suggest stopping here if you are in the area! There is a ton of great places to eat and shop right up the street! Enjoy!
author: Jessica C.

description:
We visited the Palace of Fine Arts around dusk, and were beyond impressed. It's a gorgeous building, especially for couples looking for a romantic stroll, photography enthusiasts, and selfie-seeking tourists. Very cool, and even though it was getting dark, we felt fairly safe in the area because there were plenty of other visitors around.

A word of caution, though: though many Yelp reviews note how amazing the Palace of Fine Arts looks at night (and they're right, it does), be wary of safety if visiting after-hours. While we were walking around here, our car was broken into and several valuables stolen. Several other cars near ours had also been vandalized. Of course, you should still visit here, because it's one of the nicest sights in the city. Just be careful; the grandeur of the building masks the crime rates in the nearby area. (When we went to the police station to report the incident, there were several maps posted showing a high frequency of auto break-ins/thefts and muggings around here - so it's not *just* us!)
author: Amol U.

description: Beautiful landmark of San Francisco. Not much to do, but stare in awe of this marvelous architecture. Fun to walk around and take awesome pictures. Walking distance to Crissy Park, so park your car there, take pics of the Golden Gate Bridge behind you, & cross the street to get here. If you're in town, definitely add this to your list of must see.
author: Joyce D.

description: I'm so happy my husband decided to just randomly stop here. We had street parking and it was free and we got one super close to the palace. This place is BEAUTIFUL. there is so much to see around it and there's a huge pond with gorgeous water and views. The architecture is gorgeous and it's kind of surreal to stand around and look up at it. It's free to look around and walk around and I love places like this, small treasures to stop by and just take in beauty. Highly recommend a quick stop at this place on your next SF adventure!
author: Marley M.

description:
I mentioned to my partner that I wanted to hit this place and he looked at me kind of stunned. "What the heck is that?" he asked. 
Not sure how to explain it, I steered our tiny Fiat towards it and parked in a very affluent neighbourhood that surrounds the place.
Stunning architecture that is reminiscent of old European structures, the building is nestled in a small park setting with a small pond in front. Walking towards it, my partner mumbled "I had no idea this place was here" and he's obviously not the only person......there weren't that many people walking the grounds or exploring the building.
Unfortunately, the day we arrived the building was closed, so we didn't go inside, but we spent a good hour walking the grounds, feeding the ducks and swans, and just enjoying the sound of cascading water (from an enormous) fountain.
This was one of the hi-lights of our trip.
author: Jim B.

description: Came here with my boyfriend as part of our little SF date and I have to say it was well worth it! Very scenic and a perfect photo op! There are benches so bring your lunch and have a picnic date. It was even cooler as it got dark because the buildings light up. Based on signs I believe this place closes at midnight. I would also recommend not leaving any valuables on your car as break ins happen often. Otherwise it's a perfect place to relax.
author: Celine L.

description:
I was mesmerized by the architecture and the scenery. Idk if I was lucky, but there was someone who was playing beautiful serene music that echoed through the foundation. Great for picture taking. Definitely a place to stop and admire for a bit. I did not have a hard time finding parking nearby either. I went during the day time, but apparently its recommended to go during the night time as well. I would definitely come back!!

TO SFO TOURISTS: This is a must see! Also perfect if you're planning a bae-cation or date :)
author: Shirley G.

description: We went at dusk because a friend mention to us that they light it up at night. It was very beautiful to walk around it. And heck it was free, so what's to complain about .
author: Anne W.

description: Great tourist attraction and close to the beach. Great spot for weddings as well. Saw this spot for the first time as a bay area native.
author: Valerie K.

description: Our Lyft driver told us if we didn't see the Palace of the Fine Arts she would take us there herself! As a native San Franciscan she was very proud of this majestic site. We visited this location on one of the hottest nights in the history of San Francisco! Nevertheless, the views were awe inspiring and made me feel as if I were in Italy or looking up at the Sistine Chapel. Enjoy your visit!
author: Vincent Artemio E.

description: The Palace of Fine Arts is a true gem in the midst of San Francisco. I loved being a tourist here as well as coming here when I was somewhat of a local. It is such a beautiful place to walk around and take in the scenery. Many people come here to take pictures for their weddings/engagement as well as film videos here so it's such a popular spot! There are a lot of benches near the lake to stop and rest. I would definitely come back.
author: Eri K.

description:
Unbelievably beautiful especially at night! The reflection is well worth it.

Have been here for multiple photo shoots and is different each time! The dome, the ducks and the musicians make an amazing Sunday 

Ideal spot for intimate weddings.
author: Deebs M.

description: Strange yet fun place. Worth checking out at least once. A bit pricy but still a cool place to spend an hour or so exploring.
author: Douglas F.

description:
This place is such a gorgeous place to wander through- I wish I had my dog to walk around with here! We came cuz we were running around seeing the sights and this was on the must-see list. It is actually one of my sister's favorite spots in SF. 

The weather was perfect- sunny with blue skies with a breeze. We saw people walking their dogs and a tour bus pull up. We saw lots of ducks in the water, a few napping on the shore, a regal swan, and turtles sunning on logs. 

The architecture is beautiful and intricate. The ceiling is gorgeous (see pic). I love the walkway that goes all the way around. Such a peaceful setting. We even saw a trio dismantling photography equipment when we arrived.
author: Sally C.

description:
Palace of Fine Arts is definitely as beautiful in person as it is in pictures. *insert heart eyes emoji*

I got to visit Palace of Fine Arts with the lovely Starr C. during her trip to San Francisco in September. This landmark is actually a lot smaller than I imagined! If you didn't stop for lots of photos, like we did, you can probably finish walking through this whole place in about 10-15 minutes. 

We were very lucky it wasn't foggy in the city that day because the sky was so blue in the background. Such gorgeous architecture! No wonder so many people take their wedding photos here.
author: Christine S.

description:
An iconic architectural jewel impossible to miss as one makes the journey across the Golden Gate Bridge, the Palace was built for the 1915 World's Fair, in an effort to show the world that the city of San Francisco had recovered from the devastation of the 1906 earthquake. This romantic locale is a popular choice for both engagements and weddings alike, as well as a mecca for professional photographers and amateurs with smartphones. 

I was in a wedding here over the weekend, and though the rotunda was a wind tunnel, it was an absolutely lovely affair. Another thing to keep in mind if you choose this as an outdoor wedding venue is that it is a public park, and free for anyone to enter. Set up and packing up needs to go swiftly, and yes you WILL have an army of tourists providing their free, creepy videography services, and perhaps an elderly couple shouting at each other over part of the vows. It'll be windy, and it'll be cold. It's San Francisco, and the Presidio for that matter, which is first to be buffeted with incoming wind and fog from the sea. 

Who cares though! You got married at the Palace of Fine Arts! Vertigo. A View to Kill. The Rock. Filmmakers know as well as hopeless romantics; this place is perfect. For me, it invokes a sort of inner peace, though. During the waiting period before we did the rehearsal Friday night, I couldn't help but stand in speechless reverence at the pond. It's what I've done each visit since I was a child. A simply breathtaking place. 

Parking: You wish. It's street parking wherever you can find the space, and walking for you, buddy.
author: Jenny P.

description: Originally built for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition as an art exhibition, the Palace of Fine Arts in the Marina District of San Francisco is one of only a few surviving structures from the Exposition.  It is quite a beautiful structure to look at, especially from across a small artificial lagoon.  By all means, bring your cameras or smartphones to photograph this structure as one of your highlights of visiting the City by the Bay.
author: Akisato S.

description: Beautiful place to walk around.  There's loads of people here walking around and taking all types of photography (wedding, engagement, birthdays, etc.)   It's definitely a place to pass by.  There isn't much else around the area besides the beautiful architect.
author: Jackie N.

description: To me, the mood is always festive and celebratory here. I've been here on many an occasion -- for a photo shoot, for play-dates with my son and friends, for performances. It always feels serene yet joyful at the same time, which is a lovely combination.
author: Camille L.

description: The outside was great for photos.
author: Ashley Y.

description:
I saw the Palace of Fine Arts while running the 1st half course of the SF marathon. I didn't know this place until then. After the race, I asked my limo driver back to the airport about what I saw and he explained to me it was the Palace of Fine Arts.  While waiting for my flight home, I researched about this place and started planning my next trip to San Francisco.

While I was looking online about this place, I saw so many beautiful pictures. I couldn't wait to come here with my SLR.

Palace of Fine Arts along with the Legion of Honor were constructed for 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition. Both buildings have amazingly detailed designed, makes you feel you are in Europe. Walk around the Palace of Fine Arts is free. I saw a lot of wild life living in their pond.

Palace of Fine Arts is so photogenic. I took a lot of good pictures while there. I also saw a wedding during my visit. Bride's white wedding dress looked so beautiful against the Palace of Fine Arts.

I saw some night pictures, I hope to come back at night for more photo shooting someday.
author: Yuko H.

description:
Add this to your itinerary on your visit to San Francisco!! 

I'm not an expert on architecture so i'm not sure how to rate this place, but I can tell you why I go. Pictures, pictures, pictures! I myself am a hobby photographer and I absolutely love coming here to take portraits!

The location is super easy to find (look for the dome jutting off of Lombard street as you look towards the Golden Gate Bridge). Parking is pretty straightforward, they have free parking in along the park and on the side of the Palace itself. I would just be careful leaving valuables in the car since I've seen shattered glass from time to time. Honestly, it's a tourist spot so I'm sure thieves take advantage of that. 

The location can get pretty crowded during the weekends so try to come on weird hours (I don't know, this isn't really a restaurant so what are odd hours?). 

Last notes. Bring a jacket! It's like always windy here when I go
author: Wiseley F.

description: We didn't do much here but we had pictures taken at a park near by and our photographer made us stop by. So glad he did. Just another beautiful place to see if San Francisco.
author: Erik W.

description: This is one of my favorite places in San Francisco. It's so peaceful, it's like an oasis inside the big city. The building is gorgeous. I love the pond with ducks swimming, and the little fountain. A nice place to just sit and read.
author: Rachelle L.

description: While walking home from the beach a large dome caught my eye. My wife and I had nothing to do so we quickly be b-lined to see what it was all about. The closer we got closer we saw a small sign that read Palace of Fine Arts. I have never heard of it so quickly googled it to see what is all about. Once I saw a few pictures I knew we had to keep going .This place was insane it felt like I was in a different country. Right off the bat we were greeted by huge towering pillars. I  was in complete awe and disappointed in all my friends that have visited prior to us and did not tell us to go see this place. It felt like we had gone back in time. Everything is massive and ornately decorated. It must be some sort of hidden gem because for a few minutes we were the only people there. I had to stop to remind myself to put the camera down and take it all in. It has a roman feel to it and what I can only imagine a rich history as well. I did not gather information as to what it represented so if anyone knows feel free to message me. If I lived there I would grab a book and spend many an hour taking in this magnificent place. I only attached one picture but will have to be sure to download the rest off of my camera and update the review.
author: Eric S.

description:
The architecture of this place is great. I love the view of the water fountain and big columns. 

The Palace of Fine Arts in the Marina District of San Francisco, California, is a monumental structure originally constructed for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition in order to exhibit works of art presented there. One of only a few surviving structures from the Exposition, it is still situated on its original site. It was rebuilt in 1965, and renovation of the lagoon, walkways, and a seismic retrofit were completed in early 2009.

In addition to hosting art exhibitions, it remains a popular attraction for tourists and locals and is a favorite location for weddings and wedding party photographs for couples throughout the San Francisco Bay Area and such an icon that a miniature replica of it was built in Disney's California Adventure in Anaheim.
author: Ashi C.

description:
This is one of the most beautiful places in San Francisco. The outside scenery is all free to walk through. As will everywhere, parking is limited. I was told that many people choose to have their wedding pictures taken here. It is just like a park. There are benches all around for your convenience. Its a very quiet and peaceful place if you need a break from all major tourist spots. It was really enjoyable.

TIPS:
1. Its a short 1.7 downhill hike from the Golden Gate Bridge. You cant miss it.
2. There is a public restroom across from the Palace of Fine Arts at the park by the boats.
author: Sam N.

description:
This is a definitely a good place to walk around. My cousin suggested to visit here with my family. And it turned out the weather so breeze and enjoying the historical building here. And of course with some nice photo shot with the art of building as background.

I would recommended to come visit here if you haven't been here before. Awesome place to stop by and visit!
author: Jaane F.

description: Lovely place to walk around and enjoy the gorgeous architecture and view of the bridge. Really a spectacular spot,  never expected a place left me this in the city. The nearby neighborhood had tons of great places to eat as well. Don't miss this piece of urban tranquility!!
author: Mark R.

description:
This place is absolutely gorgeous. A must see if you are ever in San Fransisco. The sculptures, and architecture of the buildings are just breath taking. There were so many things going on here. Graduations, Weddings, Quinceanera photo shoots... The list goes on. There is a huge pond that wraps around the front of the building. It's definitely the cherry on top of the ice cream. Hehe! There are so many ducks, koi fish, and even cute little turtles. I was in awe. I would highly recommend coming here if you want to take family, engagement, scenic pictures. Thank you San Fran for a memorable experience. Can't wait to come back again. 


P.S: For all you Pokemon Go users..... I caught like 10 Water Pokemon here. So if you're looking for a Squirtle..... Mhmmmmmmm hahahaha
author: Keiki-O-Kalani A.

description: One of those places you shouldn't miss out on stopping by. This is one of my favorite places when visiting San Francisco. What's fun about this site, it's how your perspective changes depending on your location. If you are by the presidio park, all you are able to see it's the top portion of the palace, as you drive or walk closer it takes your breath away. The palace is quite tall and the tranquillity that surrounds the location gives you a sense of peace. You will see a lot of people getting married or taking portraits since the location and color of the scenery is the perfect spot. Come check out more pics of San Francisco on my Instagram @bohemianprovisions
author: Ana T.

description:
This place is gorgeous! I would love to come back here during sunset to take some better photos with the sunset lighting. Lighting is everything. 

There are plenty of benches and grassy areas if you would like to just have a seat, or have lunch at the park. There's a Hunger Games Exhibition inside the park, but you need to pay for that. 

Since this place is so well known, there will be tons of tourists (especially on weekends), so if you can, go during weekdays, or non-peak times. You'll be able to get photos without random people in them!

There's free parking all around the neighborhood, and I was lucky enough to nab a spot pretty close. I believe there are also nearby lots where you can pay, if you choose to park there. 

ALSO: Great place to catch some Pokemon if you're playing Pokemon Go. Tons of PokeStops!
author: Michelle T.

description:
What a beautiful place! This is a must stop! Enjoy the park, take a stroll & be prepared for some beautiful pictures! I can see why this is a popular venue for weddings!
Speaking of love, I was fortunate enough to see a proposal happen right there while I was strolling the park! So beautiful, wishing the happy couple well!
Enjoy the Greco-Roman style rotundas & collar aides and admire the beautiful swans swim in the lagoon. 
Explore the gallery inside. When we went, The Hunger Games Exhibit was in town. Such an amazing experience!
author: Phylicia K.

description: An amazing delight in the marina district of SF. This structure seems like something you would see it Europe. It was built to commemorate the Pan American games. If your looking for a lovely, romantic destination this is it. The palace is on a beautiful park with a pond. An ideal place for a picnic.
author: Susan S.

description:
Whether its a clear sunny day or a starry night, the Palace of Fine Arts is a must-visit place for tourists and locals alike.  Its an ideal place for photos for any occasion - weddings, graduations, family picnics and get togethers, etc.

We came here since there was a dance show at the Palace of Fine Arts Theater (which is reviewed separately), and had some time afterwards to walk around the grounds before dinner.  There is also a separate "Hunger Games" Exhibition inside the park grounds - wished we had time to stop bye!

As for parking, agree its tricky.  I used one of the nearby pay lots ($1.50/hr) on 1040 Edie St. A 10-15 minute walk is all good just to avoid the stress from traffic around the palace.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Of all my times coming to NorCal, I finally took the time to stop by here. We stopped by in the evening, so we were able to take in the architectural beauty of the place. There were no events going on at the time.
This place sits on the southern side of the Golden Gate Bridge. Parking was not hard to find, and there are plenty of walkways around the building and waterways to explore. This place is picturesque and impressive. I saw many fellow photography enthusiasts taking advantage of this modern wonder. For further information, see photos.
There is a small park on the premises, with benches to enjoy the sights. The walkways go around the park, and into the area where the event center sits, as well as the arches. At night time, the lighting here makes it look amazing. I recommend coming here at night, it makes for a great romantic walk.
I'll be back during the day, and I will update my review accordingly. In the meantime, come check this place out!
author: William G.

description: Awesome spot in the city for photos or just to have a small little picnic. The little lake around it has ducks,swans, and turtles living there.  The architecture around it is beautiful for pictures!! I see a lot of people here taking Wedding and Prom photos! The best thing is it's free outside to walk around and Day or Night the place is worth seeing!!
author: Elvin D.

description:
One of the highlights of my trip! 
So beautiful, and a must see in person. I can't believe the view of the houses around the neighborhood get to see every single day. 
The architecture is simply gorgeous!
author: Marinela A.

description: GORGEOUS!!! i like going in the evening when the sun is setting. the angle at which the lights shine on the architecture is really breathtaking. this is a nice place to stroll around, have a picnic, take photos, and just relax. this is also a nice place to go for a nice run!
author: Jamie C.

description: As elegant as it is historic. The towering architecture is enough to leave you breathless, but be prepared! There are always a ton of photo shoots going on.
author: Lisa D.

description: The Palace of Fine Arts is the perfect location for photoshoots. There's very much to appreciate. It's very well designed and detailed, there's small lake, and even some wild life. It wasn't as fun as Alcatraz or Golden gate Park, but it's worth a visit, even if just for a few minutes.
author: Chris G.

description:
Oh ya .... apart from the architecture, this place is just beautiful and a must see... 
make sure you Go on a bright sunny day...
author: Victor D.

description:
I've been here a long, long time ago for photos when my friend got married in San Francisco.  

After high school, she had gone away to college at Stanford, then got a job in California, and met her then husband.  Many years have passed and my friend is happier with her second husband and 2 children.  

The Palace of Fine Arts remains the same despite life changes... It's still magnificent, awesome, and full of grandeur.  It has survived through all kinds of weather and the ups and downs of life.  It will remain majestic and beautiful for many more years and bring back memories to tourists and create more memories for new visitors!

The next goal would be to come in the evening and during the nighttime with different lighting.  The photos will also be beautiful!  Maybe we can catch a close up or two of the swans and ducks!  There's free street parking and no admission fee!!  It's so easy and convenient!
author: Nadine C.

description:
Natural Beauty. This was a must on my list of places to visit in SF. Not only is the structure amazingly gorgeous, but it is such a nice area to sit and relax and escape the realities of adulthood and work. 

HISTORY LESSON: A long time ago, there was talk about knocking the dome and pillars down because it had no geographic value (they wanted to build homes) but the millionaires at the time donated a ton of money to keep this alive because of it's beauty and "peacefulness" and this continued for a few years that it finally became a historical landmark and tourist destination for San Francisco. Currently, anyone that wants to reserve this for conventions or any shows, they pay rent to the city.

A lot of residents not only come here for the peace & quiet but they also come here for prom pictures, wedding pictures, any event because it's just absolutely breathtaking. I wish I could come here everyday. Very good to take a stroll & just appreciate the architectural genius of the place. 

I highly HIGHLY recommend that you come here. Enjoy the peace, keep it clean & bring bread for the swans, ducks, turtles and fish to eat. They're huge & like I said, it's just the place to be!
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
Always a great place to go when you have visitors, want to have a picnic on a nice day, or simply just to stroll around. Lots of people enjoying the same artwork as you, so be respectful to one another.

The craftsmanship of the Palace is beautiful. This is where the old Exploratorium used to be located. A few movies were filmed here too, for the movie buffs. 

Swans, ducks, geese, turtles, fish in the pond. I've been to Rome and seen the old ruins. I've been to Paris to see the Arc of Triomphe. Of course, it doesn't compare to those, but it's nice to see great architecture in little ol' San Francisco. There's lots to marvel about in the city, and this place is surely one of them.

Street parking is plentiful in the neighborhoods. You can gawk at the beauty of the luxurious homes nearby too!
author: Steffi G.

description: Tip: park for free at Chrissy Field by the beach and walk across the street to the a palace of Fine Arts. One of the many beautiful places in the city! The architecture is amazing and everyone I bring to visit loves it,especially since we can enjoy going to the beach afterwards!
author: Keisha K.

description: I've been wanting to visit since my last trip to San Francisco! I wish I went last time so I could have come back again!
author: Taylor P.

description: Absolutely beautiful. Amazing built in 1915 for an exposition. It has been restored. I do wish they had a little security walking around. Some idiots climbed up on the building and were doing a photo shoot. Even though it said not to climb on every single ledge they climbed on. And people stepping over dividers into the flower beds for photos. People can be so disrespectful. Lots of birds turtles and a swan or two swimming in the pond.  Wonderful piece of history and architecture.
author: Phil B.

description: What a beautiful place to walk around and enjoy! There's a lot of areas to take photos and it's a nice calm and serene atmosphere amongst the busy city. We witnessed a couple have a very low-key and intimate wedding ceremony while we were here and it was nice to see that this is that kind of place where people want to remember where they tied the knot.
author: Patricia C.

description:
Good place for photos! Don't be stupid, don't club those big steps that clearly don't look like stairs. 

Go to place for taking friends from out of town! Pretty close to Golden Gate Bridge as well, so swing by that way too! 

I've walked here from the financial district...take an uber/lyft/cab unless you like walking like I do. It was probably not a good idea to wear 3 inch chunky boots that day.
author: Dianna C.

description:
Tourist must stop!

If you are in the San Francisco area visiting, live here or coming to live here this place is a must have for your bay area bucket list. 

Free to the public to take pictures or tour around. This is one of the most popular venues for wedding photos, picnics and site seeing. i absolutely love this place and even the architecture makes you feel like you're in another world. 

Absolutely the picture of romance and essence of bay area culture and arts.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Besides the influx of tourists and parties of families, friends, and couples gathering for weddings, Quinceaneras, or even PDA time, the Palace of Fine Arts is a splendid attraction in the Northwest Part of San Francisco. Whether you are a longtime resident, a tourist, or a newly minted citizen of "the city," the Palace of Fine Arts has been around an insanely long time that it should demand at least one visit from you.

I think I remember passing by the Palace when I was an itty bitty child, but recently had the opportunity of spending some time here over the weekend. As mentioned, this place gets crowded FAST! Finding parking isn't impossible, even over the weekend. Just drive out a bit farther toward the marina and you'll see plenty of neighborhood parking spots. 

The Palace itself is gorgeous. There's a reason why so many people come here to take pictures and share a romantic moment. In the daytime, you can really get a sense of how beautiful this place is. And at night, when all the lights are on, you feel like you are in a different world.

tl;dr The Palace of Fine Arts should be on your own thrillist of places to visit in the city.
author: Bryan W.

description:
Un-freaking-believable. I honestly can't believe that a place like this can exist. As a Los Angeles native, we really don't have amazing buildings like these around. 

Such a peaceful place. Of course the weather was below 0 (felt like it to me anyway, hello, La native) so that put a tiny hamper on the enjoyment. But I still took my time and walked around. Came during the nighttime so not much going on and lots of tourists but still a site to see if you're ever in the area.
author: Anna M.

description:
Palace of Fine Arts is a lovely place to go and have a picnic lunch, a nice place to take family portraits or even just a nice place to relax and get away from the city life. There is plenty of Roman Greek inspired architecture to admire and a beautiful lake that doesn't smell funny! I look forward to stopping here on our trips to the city. Parking can be tricky but hey, at least there is no charge for admission!

2016 Review #11
author: Stephanie G.

description:
What I know of the Palace of Fine Arts, I know from the movie The Rock. So when the Big Bus Tour stopped here, I took advantage of the opportunity to take a look at this historic building and the park that surrounds it.

In all my travels, the closest thing that I've seen to a structure like this is Marble Arch in London and the Arc de Triomphe in Paris. The size of it, you just can't believe the building from a distance or underneath the dome. It's amazing.

And then is this huge lagoon, complete with swans and geese and ducks. Yep, even in January there was a good flock of the buggers being fed bread crumbs by a tourist.
