Well worth the stop! What an amazing building!
author: Bruce K.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is such a beautiful historical landmark. 

I would love to have time to walk more leisurely here another time, especially at night! I've seen many lovely, illuminating pictures of this place in the evening, but would love to experience the majestic lights and sights myself after sunset. 

First time I walked here was in Fall of 2015. People such as families are happy being here and comfortable to ask me to take their pictures. I'm like a skillful photographer when somebody asks me to take their pics. So, I happily said yes to that family, and they were very thankful.  

On another instance, a lady saw me walking alone beside the map and taking pictures of the glory all around me, then she asked me can she touch my hair and some complimenting words! Ai ya. I hesitantly said yes so I could go about my way and continue my exploration. She was another random admirer of my long luscious locks of strands of hair. 

In the beginning, I asked a nice woman to take my picture with the lagoon and dome shaped structure behind me. Then, I walked towards my right along a pathway and lured by the cute birds. I saw swans and ducks. Seeing swans I walked quickly towards them since they swam away towards the other end of the lake and I was thinking oooooooo swans! Must get a picture. Luckily they were nearby enough and I was able to record a video too. ^_^ I rarely see swans in my city.

Continuing my walk around the lake path further to the tall pillars, I saw more pretty landscape too including plants and beautiful flowers. Finally reaching the dome, I was in awe when I was able to be amongst the wide, vast Roman & Greek architectural structures. Underneath the dome was beautiful! Wow, just simply amazing! Such beautiful designs and cool color. I liked seeing the angels. Perhaps they are guardians...those sculptures with wings. 

I tremendously admire the Beaux-Arts architecture. The dome, rotunda, colonnades, and lagoon are all very nice.

Grandiose. Spectacular. In complete awe :)
author: Andrea S.

description:
Going to San Francisco? Bookmark this place. By far, my favorite place I visited in SF - even getting an edge over the iconic Golden Gate Bridge. 

I truly felt like I was in a foreign country, and others said the same thing, too - the architecture is reminiscent of the Alhambra in Spain or Middle Eastern architecture. My jaw dropped and I was in awe the entire time I walked through this magnificent structure and strolled through the park - walk around to the side with benches and a pond for great panorama views of the Palace. 

I recommend going at the "golden hour" around dinner time or mid-morning for the best pictures - I ended up going at both times over the course of 24 hours because I loved this place so much. Many people come here for wedding and family photos, and I even saw a Saturday morning wedding here!

This park/monument is free and beautiful and many flock here for walks, photos and peace and quiet. 100% recommend checking it out!
author: Katie U.

description: Just a great place to wander around, enjoy the scenery, and take great pics. Well worth the trip if you are in the area. We were there right after taking sunset pictures of the bridge and there was a nice effect of the lighting inside the structure combined with the still bright sky.
author: Chris V.

description:
Growing up in San Francisco, you learn a lot about where things are and sometimes you don't appreciate, but I haven't been here for maybe 25 years. I used to take the little girl that I babysat for three years because her parents work at the Exploratorium.
 So twice a week we would come here, and then we would walk around. I let her run around the Palace of Fine Arts.

Well the day that we went, I took my brother and his wife, my sister and her husband, who is a history buff, historical with information and told us a lot of stuff about San Francisco. 

It was raining. It was cold. I was in my shorts, but I still went out walked around, took lots of video & pictures, saw the lake. There was actually someone in a wedding dress taking photos. I'm like no not when it's raining.

So, when it's sunny and gorgeous out, come and check out this place, and you can really enjoy the fine structure of the building and take some video and some beautiful photos. Thanks for Reading ~Liz~ :)
author: Lizzie G.

description:
A beautiful scenery that is perfect for photography in cloudy weather. 
Easy to find parking space
author: Ali M.

description: Came yesterday to take professional graduation pictures with my friends. Such a beautiful place. Now I see why it gets so crowded.
author: Cynthia M.

description: By far my favorite part of visting San Fransisco it was beautiful ! Loved it! Beautiful park to walk and relax and take pictures . Would be a great place for a date or a family day . I only walked around so can not say much more but it is lovely!
author: J C.

description:
I can't believe it took me so long to review this, but the Palace of Fine Arts is one of my most favourite spots in San Francisco. It's definitely a little under the radar when it comes to locations of San Francisco that tourists will name off from the top of their heads, but it should definitely receive a lot more attention that it has. 

I came here once during the day and once during night, both scenes were fabulous! The day shot is beautiful, it feels like you're in Europe for a second and a ton of people come here for their wedding pictures. The night view is magnificent as well, with beautiful golden lights shining on the structure of the building. Parking here at night is really easy to find as well!

COME HERE WHEN YOU VISIT SAN FRAN!
author: Kristy N.

description:
Alright this place is absolutely stunning. 

I have yet to visit Rome and the European continent but to stand beneath the pillars built upon the styles of the ancients was a magnificent experience. 

The architecture was so stunning, and the building itself was located in such a nice neighborhood and pond. 

But best of all this place was free. It's freeeeeeee! It means a lot to me since it seems like the entire city is trying to swindle money out of me.
author: Siamrath B.

description:
This place is so cool!  Had no idea this even existed and then my friend and I stumbled into it while taking a walk around the city.  It's gorgeous!  Fantastic views and inside there was a little art display along with games...who knew?  

Check it out if you're in the area.  You won't be disappointed.  :)
author: Jessica C.

description:
You don't have to go to a showing to appreciate this beautiful architecture! As the last remnant of the Panama Expo venues, Palace of Fine Arts is a historical landmark that is a fine example of Greco-Roman structure in central San Francisco. It's worth taking a drive there to admire and snap a photo of this beauty! Even on a rainy day, the beauty never ceased to awe me. 

Street parking is often very limited but you will not need more than 30 minutes here.
author: Jay Y.

description: This is a beautiful place where I see so many SF people come dressed in their prom dresses, wedding dresses, tuxedos and foreigners from all over the world come and take pictures. This place feels a little bit like Italy with the high columns with statues and a peaceful small lake with swans and turtles. They now serve Poke Bowls and Korean BBQ beef at the cafe from Poke Delish! It's located inside the double front doors.
author: Linh G.

description:
I know, I know, such a tourist spot, but for good reason!  Hear me out!

For all my years in NorCal, I have never ventured to PoFA.  Even though it's free, I tend to avoid tourist spots like Joan Rivers's face avoids movement.  Too many photoshoots, crowded, no parking.. what a nightmare, right?  But, I found a parking lot out by the Presidio Arts Center that's worth the walk, since the Arts Center has a nice view itself and you can see the Golden Gate bridge beyond the freeway.

The Palace is so simple, yet so majestic.  I couldn't help but laugh at how I went to Europe in search for architecture like this, when there's one right in our backyard!  And imo, ours is even better, because PoFA has WATER.  You can see so many different species at this bird refuge.  Swans swimming alongside with last night's dinner (ducks) and other fowl that look just as tasty.  My eyes sure had a feast.

Skip the Exploratorium.. it's pretty small and spacious.  I felt bad since it was funded by donations only, but with a great view outdoors, who wants to go indoors?!  Except of course, for their popcorn, which you can purchase inside.

This place has it all.. architecture, history, nature, wildlife, and popcorn!  Being here makes you forget all about the concrete-jungle surroundings.  Speaking of concrete, you lazy mofo's need to walk around on the concrete and not cross through the lawns!  This tramples the grass and degrades the scenic view.  Thank you.  My Greenpeace duty has been done.
author: Regina N.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is located in a sneaky beaky location. The turn for it (Lyon St) is on Lombard and right before it becomes a highway again. Go and find street parking, and you can spend a good hour here just walking around taking pictures. There's the main Palace, which is circular and is a great place to hide on a hot day, shielding you from the sun. It's beautiful and reminds you of European architecture. 

There is also a lake in the middle, and the surrounding parts is a park, where you can walk around and enjoy the ducks all around. You can bring your camera (must) and try and find the perfect angle, because it changes as the sun shadows change. 

A great place to just relax and forget about the taxing items in life.
author: Raymond L.

description: Like taking a walk through history.  One of the most beautiful architecture I have ever seen.  The lake really adds to the beauty as well.  Expect to get some good pictures here.  I have had friends that took wedding pictures here. Parking is not that bad to find on the streets and neighborhood.  There is a cafe and game room located here too.  Swing by for a visit if you are in the area, you won't regret it.
author: Dang L.

description: Very beautiful, even though it's not one of my favor places in San Francisco, but still pretty decent. There is a lake and you can see goose jumping into the lake. It's a pretty good place for a walk.
author: Robert J.

description:
Such a gorgeous place! If you are visiting San Francisco, add this to your plan to stop by- definitely a tourist must stop!

The architecture is just beautiful. The water lagoon surrounding it is calming, even when busy with visitors. This would be a great place for some awesome photos. The day we were here, a wedding photography session was going on. 

Just strolling along the landmark, small water oasis surrounding it was just peaceful. 

The few times I had been to SF, hadn't gotten a chance to check this place out. So happy I was able to stop by  during this visit.
author: Yukta R.

description: This place is so gorgeous. I have been here a hundred times because of elementary and middle-school field trips and countless photo shoots with my mom for our Christmas cards haha. It's nice if you want to actually visit and go inside or even if you just want to take some classy photos outside! There's parking on the street that is usually easy to find. Even though there are a lot of people who hang out here, it never feels overcrowded to me.
author: Brittany R.

description:
This is somewhat of an interesting review, but my friend recommended checking this landmark out, so here goes. 

The Palace of Fine Arts is more of an area of the city than an actual location. There are events being held and a theater area, but in my opinion, it is the perfect place to take a stroll through in the city. It is typically quiet, intimate, and a nice area to have a picnic and relax. It is quite beautiful on the outside and I have only had a chance to walk around the theater area once. Really enjoyed taking pictures around here! 

I would recommend taking advantage of this beautiful architecture and the area surrounding it with friends, family, or a date. I guarantee you that it will be more fun than you realize. Whenever we pass by at night, the structure lights up and makes for one spectacular view.
author: Steve N.

description: Absolutely gorgeous!! I went for a run recently from Pac Heights to the Marina and hit the Palace of Fine Arts in between. Though I didn't get to enjoy the inside, the outdoors alone was already breathtaking. The building is surrounded by a beautiful lake with a fountain. The reflection of the building on the water is so aesthetically pleasing. Definitely worth a trip.
author: Elysse P.

description:
If someone wanted to describe heaven in this raucous city. This would have to be on the top of the list. For years I have wondered where this gorgeous spot was and finally had the opportunity.

It is worth visiting several times, I could see myself never getting tire of seeing this spot like the first time. The images online do it no justice, think of it like the Grand Canyon. Ok, maybe not to that level but it is quite a beauty to see in person. 

Take a picnic and watch the birds fly over the lake. Great place to people watch as you see life unfold. This is a very popular spot for wedding or cotillion photo shoots. Truest extraordinary watching a glimpse of life.

But if you had to go at the perfect time, go 1 hour before sunset. The sun shines through the arcs with an amazing glow. The whole place gives a golden horizon. Great spot to meet up and stroll through the area as you gaze a beauty. Highly recommend to any tourist and even the newly transplant.
author: Enrique G.

description:
This place is gorgeous. It's right up there with Golden Gate bridge if you're visiting San Fran. You don't even have to stay here long, but you might end up doing that while admiring how friggin' HUGE and beautiful these structures are! 

It's also great to take photos. My cousin and I ended up posting basically the same photo of ourselves on social media. 

I seriously have no more words for this place. Just check it out!
author: Neal N.

description: This place is so beautiful and peaceful. The architecture is STUNNING. you really feel like you're in a different cojnrry. Came here to relax and lie down in the grass after a busy day of tourist activities. Recommend this place to anyone who is looking for a relaxing activity.
author: Olivia W.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is a beautiful spot to walk through! While strolling through the palace, there were many people taking engagement photos.

For the best picture, stand on the side of the lake closest to the street. This way, you'll have the whole lake behind you along with the palace. Go at a time when lighting is in your favor. It's beautiful close to sunset but the shadow tends to fall on you when trying to take a picture, which makes lighting an issue. I think that the morning would probably be best.

The grounds itself are larger than expected so I didn't get to explore the whole area, but it was a peaceful area to walk around with friends!
author: Courtney O.

description: Such a Greek style of art area attracts a lot of people here for photo shooting. We felt so relaxed and yet soaked into the art. Such a good fine art place that we will come back next time to spend more time here to go inside and explore next time.
author: Karmen S.

description: One of the prettiest places in the city. Beautiful little lake and lovely paths around this old antique of a building (a Maybeck, beaux-art style architecture style). The time of day and season will change your experience because of the reflections, light, and landscaping.  For some reason I always get lucky with parking, but I hear locals usually bus or walk. It's super easy to get to right off the bridge after you've done it once. It's in the Marina District, which is considered a posh neighborhood with younger people and there's easy access to the Marina, Chrissy Field, and Chestnut St..
author: Judy L.

description:
What you will get is...a mixture of pride and prejudice setting, old Roman ruins (definitely not Roman tho), and...ducks!  Haha! No seriously the lake and birds were amazing too!

I seriously feel this is one of the top spots in SF. The peace the architecture the FEELING good God the FEELING!! Come here you'll fall in love just like we did!!
author: Sarah M.

description:
Absolutely gorgeous architecture! 

This stop was one of the more memorable places with the history and design.  I was told it was the most popular places for wedding photos.  When you arrive here you can see why.  

The rotunda itself is beautiful but you'll notice the paneled columns around it with the weeping women sculptured on top.  It really is an amazing piece of art.  

There is a fabulous lagoon in the front with a pretty water feature.   Swans, ducks and other wildlife were enjoying their home making it serene.  

I was lucky to stop here and appreciate it.  It's surely is a piece of fine art.
author: Bethany E.

description: Just huge and amazing site to see. The artwork and architect is so awesome! Nice to walk around and stroll with hour love one, so romantic! A must see and the best part is they have a game room that I let my fiance win at jenga and ping pong table!
author: Tammy C.

description:
I'm honestly not a big San Francisco fan due to traffic, overrated hipsters (sorry), and overpriced things. The Palace of Fine Arts is a definite gem in San Francisco. I've been here many times with friends and family; never have I been tired of looking at the immaculate architecture.

They have held many events here: weddings, orchestras, photoshoots, etc. I've seen a few women get proposed here and all I can say is, "damn, what an awesome place to do so." Lol.

Walking here at night is even better. With dim lights, the sound of water, and the beautiful scenery really sets the aura of being calm. Whether you come during the day or night, you'll find yourself enjoying your time there.

I highly recommend this place for locals and tourists. Oh, and don't mind the houses surrounding the park, they're only just about $4 million lol.
author: Shannen R.

description:
This place is absolutely stunningly GORGEOUS!!! A must see for sure when visiting SF. The architecture makes you feel like you are in Greece or Italy, but your heart smiles a little when you remember this treasure is in California. 

You can take a walk around the huge pond and soak in the beauty of the place and its quaint neighborhood. Great place for photo ops! We saw lots of wedding pictures being taken today. 

It is also a 5 minute cross walk over away from Chrissy Fields which is a beach with insane views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz. 

I tend to hit these two places up when I'm at either one of the locations because the breathtaking views at both never get old.
author: Lin S.

description:
Gorgeous architectural work...I wish I could come here during the daytime to admire it more!

The only two times I've been here were at night. And even though it's great to see it lit up, I still haven't gotten the opportunity to admire it with full sunlight - and I'm sure it is way more beautiful. 

There are swans in the body of water in front of it (so cute!) and plenty of parking all around the structure...whether it is free during the daytime, I'm unsure, but I know in the evenings it feels like you have unlimited access. 

Since SF is such a distance from home and the hassle of driving in the city makes me less inclined to return, I'll catch this beauty during the day whenever I have a reason to come back!
author: Melanie B.

description: I didn't actually get to go inside but we stopped by the Palace of Fine Arts while biking up to Saucelito and it was totally worth a few minutes of our lives.  I thought that I was in France and Chopin was playing the piano somewhere!  Definitely a great place to stroll around and enjoy the ducks as well as the intricate details of this palace.
author: Monica G.

description:
Seriously one of the most beautiful tourist spot to take pictures at while visiting SF. This was one of our pit stop while attempting to hit all the tourist attractions in one day. We found free street parking quickly and walked on over to the amazing view of architectural structures. 

It really does make for a nice back drop to add to the memory book. We took about half an hour walking around the whole thing and soaking it its beauty, taking all the pictures we could. Pictures really doesn't do any justice but the experience of being there is all the worthwhile.

There's also a great lawn in front to hang out and have a picnic or just leisurely spend the day there with friends, family or your significant other. There are benches as well to sit and admire the view even with the swans, birds, and turtles lurking in the pond. We watched an artist in front capturing the beauty of the landscape. 

It was a sunny warm day as well when we went so it was a nice walk around the palace grounds. It's FREE so definitely recommended for all to see especially for those who love history and architect. I could even imagine how gorgeous it would look at night, wish I was able to have seen it during the evening time.
author: Roxanne Lynn T.

description: This is such a gorgeous place! Stunning architecture, lovely pond and beautiful trees. Awesome spot in the city for photos!
author: Olga P.

description: Such a beautiful area. We came too visit and walk our dog. It was so nice and peaceful. Definitely worth coming here.
author: Lsxo S.

description:
I was playing tour guide and trying to figure out where to take my out of town guest. As we drove around the City, I realized we were close enough to Palace of Fine Arts to swing by for a stop. 

I hope the name doesn't throw people off because it's simply a landmark and there are no "arts" to see. That said, the setting is beautiful. It doesn't take a genius to be able to take incredible photos here from all angles. We spent a good amount of time strolling around the lake and then sitting on the grass just enjoying the day.
author: Yi Z.

description:
This is one of the finest gems in San Francisco. I remember when the Exploratorium used to be here and when Palace of the Fine Arts wasn't all that popular. I always get a little sad when hidden gems get too popular because of how crowded it gets. But nonetheless, it offers a beautiful place to take pictures, to take a stroll, to take it what SF has to offer.

It's especially wonderful if you come at night because of all the beautiful lights and the beautiful scenery it offers. Either day or night, Palace of the Fine Arts is a wonderful place. 

Overall, I highly recommend coming here, even if it's just for a quick visit. Whether you're a tourist or a local, this is a must to visit.
author: Wendy Y.

description:
I'm here for he first time for a play my GF wanted to see. The place seems to be nice. Seats aren't very new anymore, but comfy for what they look like. 
We got cheaper tickets in the back (S/33) but the view into the stage is great. 

Small advice: don't buy a hot tea before entering. They make you buy a cup for 3 bucks ;-)
author: Dario S.

description:
This is one of those most-photographed places. There's probably no earthly need for YET another shot but what the hell.  To me it is where they shot a scene of The Rock, a movie with Nick Cage and Sean Connery where Sean Connery met his daughter played by Claire Forlani after escaping from the FBI, only to be found and taken back into custody.

The rotunda is all that's left of the structures built for The Panama Pacific Exposition of 1915. Actually it isn't even supposed to be here as everything built for the event was designed to be temporary and constructed of materials easily torn down a year later. Someone decided to rescue this one though, and what you see is a concrete duplicate of the original. Benches surrounding the lake where you can bring lunch and enjoy the view of the Palace and see the birds gathering by the lake. 

Love bringing  friends visiting from out of town because of it's beauty  it was built to resemble overgrown Roman ruins.  Awesome place also  a favorite backdrop for a wedding photoshoot. It's easy to see why - lovely gardens, romantic fountain, and historic building makes this a popular place to go.  It is near Crissy Field and beautiful Marina neighborhood surrounds this attraction. Five stars for me!
author: Maria M.

description:
I'm usually more of a fan of visiting natural wonders rather than man made architecture.  But WOW...the palace of fine arts was jaw-droppingly beautiful!  The architecture of the Palace of Fine Arts formed a mutualistic relationship with the scenic lake, in which the man made structure accented the beauty of the surrounding nature, and vice versa.  The two beautiful swans and ducks gliding through the blue water also enhanced my experience at the Palace of Fine Arts. The architecture was so impressive that I was willing to overlook the fact that it was a slight misnomer.  It was more of a free standing structure than a palace in which you could wander inside of, but it was beautiful nevertheless.  

On the grass surrounding the lake were people sunbathing, enjoying a good book, or having picnics.  What a nice environment for family bonding, catching up with friends, or spending quality alone time with yourself! 

This scenic landmark is also highly recommended as a backdrop for romantic engagement/wedding/friendship photos!
author: Vy N.

description: The Palace is a really wonderful landmark that everyone should see when they come to San Francisco. I really enjoyed walking around the small park area and taking it all in. Parking is limited, but it is worth the hassle.
author: Adam S.

description: This place is breathtaking! Stumbled across it walking to the beach and I'm so glad i did. So beautiful, pictures don't do it justice. The pond was full of ducks and turtles. Pretty flowers all around with beautiful trees. Seems like a great place to walk your dog or go for a jog.
author: Gracie N.

description:
POFA has recently become my new favorite place to take out-of-towners....as well as myself!  Along with the Pier 39 sea lions, Filbert Steps, and Sutro Baths, POFA packs a big punch for such a small investment (all of these glorious places are free, by "investment" I mean cheap Uber ride to get there)

We arrived on a sunny and warm summer Sunday and, WOW! The nature here was performing.  We had more fun that a group of 30-something adults should have just hanging out watching the ducks, ducklings, herons, and turtles.  Such a peaceful and serene landscape is such a great juxtaposition in a bustling big city.  

Make sure to wear comfy shoes as there are plenty of paths and places to discover.  There are so many gorgeous vista points here to use as photo backdrops!
author: Andrea H.

description:
Absolutely beautiful!  And the best part is, it's FREE.  No cost to walk these gorgeous grounds or take pictures next to structures that make you feel like you're in a different time period.  After all, it is inspired by Roman and Greek architecture.  The lagoon is so picturesque, and we saw turtles and ducklings swimming around when we went.  Cute!

It was originally built in 1915 for the Panama-Pacific International Exhibition, or world's fair, then re-structured in 1965.  Definitely read up on it.  

Thank you, SF, for making this lovely place completely accessible to the public.
author: Emmeline C.

description:
A beautiful place in a beautiful city. If it's a nice day and you have comfortable walking shoes, you can walk here from the Golden Gate Bridge. Otherwise they have free buses from GGB and just ask the driver when you should get off.

There are plenty of spots for picture taking, but the best part is just walking the grounds and enjoying the beauty. One of my favorite movies was filmed here. Plan to spend as little as 20 mins to an hour here if your schedule permits.
author: Roll N.

description: I so much wanted to love this place! Don't get me wrong the architecture, surrounding grounds and the lake are all gorgeous but there is no ART like nothing, zero! I When I first heard about it in my mind I imagined this place to be the equivalent of Louvre or any other major European museum but unfortunately no! Its sad that the place couldn't be filled with some historic or art pieces, it would definitely make this location stand out! I guess this is a perfect place for some elegant outdoor photography!
author: WarmCoffeeHub ..

description:
I love this place. Beautiful. It can get a little crowded at times but it's FREE! Great for a quick little walk or even to stop by while biking around the city.

I usually try to stop by when biking from the Ghiradelli/pier 39 to the Golden Gate park/bridge.

Parking is very limited and can be a pain.
author: John L.

description: This a must-visit place. Near Golden Gate Bridge. Stunning palace
author: Tim H.

description:
Bottom Line:  A lovely park with a historic structure as the crowning jewel.

The Palace of Fine Arts doesn't resemble what one may traditionally think of as a palace.  Rather, the Palace of Fine Arts is an urban park with a Roman/Greek inspired structure at its center consisting of an impressive rotunda and colonnade.  The brief history on the Palace of Fine Arts is that it was one of many buildings built for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition.  The Panama-Pacific Exposition was a world's fair that celebrated the completion of the Panama Canal.  But like most, or all, world's fair buildings, the building were meant to be temporary.   In the case of the Panama-Pacific Expo, the fair was only scheduled to run nine months.  Nevertheless, the Palace of Fine Arts survived many decades before it had to be torn down and rebuilt.  Although the structure was completely rebuilt in the 1960s it was built using the original design and the original foundation.  Even better, in this century the historic landmark was once again altered to withstand future seismic activity. 

Until fairly recently the Exploratorium, a family friend science and art museum, used to be in an old exhibit hall immediately adjacent to the Palace building.  The Exploratorium has since relocated to Embarcadero Pier 15 so the real attraction at the Palace of Fine Arts is the historic structure, serene lagoon, migrating waterfowl, sunbathing turtles, flora and fauna.  The Palace of Fine Arts is surrounded by a level paved walking path that is friendly for brides on a photo shoot, families with little ones in strollers and the elderly that need a little stability from a handy dandy walker.  Those wanting to admire the beauty of this park for a little longer can bring a picnic lunch and sit on the nearby grass.  

Until recently I had only seen the Palace of Fine arts as a curiosity on the horizon.  I am glad I finally got to the Marina District to check out this fascinating piece of California history.  Props to all of those individuals and organizations who have fought tirelessly to save and restore this unique landmark.
author: Courtney K.

description: Walking around the grounds was gorgeous. You can see genuine historical architecture go to Prague, Rome, London, etc.. Great!
author: Arielle L.

description:
WOWZERS!!!! 

What a beautiful place. 

Don't get me started with the pictures. This place is fantastic for taking pictures. It is crowded during the weekends. I was lucky i found parking right in front of the location, only like ten cars fit there. 

Unless if you park on the street there should be some with some luck.
author: Jannie M.

description: Absolutely GORGEOUS! Breathtaking once you arrive and you don't believe your eyes. The structures are beautiful and the walk around the grounds to see them is so enjoyable. The photos we took are gorgeous. The swans were the icing on the cake. They were talking to one another and it was so sweet to watch.
author: Nicole O.

description:
Love it.... The PoFA is such an iconic landmark in San Francisco. It stands shoulder to shoulder with all the other famous sights in the city. My personal preference is to visit it at night. It's beautifully lit and really breathtaking to look at. When you first walk up on it, you really realize what a big structure it is and how beautiful the architecture really is. Walk the grounds, walk along the little lake and dont forget to look up because it truly is a wonder.

Great place for photos and more than likely, you will see a photo shoot going on during your visit. It's a common engagement/wedding photo as the backdrop can truly be breathtaking... The surrounding homes in the Marina arent bad either.
author: Chuck D.

description:
This place is truly beautiful.  Pictures don't do justice. 

I've been wanting to come here for awhile so imagine my excitement when this was our first stop while exploring SF.  I came here mainly for cute pictures with my boyfriend, & that's exactly what we got!

We were able to find free street parking very easily and there is no admission fee to walk around.  Such a cute and romantic place with an amazing view & exquisite architecture.  We were here during the daytime, but I can imagine this place being just as beautiful at night.  I would've loved to been able to experience both but perhaps next time.
author: Regina O.

description:
If you are visiting SF make sure to stop here! The view is beautiful! You can enjoy a nice picnic here before heading to the Golden Gate Bridge (5-10 min away).  You can find parking near the residential areas across the street. 

Awesome Place!!
author: Wendy C.

description:
Yeah yeah yeah.. it's cliche, but stick with me here. 

1.) It's beautiful. So you have to take your tourist friends here
2.) It has a really interesting place in SF history
3.) Amazing architecture (maybe this is a duplicate of the beautiful part) but seriously. Check it out at night
4.) Watch out for the geese though. They get mean. They hang out on the side of the pond and I watched a kid battle one the other day, like a boss. He won, but I feared for that child's life. Geese are big.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description: This place is absolutey gorgeous!!! Very European like. Its a great place to just walk around and enjoy the beauty of the sculptures and the fresh air. They even have little ice cream stands to get some yummy ice cream which makes everything more enjoyable. Its a great place to picnic on the lawn area and go on a nice jog. Bringing a camera along is a MUST! definitely recommend to check palace of fine arts out!
author: Heather O.

description:
During my last afternoon in San Francisco I met with one of my very good friends who now calls the Bay area her home. She was nice enough to treat me to a very wonderful afternoon out. I told her I didn't want to see anywhere overtly tourist (besides the Golden Gate Bridge of course) and wanted to see places she loved to go. One of our first stops was the Palace of Fine Arts. 

Only two words can be used to describe the Palace: ABSOLUTELY BEAUTIFUL! 

Seriously, it was stunning. I was immediately jealous of whomever owned the homes directly across the street with the big picture windows. It must be amazing to wake up every morning and sit and sip your coffee looking at the stunning architecture that this building has. 

We took a nice leisurely stroll around the palace grounds, stopping for photoshoots with the ducks and to giggle at the fat little turtles that were happily swimming in the lake. We saw wedding photos being taken and a Quincenera girl with a stunning gown (whose colour scheme was much like the palaces) posing for her photos. 

Even though it was busy and active overall the palace grounds were incredibly tranquil. This would be a lovely place to take a book and a picnic and just sit and enjoy. 

So thankful I was able to visit.
author: Zoie H.

description: Stunning is the word I think of when thinking about this tourist attraction! The architecture is simply amazing and the park is very clean. The atmosphere is very relaxing, and the tour buses are told not to drive too close so as to not disturb the peace of the park! It would be perfect to read a book here on a summer day!
author: Amelia J.

description: Absolutely beautiful scenery! I've been to San Francisco a million times and never knew this was here. This is the kind of architectural landmark you'd see in Europe. There is a huge pond with tons of turtles swimming around (so cute!) although they need to clean the water because it looked pretty mossy/murky. We saw a pair of huge swans with a litter of teeny tiny swan babies on the lawn - it was the sweetest thing! I'm really glad we walked around here to enjoy the beautiful scenery that is so quintessential San Francisco. Thumbs up for me, cheers :-)
author: Lisa R.

description:
One of the most beautiful places in the world. No joke. It's really close to the Yoda statue, so there is that as well! 

This is seriously a majestic place and it always surprises me how not packed this place really is. Sure there are a decent amount of people, but it's never truly packed. A lot of people even come here to get married as it's that beautiful. No joke. It's truly a place that will leave an impression on you. 

The architecture is breathtaking and will leave you with a bit of drool going down your mouth. It's that kinda of place. You will truly feel at peace with the Earth when you're here and bring anyone who has never been to SF before. 

This is the place to visit if you want to slap yourself to make sure you're not dreaming.
author: Benny H.

description:
This place is beautiful!! 
The Size! The Craftsmanship!

The pillars and cathedral height ceilings will make you feel as though you have been transported back in time and far from SF. The overall detail is immaculate. 

This is without-a-doubt a must see if you are near the Bay Area. If you like photography this place offers up some amazing shots and also provides a nice are to sit relax and even have a picnic. 

Pictures do not do this place justice. You must see it in person to take in its full beauty and get the full effect.
author: Taylor F.

description:
I'm going to be a bit biased on my review here since its the location of my beautiful boutique outdoor wedding.

I like this because it radiates class, style and tradition with it's aesthetic architecture  and is very picturesque.

As an FYI - if you're planning a wedding, you'll need to contact the SF Park & Rec department to schedule a reservation to get a permit and there's a 2 hr minimum to rent the rotunda (underneath the dome) main area, which can hold up to about 250 guests.  As disclaimers to this as an event venue: 1) It's outdoors, subject to the elements of mother nature's weather; 2) No restrooms, other than if the neighboring indoor museum is open; 3) No electricity, and in fact you can only use battery powered amplification anyway; 4) You'll need additional permits for a reception (serving food/drink) as well as for any performances.  There's a whole set of "do's and don'ts" regulation, rules n' guidelines they both provide and can answer questions about.

You can just drop by and take photos for free, we've seen many wedding parties stop by with their photographers.  It's if/when you have an organized gathering that you need a permit for holding a service or formal get together.  Also, since it is a public venue, having a permit and reservations does not provide nor entitle you to exclusivity, and people can enter and potentially interfere, but most of those who visit are courteous.  What the permit provides you with is the rights to assemble, and if the Park Ranger comes by you'll need to have a permit.

The rotunda is nice, it gets a bit windy, but it is San Francisco, so it's to be expected to be unpredictable to plan too far ahead of time in advance for how the weather's going to be here.

It's open to the public and is a beautiful place to vist.

Parking is amazingly rather easy at the POFA too.
author: Rick S.

description:
Simply amazing. Wow.

Coming to the Palace of Fine Arts is one thing in the afternoon. Coming at night though, it's a completely different animal. A romantic and peaceful reflection of what humans can simply create is spectacular. Street parking sucks during the weekends (who can blame them, though), but fortunately the best time to visit the Palace of Fine Arts is at night! Parking heaven! 

The history is pretty unique, but I suppose you came to YELP not for a history lesson. All good! Inspired by Roman and Greek architecture, it's one of the spots that makes you do a double take. 

Every review has used words like: beautiful, amazing, alluring, etc. They're all right! An architectural building that is completely stunning to look at, all the while transporting you back in time to a period of complete fantasy and dreams. 

No wonder there are so many weddings and engagements photos here. I would to. Come and visit at night! You can thank me later. =D
author: Chris S.

description:
This was on my top three places for sight-seeing when I came to SF! Daytime, nighttime, this structure is breathtaking. I would have never discovered this place if it wasn't for my co-worker! She told me to go here if the weather permits because it seriously is THAT beautiful. It has left an impression once I left. I took pictures from every angle so that I could remember how beautiful this architecture is.

Palace of Fine Arts isn't really packed with tourists like Pier 39 or Union Square because it's hidden. I would have never found out about this place if it wasn't recommended. I will definitely come back here whenever I visit again!
author: Sophia V.

description:
My friend and I barely had 48 hours in SF, but we made it a point to come visit the Palace of Fine Arts since we were staying in the Marina District. Our first visit was unfortunately during a torrential downpour of rain, but the ugly weather didn't hide the beauty of this place. It's absolutely majestic with the beautiful building overlooking the lake. 

We came back the next day when the sun was out for pictures and we ended up spending an hour wandering around the grounds with our coffees. There's a lot of pretty benches to enjoy a tranquil moment if you're alone. Even with the tons of tourists trying to snap the perfect selfie, the ambiance remained calm and peaceful. It was definitely worth going into the actual dome and getting a closer look at the architecture.

Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area!
author: Megan K.

description:
Really pretty place at sunset. There was a group of bicycles and roller skaters passing by and making donut rounds under the dome. Some bicycles had glowing led lights which looks awesome at night. There were some naked bicycles too tho.  

The two angry swans which normally inhabit the pond and fountain were no where to be found tonight. 

We came here for raise the macallen tasting night which was a nice venue to host the event. But making us wait in line outside for 30 mins was not cool as there were mosquitos around. 

Still a very iconic sf tourist location even after they moved the exploratorium down to the pier. It's a nice stroll around the pond at night.
author: Vicky L.

description: Awesome place to wonder around and take pics.  I recommend going early in the day as street parking is a problem.  It was a perfect, short stop (under an hour) before we took the kids to Crissy Field/Torpedo Wharf to view the Golden Gate Bridge.  If you have plans to visit the area, you should try to stop at the Palace, as well.  To my surprise, the kids did not complain and enjoyed walking around the grounds and watching the ducks in the pond.
author: Michael M.

description:
My absolute favorite place in San Fran. So beautiful (I used to dream of being proposed to here). Sooo glad they didn't tear it down after the end of 1915 Panama Pacific International Exposition, for which the Palace was built. The movie "The Rock" introduced me to the Palace. :o) The architecture is elegant, stunning and the colors unique. I still wonder why sculpted ladies bordering the rotunda face inward. It's relaxing to take a stroll and watch the pond ripple and carefree swans.

You can get married under the rotunda. On one visit an artist stacked rocks in gravity-defying ways along one path. You can see part of the Palace driving by but make a stop to check it out. You will not regret it.
author: Mia K.

description:
Beautiful, picturesque and breath taking. I've always loved the Palace of Fine Arts. Especially around twilight. All lit up with the gorgeous colors of the sky.

View from Baker Street: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/palace-of-fine-arts-san-francisco#1eMujAFe0LeXSsva5IGz0Q

If there's a spot worth going to for a photo op, Palace of Fine Arts is definitely one of them.
author: Elena N.

description: This place is a must see if your in town it beautiful  to enjoy the calm serenity this place has to offer
author: Maria G.

description:
Lovely place to walk around outside! I like to take my friends here because it's so picturesque and wonderful. We've never actually been inside though. It was funny since I was with a bunch of other NorCal locals when we realized that none of us really know what's inside the Palace of Fine Art ... except for fine art I guess? 

But this review is for the outside walk--it's lovely. The architecture is gorgeous, the pond is cute, lots of ducks and birds flying around. It's not a particularly large park though--probably only entertained us for about 15-20 min and that's including us spending some time taking pictures. 

tldr; great sight seeing place... but there's not actually anything you can DO while you're there except for take artsy photos
author: Jasmine X.

description: Great place to visit. Many different exhibits which offers a great chance to see something different. Great views for photos. Many people take wedding photos here. It's a beautiful place
author: Andrew M.

description:
There really isn't a lot to say except this place is beautiful!

Parking may be difficult to find here especially during the day. You can find parking along the streets or inside the small parking lot.

Great place to take some photos. When my friends and I came here for a photo shoot, there were people taking photos here for their wedding.

This is a definite place to stop by and take photos!
author: Aj C.

description:
One of the most beautiful landmarks I've seen in my entire life! If you've never been to Palace of the Fine Arts then you should go here!

The day was perfect when we came here last weekend - not too hot and not too cold either, it had that good, cool breeze going on. 

There were a couple of people getting their photo shoot done - Engagement, Wedding, Couple, Modeling, you name it! I like how you can sit on the lawn and have some mini picnic and just enjoy the scenery and watch the ducks move along the lake and be adorable. You can sit on the benches and even read your book in peace. I find this place to be a good spot for a casual date if you want to be different from the typical movie and dinner type of thing.

Parking can be a nightmare since there's no garage or whatsoever so you just have to be smart around the street parkings around the neighborhood. You must be at a level 100 super expert parallel parking type of skill because that's what mostly you're going to do :P

Bring a jacket if you're one of those people who get cold easily.
author: Aarize D.

description: Such a beautiful establishment, landmark near Golden Gate Bridge, but less crowded and many spots for photo shooting.
author: Maruko X.

description: I am absolutely in love with this place, I went for the first time and took so many amazing pictures. Im planning a photo shoot there now! Please go it's so much bigger than it looks and there's so much to see, from the pretty swan, to the hundreds of turtles and beautiful birds, not to mentions the actual beautiful buildings!! This review and my pictures don't do it justice, go see it for yourself, there's convenient free street parking.
author: hanin s.

description: really pretty spot to hang around, its a unique park and the building itself feels very roman. Not that exciting to come multiple times, at least for me, but definitely cool to see once! If you're visiting SF, this should be on your list of places to go. I've seen impromptu weddings take place as well, which is really cool
author: Tom R.

description:
Very nice place to walk around and bring your tourist family and friends. Really nice structure. It gets crowded though and kinda difficult to find parking (but def worth it). Great for taking pictures. You would actually see a lot of couples taking their prenup photos here. 

Best time to come here is actually at night because it gives that very romantic vibe. 

Anyways, if you are visiting, this is definitely a must see! =)
author: Isabella D.

description: Beautiful and picture perfect! A nice place to take a walk with your significant other, and also great for the family!
author: Yaree L.

description: My gosh, this place is beautiful! Must see! Went on a 3 day vacay here and am so glad I included this! It's a must do, absolutely beautiful and you really appreciate the space and architecture.
author: Justine S.

description:
Beautiful landmark that you have to see if you are ever in San Francisco. It is on the way to the Golden Gate Bridge and you will need no more than half an hour to enjoy to place.

Parking isn't that hard to find since the place offers lots of street parking and there is also neighborhood parking around the area. 

Do a stroll around the entire pond and dome, there are lots of cool photo opportunities around this place. If you feel adventurous, you can climb the big brick steps behind the dome and take pictures. Both times that I've been here, I see couples doing photo shoot here. There are lots of benches where you can just sit and people watch.

Be careful of the swans and wild life around here. They do bite so just look and don't touch!
author: Minh-An C.

description: Who knew there was a nice Palace located in this giant city. Walking around and through this monument really musters up appreciation for the arts. Everywhere you look you will find intricate details that inspire the imagination. It was cool that there was a pond with ducks and swans, which people www feeding bread crumbs. Be careful, because one eager swan was biting at the legs of a guy feeding the birds. Another cool thing that I noticed was that there were multiple couples doing wedding photo shoots. Since this is a free attraction it makes for a perfect destination for this sort of thing. If you plan t go here it is the perfect end destination on a walk through the city.
author: Vats A.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is like an old world charm! This majestic roman statuettes with its pillars makes one feel, somewhat-authentically Greek without having to fly out of San Francisco.

Seeing the ducks, seagulls and a few white swans gave me a bit of a chuckle. How wonderful it must be, to see such great animals doing about what they do best, while totally oblivious and trusting of human footsteps only centimeters from their distance.

I have been inside the Theater and watched a few shows here and there, but nothing so spectacular as the outside, especially when it is all lit up at night in its full glory!  During my visit, it was nice to see young lovers alike, capturing their Kodak moment, and some, came fully spiff up with their white satin gowns, top hat and all!

To take in the beauty of this place, I recommend starting across the water, working yourself from the outside in.  You will capture a wider lens and great compositions!

Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description: Beautiful building and peaceful environment. Walk around the lake and enjoy watching birds on the lake and smell of fresh air ( in the Spring)
author: Ava R.

description:
Gorgeous architecture combined with the natural beauty of the city in a park like setting.

Seems very popular with the wedding crowd as there was some photo session in progress.  Ducks galore.  Big climbing tree great for the kiddo.  Gorgeous homes bordering the perimeter.

Great for a stroll.
author: Lan C.

description:
This has always been, hands down, my favorite spot in the city.  If I am in the city I will make a point to come here just because.  The Palace is amazing during the day time and equally breath taking at night.  I am hard pressed to decide which time I enjoy coming to more.

Bring a picnic and just hang out on the lawn and take in the sights and people.  Bring a camera.  I have a million pics of this place and I still take more each time I come.

Do yourself a favor, though, look up the history of the Panama-Pacific International Exposition.  This will really put the Palace Of Fine Arts into perspective and give you a grander appreciation for the site, the Marina and San Francisco.   There is a free exhibition in the Innovation Hangar that is a must see.  http://www.ppie100.org/
author: Cap P.

description: Another San Francisco landmark that helps define the beauty of what this city truly has to offer. From afar and especially at night, the Palace of Fine Arts is breathtaking. It has that old-world, European feel to it. If you are not from the area and suddenly stumble upon it, you'll be immediately be taken back by it's beauty. Depending on where you are coming from, it's a nice prelude to another San Francisco landmark - The Golden Gate Bridge. You'll definitely see a lot of photographs being taken, professional & amateur, since it's so picturesque. The giant columns are stunning in photos, believe me. I honestly don't remember the last time I came here, but it was probably back when I was still in college or working/living in SF. It's been so long that I didn't realize that the Exploratorium relocated from here. Yup, it's been that long. During this last visit, the "Hunger Games" temporary exhibit was up where the Exploratorium used to be. I remember jogging around here and appreciated the beauty because I always felt like I wasn't in San Francisco. It was so awesome to be able to take my then 6-year-old daughter here and for her to be able to experience such a lovely part of the city that brought me calmness and serenity.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
My desire to travel to Euro is very low. If Euro could be dropped at my feet, that would be ideal. Insert this tremendously beautiful piece of work and I am happy as a clam. Took a coworker from Toronto to see this and he was absolutely blown away. In fact, he mentioned that maybe, just maybe, Bay Area peeps are kinda sorta spoiled. I tend to agree, but typically after it's brought to my attention. Not like, when I can walk the GG Bridge on an absolutely gorgeous Sundee (that's white people chatter for what most of us call SunDAY) or stroll the grounds at Palace of Fine Arts and watch all the tourists from across the globe taking photos like TMZ stalking the Beebs. 

I'm a huge fan and truly happy that the renovations that took place not long ago have created such an incredible attraction for locals and tourists alike.
author: Hector G.

description: Beautiful place to sit and enjoy the beauty. Also really good place to take professional photos for a wedding or a graduation. I love this place because there is always parking and its nice to walk around. I wish people wouldnt set up their stands trying to hand out flyers, because it really takes away the beauty of it but hey, you cant win them all.
author: Lizzie D.

description: Even though people seem to love this place, it seems like a low quality copy of Southern European architecture. Some decades ago people would bash this "Palace" for its lack of true American identity, but everything is considered good taste now -- even kitsch pseudo-Italian imitation. The Ferry Building is much better and less foolish for many reasons. Many people might feel like they're in touch with the very heart of ancient Western architecture when visiting the Palace of the Fine Arts, though. Well, it's OK but don't be fooled by those numerous sculpted angels and ladies: the real deal is elsewhere, in another continent.
author: Rogério M.

description:
If you're visiting the Golden State Bridge you have to swing by here. It's like less than 10 minutes away and it has free parking. But be careful where you leave your car, a homeowner told us that some people take advantage of the tourists and break into the cars.

Absolutely stunning, a must do when in SF. You can have a picnic, take pictures, take a date and just take in the view.
author: Matt T.

description: I had seen people post pictures of this place on social media so I decided to finally come here to check it out. This place was very easy to find because of the large architecture so you would not miss it. Wow, the view was pretty awesome and gorgeous of the way it was built. This place was truly great for taking pictures and we noticed a couple taking engagement photos. I figured this would be a popular place for wedding photos. You can also relax near the lake on the grass too and enjoy watching the ducks. This is a great once in a lifetime visit.
author: Michael N.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is half park and half theatre making it a cool tourist attraction for the beauty and architecture as well as a destination (or rental) theater/location for events, weddings, or performances. Either way, it's a stunning scene.

Located in the Marina District (not too far from the Golden Gate Bridge), the Palace of Fine Arts was originally constructed for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition. It's been renovated and upgraded a few times (including a complete re-build in the 1960s), but the structures, paths, and lagoon harken back to a different era and lifestyle recalling influences from both classic Roman and Greek architecture.

As a touristy photo spot, the Palace of Fine Arts ranks up there among the great attractions in San Francisco. The grand Rotunda is the central lure. The surrounding garden and nearby lagoon lined with Eucalyptus trees make for an elegant landscape for photography and videos. Plenty of swans, ducks, geese, turtles, and other wildlife add to the mystique of the Palace of Fine Arts.
author: Michael S.

description:
I know this place has been reviewed over a bazillion times but this is for the benefit of my friends and those that read my reviews.  

I didn't know that we could review parks until the other day the local CM told me we could so yes this is the first park I could think of that I visited recently and just had to write about.

The Palace of Fine Arts in San Francisco, California is one of the nicest places in the city to see and that is saying a lot because San Fran IMO is the most beautiful city in the USA.

It is located in the Marina district not far from the Presidio and Golden Gate bridge.  When we finally decided to visit this place I was lucky enough to find parking on Bay Street in front of a residence.  The signs said 2 hour max which was plenty of time to walk around the park for some nice photo opportunities.  

This park and the structures and ponds that make up the area are just beautiful to walk around and see.  There are plenty of waterfowl in the pond including white swans.

Parks like this one is what contributes to making San Francisco a very aesthetically pleasing city.
author: Lambert P.

description:
Coming here is like going through San Francisco's history.

The Palace of Fine Arts. The only surviving monument of the 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition of San Francisco. A monument that celebrates the creation of the Panama Canal, but also to recognize and reform from the disaterous earthquake of 1906. This place is one of the most biggest spots for anyone to come to, tourist or not.

Located in the Marina district, this place is great for a lot of things. Romantic walks, family walks, tourist walks, photoshoots, etc. Definitelt bring a camera, because a picture of this place is worth a thousand words. When you walk through the large European-esque archs, you'll find yourself standing in the middle of the dome. There is also a very tranquil pond that you can wall along as well.

When I was growing up, the Exploratorium used to be right next to this place, but it has now moved over to the pier by the Embarcadero.

This place is gorrgeeeoouusss at night. Bring a jacket though. It gets super cold.
author: Jerianne G.

description:
Most people come for the exterior architectural beauty of Berkeley's Bernard Maybeck. But inside lies a gorgeous theater with concert and dance performances. I remember playing for the Cal band in a joint concert with Stanford when I was an undergrad.

The outside needs no introduction. Many cute swans swim around the pond. It is almost impossible to come in the weekend without seeing wedding photos shot here. It does get very chili during sunset and evenings so bring a jacket! 

If only they can have a crane to do a little scrubbing and cleaning of the right side of the rotunda it would be perfect. Do come in the evening to check out the lit rotunda.
author: Stan L.

description:
Beautiful architecture! SF must see tourist spot! Great photography location. Lots of couples have their engagement or wedding shoots photos here. It's very spacious.

It's quite easy to find street parking when there's not an event. The only two times I've been here, quite coincidentally were during Miss Asian American Pageant. They have an auditorium for special events. Last year, my bff was a contestant and it was soooo hard to find parking. And I came back yesterday to show a few friends this place and it was the 2014 Miss AAP. Who knew!

There are lights at night, but I think it's definitely a LOT prettier during the day with natural lighting. It's also a place where you can either decide to stay for 5 minutes or hours.
author: Winnie T.

description: Amazed with the history and architectural of the place. My kids were wowed from the moment we started walking closer to it. Great place for pictures and even if u wanna just relax and read a book there's benches all over the place and also the small park with ducks swans turtles and fishes
author: Miguel N.

description:
This was a beautiful place to visit! I'm so glad we made the trek down from Presidio Social Club. It's like being transported to Europe for a hot second. The sheer size is worth the ooh-ing and ahh-ing. The greenery and pond views were an added bonus. Perhaps it was the never-ending winter I was facing back home in NY, but I was soaking in the lush beauty. And then the swans just added to the luxury of the space. 

Although, I wish they had more placards explaining the history of the architecture. We were wandering around wondering why such a huge space was built here.

Spend some time craning your neck with your jaw dropped to capture the detail in the column design and intricate carvings.
author: Breanna B.

description: My favorite landmark in SF, breathtaking and stunning. If you are touring SF, add the Palace to your list!
author: Ross S.

description:
I always had an obsession with the Palace of Fine Arts - I would always drive by it and see it on the freeway and always had a desire to go see it.

I went to see the outside building and I was very amused and keen on the experience. There are a ton of angels and creatures carved throughout the entire structure, it's really a magnificent place to be.  

Parking is effortless, it's just on the side curb, and already you get an amazing view from every conceivable angle.
author: Marina S.

description:
When people think of San Francisco, the last place that comes to their mind is the Palace of Fine Arts, and that's a damn shame. Built for the 1915 World's Fair, this gem is a perfect photo op for professional and amateur photographer's alike. Yes, you can totally use that hashtag #nofilterneeded for that Instagram post because it's THAT beautiful here. Do be aware of rude people stepping all up in your picture as you're attempting to get that one good shot. Be understanding that they're probably in awe of this beautiful architectural structure. 

There is a parking lot in the front, but it's small, so you're better off finding street parking in front of those multi million dollar homes. 

And one last note, if you absolutely need to use the restroom while enjoying the sights here, good luck! Take your business over to Crissy Field, which is a short walk away, but when you gotta go, it seems like FOR-EVER!
author: Jackie T.

description:
Parking was bloody aweful here, but the view makes up for it. Prepare to get a lot of exercise here.

The combination of the architectural arch, the plants, and the water makes this such a beautiful place to have a photo op. I also saw a lot of people taking wedding pictures here.   This place is a pretty chill place. I saw a lot of people sitting under trees just passing by time and appreciating what this place can offer.        

Would definitely come to visit again! :)
author: John T.

description: Wow i drove by this place on a fluke going down filmore and i just had to explore the huge dome. It caught my eyes immediately. The houses are so beautiful around the area they all have huge windows and the architecture are brilliant. The palace of fine arts is the last remaining structure of the olden days. The place use to stretch all the way to fort mason until it got torn down. They have a museum that tells you about the history of everything and its non profit! They even have phone charging station.. just brilliant
author: Pu B.

description: This place is so BEAUTIFUL, especially at night time. My girlfriend brought me here on one of our dates and the view is absolutely stunning. It's well lit at night time and walking around the outside area is so romantic.
author: Jasmine V.

description:
Such a gorgeous place, not only for tourists, but also for locals.  Yes, parking is a pain in the is area since there are a lot of tourists around Golden Gate park, but the Palace of Fine arts is tucked away from all of the Golden Gate visitors.  

Very relaxing place to sit and unwind, or take a stroll.
author: Sophie L.

description: A lovely place that I had wanted to visit but the lighting on a mid afternoon happened to be subpar
author: Loose Seal A.

description: It is very beautiful here. There is a lake that wraps around the Palace and lawns so people can picnic and enjoy the view. Surrounding the whole area are individual colorful houses I would love to own, but probably cost a bajillion bucks. It is a cute spot for pictures and day date.
author: Vivian X.

description:
I've wanted to go here after seeing the beautiful pictures that others have posted. Luckily, we were able to get a spot in the parking lot. The place is serene and picturesque. I spotted at least two couples taking wedding pictures. This would be a great place to take a date and have a picnic. 

FYI- Palace of Fine Arts is on the National Register of Historic Places.
author: Helen H.

description:
I don't understand why anybody complains about this place. Why doesn't this place have a perfect 5 star rating? Let me just enlighten you with a list of reasons for why this place is so amazing:

1) It's BEAUTIFUL. The architecture is absolutely breath taking. They are very large and very very photogenic. The sight of the buildings makes you really marvel at how awesome human beings are to be capable of crafting a place like this.
2) It's FREE. You aren't paying some 20 dollars for some BS tickets. This is a FREE sight seeing area
3) There is a grassy lawn area right outside the palace... PERFECT for a picnic! There's even a small pond if you like water. There are some trees too if you want shade.
4) It's very close to the Golden Gate Bridge. If you get tired of the place, you can always go to Golden Gate. It's only a 20 min walk, which is the perfect amount of time for some exercise.
5) There are some "extra" buildings on the side... we were in a hanger titled "Innovation Hanger". It's not the coolest thing around, but there are some interesting looking sites in there. Again, you don't have to go in if you don't want to, but they do have A/C!
6) It's easily accessible. Take an Uber and you are here! It's located real close to Presidio park!
7)  It's FREE! Did I mention that already?
8) It's BEAUTIFUL.

Just come.
author: Jim S.

description:
This is a definitely must-go tourist spot in San Francisco. This was one of the 8 palaces of the 1915 World Exposition (aka Panama-Pacific International Exposition), and the only one that still remains in its original place.

It is absolutely marvelous! The more you walk around it, the prettier it gets. The construction is really amazing and beautiful, and the mixture with the ponds and trees is just right. 

This is a place for you to contemplate beauty, history, and to take exceptional photos.
author: Andréia S.

description: Beautiful palace great place to picnic and relax or take plenty of pictures. Went here on my trip to san francisco.
author: Tony N.

description: Beautiful place to relax, take pictures, take the dogs, etc etc. Love the beautiful architecture!
author: Matt S.

description: This is a good place to take pictures! I think I counted 4 quinceneras and 1 wedding. I would say come early, because this place can get pretty packed. Visually, this place made me feel like I'm in a different country. I can't believe I've never been here previously. Gotta see, must see!!!
author: Willem V.

description:
A gorgeous sightseeing location! Be prepared to be awed by the grand architecture and decorated carvings. I came here during the day and it was just beautiful, and I'm sure that it is just as amazing at night with the lights and all.

Free parking is just behind the building.
author: Eva L.

description:
WEDDING PICTURE HEAVEN! 

FREE PARKING on the street. FREE ADMISSION. It's already off to a good start.

This is a great place for a picnic, first date, family stroll, or just a nice place to read a book. We spent maybe 30 minutes here touring the grounds and gawking at the beautiful architecture and scenery. Since I wasn't quite sure exactly what this was supposed to be, we only walked around the outside and never saw the theater inside.

Apparently this was constructed after the huge 1906 earthquake for a worlds-fair type of exhibition. Now it's a great place to jog around or wander the grounds but watch out for those extra large geese. The signs say to stay at least 20 feet away from them. My daughter got a little bit too close and they started attacking her.
author: Lori I.

description:
Such a beautiful location! My friend and I went to San Francisco for lunch and saw how beautiful it was so we decided to check it out. 

We walked around for awhile and we were amazed at how detailed and the great condition it was. So many people were taking pictures because it was gorgeous. It's also pretty calming to walk around and admire the beauty. 

I want to do some research on this and then come back to fully understand the greatness.
author: Kalani M.

description: Beautiful place. However, 3 car break ins when we were there, including ours! As the police took our statements, they had two more reports with cars parked around this place. So it's a team effort they said and happens a lot. The police tried to get them to install cameras. I would recommend seeing this place from Google Maps.
author: Chun A.

description: Nice place to swing by if you are at Crissy fields, especially if the weather is good. Worth a visit!
author: Sreekanth V.

description:
Saw Potted Potter here yesterday (side note, super fun show!). We were in Row O, seats 58 & 50 (I added a pic from our seats). Small, intimate theater setting, easy to see/hear from basically anywhere. We had planned to wander the beautiful grounds after the show, but sadly, the weather didnt cooperate (although I won't complain about rain) so we'll be back to check the rest out some other time. 

We lucked out with super close parking, and everyone inside (well, the 3 staff we actually saw) was friendly.
author: Dani A.

description:
Walked about 4 and a half miles from the Good Hotel, to Fisherman's Wharf, to Ghirardelli Square, and then found this place a few miles away thru yelp. It was totally worth it! Photo opportunities are a must and there's never a bad side of the Palace. And being a former college of fine arts student, it was an obligatory site to visit!

My friends and I walked the parameters of the pond and enjoyed the natural vibe from the ducks, birds, trees, green ass grass, plants/flowers, and the sun! It was such a beautiful stroll at every viewpoint and the palace itself was a bonus for the experiment. I don't know what, but it just felt so vibrant to be there.

There's great historical background on this valuable archetype, and it's too bad I didn't get the chance to go into the theater and experience it all. From what I understand, in the early 1900's the civic leaders of San Francisco envisioned a bold plan to bring the world together to encourage trade and to show the future of the world as it could be, and to demonstrate that a rebuilt San Francisco would be truly an international city.

It makes me feel some type of way when history itself is formed in the definition of the structure and is still standing strong. I appreciate a lot about this place, thus leads to my conclusion of recommending you to visit and see for yourself as well! Even if you don't have the time or money to see a film in the theater, you can choose to relax outside on the grass or take pics all around!
author: Sharz T.

description: Palace of fine arts has to be one of the most beautiful architectures I've seen to date. It's a piece of art.
author: Tuyen H.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts was originally constructed for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition and is one of the few structures left and the only one still situated at its original site. It was rebuilt in 1965 and the lagoon and walkways were renovated in 2009. It hosts art exhibits as well as various other events which are listed on their website. This place is such an icon that there's even a mini replica of it at Disney's California Adventures!

JQ and I just stopped by because I wanted to see the beautiful architecture. One great thing about this place is that they have free parking. We walked around admiring the columns, the lagoon, the rotunda... the entire area is very beautiful and picturesque. No wonder a lot of couples have their wedding pictures taken here! This is a nice place to just hang out and relax for a bit, or wander around taking pictures. Definitely recommend stopping by if you're in the area :)
author: Esther K.

description: Beautiful place but BEWARE of thieves.somebody broke into our SUV and stole a lot of stuffs like ipad,camera,etc which where inside the backpacks...no security at all not even a surveillance camera on site.really unsafe for tourists...lesson learned "don't leave any unattended valuables"..just be careful guys!
author: Liezl M.

description:
I have been coming to the Palace of Fine Arts since my parents and grandmother took me here to feed the ducks in the lagoon many years ago.  This whole area is a lot less crowded ever since the Exploratorium moved to Pier 15.  Now there are a sufficient number of parking spaces on a weekend afternoon, which is a nice change.

If you don't want to drive and look for a place to park, take the MUNI.  Ride the 30 Stockton from downtown to the end of the line, which will be after a right turn onto Broderick.  That leaves you a couple of blocks away from the Palace.  You can easily walk the rest of the way, it's flat here.

The Palace of Fine Arts is one of the few remaining structures from the Panama Pacific International Exposition of 1915.  But I guess that statement is technically not quite true.  The original Palace of Fine arts was built of plaster, and was not meant to last.  It was rebuilt in concrete in 1965 and underwent a seismic retrofit in 2009.

This is an extremely popular spot for weddings and engagement pictures.  Tourists also flock here by the busload.  It's a nice place to visit on a sunny day.  Just keep the kids away from the water's edge, I sincerely doubt that water is safe to swim in.

The Palace itself is illuminated at night, and that is quite a sight to see!
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description:
When I have children one day, I might never let them watch Disney movies. I'm sick of stories showcasing a knight in shining armor that sweeps a princess off their feet. No more tales of a sleeping beauty being awaken by a passionate kiss from a handsome prince. All these unreal love stories lead to magical weddings that little kids want one day in their future.

Take for example, a wedding at the Palace of Fine Arts. Off Lyon St and Marina Green Blvd, you can host a ceremony that holds up to 250 guests for a reservation fee of $409 and an hourly rate of $117 (2 hour minimum). You get an idea like that stuck in your bride's mind and you're gonna sleep next to Bridezilla for months up to the wedding. But, that's just how awesome the venue is at the Palace of Fine Arts.

This monumental structure was originally built for the 1915 Panama Pacific Exposition that exhibited fine works of art. It's one of a few surviving structures from that world's fair and is the only one still situated at its original site. It was rebuilt and renovated in 1965 for your viewing pleasure, complete with a lagoon and walking areas. It's almost like a perfect wet dream for tourists and locals alike.

It's quite a sight, I give you that. The architecture is not something you see at your local park. Great place to snapshot that attention you crave on Instagram or to go for that long walk that your daily horoscope reminds you to do. Inside, they showcase art exhibits as well, along with theatre events. Given its name, they make sure it fits the meaning. (www.palaceoffinearts.org)

Hey, if you're into these kind of things, make it happen. As for me, I'd gladly attend a show here than be a part of a grand wedding to join two people in holy matrimony. "In sickness and in health, in poverty or in wealth, til death do us part." Just remember, marriage is eternal, unless you can find a great lawyer.
author: Chris C.

description:
What's not to love?!? I have been coming here since I was a little kid. Need to take out of town relatives to a staple Bay Area scene? This is it. Need to relax and enjoy some beautiful scenery? This is it. Need a place for some great photo ops? This is it! 

Strolling around the park makes me feel like I'm in another world. Truly one of my most favorite places in the world. Must see
When you come to SF! The architecture, the lake and the breathtaking  SF landmarks, you won't be disappointed! And it's free! No admission necessary. Only need to find parking.
author: leanne s.

description: If their management knows that this has been happening 20 times a week, they should at least make sure that there's a roving security guard. People are willing to pay for parking if it means being safe.
author: Danna F.
