description: Absolutely beautiful! One of the many gorgeous spots in San Fran! You can take a romantic stroll, take pics or simply enjoy a picnic. There isn't an admission fee and open all day, so enjoy the flexibility of your visit!
author: Noor S.

description: It's so beautiful here! Breath taking! First time I was here, I just wanted to sit and admire the scenery. Second time I was here, I was a photogenic lol!!! A go to place for picnics, special occasion photos, and relaxations!
author: Derek N.

description: Definitely a place to visit when visiting San Francisco! It's about a 5-10 minute drive from the Golden Gate Bridge. The Palace of Fine Arts is beauty at it's finest. You will never see anything like this anywhere on the west coast. Architecture like this is only found in Europe. Everything here is picture perfect, so make sure to bring your camera and explore! A perfect place for a walk. The Palace of Fine Arts consists of the huge main dome and arches, along with the huge fountain in front of it where geese and ducks can be seen swimming. An amazing landmark of San Francisco, so make sure to come here! Also, there is plenty of parking just by the Theater behind the dome, or you can park in the nearby neighborhoods.
author: Michael Q.

description:
So beautiful!! I've seen pictures from friends going here but pictures can not capture the beauty of this place. It's just so massive and stunning. 

There are benches around the lake area to just sit and relax to enjoy the sunset or watch the ducks. Two swans swam by as I was there and it made it seem so romantic and majestic! 

We were reading some of the signs posted and this monument was almost knocked down! I'm glad they were able to preserve it. I highly recommend coming here and viewing it if you're visiting. The architecture and just beauty of this place is something worth seeing.
author: Kristin T.

description: Had our white coat ceremony here.  It's gorgeous for pictures taking.  A lot of people come here for photo shoots.  Beautiful waterfall and building.
author: Rou M.

description: What a funny looking place! But fun to walk around. Plenty of bird life and turtles were in and around the water. No fences around the water so you need to hang onto the littlies. Take time to read the historical boards to explain why this place exists
author: Sue L.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is colossal and awesome.  Located in the Marina District of San Francisco, the palace is a giant Classical Greek and Roman-influenced outdoor structure.  It's massive and monumental, complete with a pond, swans, ducks, a walking trail, and a park with benches.  The property isn't huge and you can probably explore all of it in 20 minutes or so, taking your time.  Unless you're planning a picnic, photoshoot, or romantic stroll, this will probably be a short stop.

If you can only go once, it's best to go during the daytime.  Not only is the structure more visually awe-inspiring during the day, but the pond serves as a reflective pool, which makes for terrific photos.   The palace is illuminated at night, so it's still worth checking out during the evening hours as well.  It's just as beautiful at nighttime and the lighting creates a really cool effect.  Check out my photos to see the colonnade, dome, rotunda, etc. and to get an idea for how massive the structure is.

Bring food to feed to the swans, ducks, pigeons, and other birds in the area if you like feeding animals.  Free parking is available along surrounding neighborhood side streets.  Many of the hop-on hop-off tour buses also make a stop here.

Access to the Palace of Fine Arts is free.  However, access to the Exploratorium science and art exhibit is not.
author: Daniel B.

description: This place and its architecture is beautiful. It's so peaceful and serene and it's a great place to take a stroll and take pictures at. A must-visit every time I'm in the bay.
author: Shareen D.

description:
I would really like to give 5 stars, but we didn't have a chance to go inside the building because they were closed to the public, so I am not sure how great staff is or clean the building is, but the structure is amazing, huge, and beautiful. It really is breathtaking!

We also saw this building from afar at night from many places, and we went on an open house tour of a house that had a nice view of the Palace. We enjoyed walking around and seeing the pond and the birds!
author: Tina S.

description:
JAW. DROPPING.

You know that feeling when you walk into Disneyland and your heart is fluttering and you just want to spend the rest of your life there? This place.

I actually turned to my boyfriend and said THIS IS BETTER THAN DISNEYLAND. Pictures aren't even CLOSE to capturing how grand this place is. It's a beautiful, beautiful location and I can't help but get excited just thinking about it. You have the lake, the grass, a fountain, and this ginormous palace. There are ducks and swans and we even saw a crane! It was crazy, and just seemed so...magical. It really couldn't get any better. 

I think what was even cuter (being the girl that I am) were all of the engagement shoots going on here. Being in such a beautiful place with people who seem so in love just added to the experience and honestly, everything was just so amazing.
author: Karen L.

description: This place was a wonderful surprise! It was especially beautiful at sunset when their lights came on! It was a bit away from the main areas but it was totally worth it! And there were beautiful white and a few black swans there swimming about too!
author: Caleb S.

description:
Must go place if you are visiting SF. Huge sculpture and carvings amazing open peaceful place

Breathtaking view surrounding a small lake
Great for taking pictures 
I was accompanied by lots of students taking pictures for their prom day pre graduation pictures 
Beware of the winds it's San Francisco and it's open place so better carry a jacket
author: Miraj S.

description:
DAMNIT SAN FRANCISCO!  Why are you making me fall in love with you?!  I may NEVER LEAVE! haha!  This is officially my favorite spot in the city.

I was so excited to visit.  I remember seeing it in a movie and it was just so beautiful.  It was much bigger than I expected.  The entire area was huge!  People are seriously tiny when walking around this area.  The lake is so beautiful.  I loved spotting turtles and the swans.  Absolutely breathtaking.  It's a nice place to just clear your mind and enjoy life's blessings.  :)
author: Chrissie O.

description:
We  visited the Early Monet exhibit. Closes at the end of the  month. I thought it might be less enchanting than exhibits of his later work but this is not true. He was a boy genius so the evolution of his early pieces and the story of his difficult young years is fascinating. One very much older adult found a museum aide and asked if there were water lilies anywhere (the exhibit ends before he created the iconic garden bridges and flora). Yes, they have Monet water lilies elsewhere. In conclusion, Monet's contributions were wonderful and the exhibit was very well curated.

We concluded with lunch in the museum. Every item on the menu was quite pricey but both our lunches were excellent so, oh well. I can not wrap my mind around some of the modern touches in the Palace such as a comic book style piece in place of "The Money Lenders." But I have never learned to appreciate the sensibility of any art after mid-Picasso (forget where Chagall falls in this chronology--love him). I also didn't much enjoy the crude representations of human existence (they look like mud but are actually bronze) in the courtyard that used to be dedicated to Rodin. So, I am not sophisticated enough for 2017 and should stick to the tried and true. Or I'll have an epiphany someday at the MOMA.
author: Diana M.

description: Absolutely beautiful and free to check out! Smaller park but beautiful structures fountain and pond with swans turtles fish and ducks. Stunning!
author: Christine V.

description: It is so pretty here! Great place to just sit there and ready a book.
author: Lily N.

description: It's a little isolated to get there if you don't have a car.  It seems a little dated. But I like it! I went there recently for the Ethnic Dance Festival (go!!) and the Naked Magic Show (you should've gone if you missed it!). Lots of parking. Take Lyft/Uber out there and there are a couple bus lines that go out thataway if you don't have a car.
author: Maile N.

description: It's hard not to love the grandeur, architecture and beauty of this place.  Great place for photos when you're in the Marina district.  Dates, weddings, photo ops, and general SF sightseeing--it's all happening here.
author: Clyde V.

description: Loved it. It was a nice walk, the area is beautiful and you have great opportunities for fantastic photos. Go check it out.
author: Deano G.

description: Amazing place to visited highly recommend to come to see amazing structure. My husband is making a n special day for me with your from San Francisco with limo a1affordablelimo again make us amazing tour I have the best husband ever.
author: Tamara L.

description:
Talk about a San Francisco landmark...

TIP: come here at dusk to dark during a weekday - easy parking, quiet and AMAZING for photos!

The Palace of Fine Arts is a pretty easy FIVE in my book...stars.
author: Patrick L.

description:
There has not been anything I've ever seen that is as beautiful as The Palace of Fine Arts. I'm in San Fran on vacation as a birthday present from my best friend. And her uncle told us to come here because it's his favorite place in San Francisco (he has lived here for years and years).

It's so crazy that when you tell people you're going to SF, they tell you about the Golden Gate Bridge, and Alcatraz, and the piers, but don't mention this gorgeous hunk of history. I was amazed walking around it and taking in the architecture and the beauty of it all. 

The pond is gorgeous too, and the ducks will swim around with you in hopes for some bread. It was so fun. 

I will say, there was a monk walking and he greeted us and gave us some little trinkets, and in return he made gestures and pointed to his clipboard where it said "donations $20 or $40". It was a little bizarre, but it was a cool experience.

I could sit out there all day and just stare. I was completely and utterly blown away. My favorite part is San Francisco by far.
author: Hailey B.

description:
Living so close to San Francisco, it is easy to forget that it's a city people from all over the world want to visit. This is one stop that visitors and locals should spend time walking around
.  
The building was constructed for the PPIE and was designed as a temporary structure.  It is one of best known examples of the famed architect Bernard Maybeck's work. His designs are prized in the San Francisco Bay Area, where the majority of his masterworks can be found.  

It is lovely anytime of the year during the day or in the evening, I guess if I could only visit one time I would go in the spring when the cherry blossoms are in bloom.

If you would like to see historical images of the Pan Pacific International Expo and the Palace of Arts, you can see them at http://www.postcard.org/
author: Terry T.

description:
Over the years, I have been to Palace of Fine Arts several times, and I never tire of experience. It's wonderful every time!  The structures, grounds, and gardens are serenely beautiful and they always leave me with a feeling of peace.

I also have been here for several weddings, and, if I ever marry, I definitely will consider this location because it seemed perfect for my friends.

If you get a chance to visit, just GO here!
author: Monika H.

description:
Beautiful and peaceful...

What a perfect location in a sunnier area of San Francisco. You just can't help but feel at peace as you walk through the beautifully maintained grounds. The birds chirping and the green landscape just make you go, "Ahhhh..."

If you want this experience for yourself, you're just going to have to visit...
author: Andy S.

description:
There isn't much in San Francisco that isn't stunning or beautiful.   The PFA is one of those undeniably stunning parks that  sits  just below the Golden Gate bridge on the way to Marin/ Sausalito.  The panorama is dramatic as you drive up to the PFA with the GG as backdrop. And this park/venue has great architecture on top of that.  So cool, relaxing and it feels like you're transported to another Euro city when you visit here  And, Roman and Greek architecture in 1 place?  I'm all IN.  

One day I wanna see a show here as I've read a few docs on how attendees love this place on Yelp and revs from  "the other white meat".  

Tip:  If you go to the Golden Gate bridge North to Sausalito from here beware on the way back, the are no toll booths but your car license plates are recorded  and weeks later you $10 charge for toll charges from your rental  car agency. No warning whatsoever, no signs on the booths as to where you can pay this toll (or I was blind at the moment).  Nothin'.   The city  should at least warn its visitors like most cities that charge toll.  Lame.  


Visits:  20+
author: Will S.

description: Besides the terrible traffic and parking this place is a must go to in San Francisco. It's a must see during the day and night.
author: Yvette G.

description:
Soooo BEAUTIFUL here! It's just one of the most romantic places to visit in SF! There are so many amazing photo opportunities as you walk through the place. We saw people getting married here, doing photo shoots, having picnics, relaxing and taking photos. It's perfect for friends, couples and families! The best part of Palace of Fine Arts is that it's FREE!! Parking is challenging because there are so many visitors here but it's a must see if you're in SF! I can't wait to come back here next time we visit! 

If you get cold easily, bring a jacket! It's very windy!
author: Minky C.

description: Magical af. I love this place! Perfect place to take photos and just enjoy some time outdoors. Makes me wish I lived closer to SF so I can simply come here when I wanna just have some "me" time.
author: Anna D.

description: Very nice place.  Great to walk around and take pictures during the day and night.  Parking is easy to find whenever I've been there.
author: Gabriel D.

description:
I know it is touristy but I love it here - it is free and usually quite peaceful.

Rebuilt in 1965, the Palace of Fine Arts is left over from the 1915 Panama-Pacific Expo. You will often see engagement photos or wedding photos being taken here which always makes me giddy.

I bring a book and a picnic blanket and can sit here for hours...there is usually parking along the side and you can take a short stroll through the Palace but it really isn't very big.

This is where I first learnt about geocaching as well!
author: Feren Y.

description: My favorite spot in SF.
author: Ling X.

description:
*No restrooms!* Great for a photo op but we went there for the Hunger Games Exhibit and there were no restrooms available. We couldn't even use the facilities even though we'd paid for tickets. If there is an event planned for the Innovation Hanger there are no restrooms available to patrons. 

There are some across the street in the Presidio. Be sure to plan ahead!

Other than that it was great.
author: Kelsey L.

description:
Of all the times I've visited San Francisco The Palace of Fine Arts failed to be on my radar until I saw the movie "The Five Year Engagement" starring Chris Pratt and Emily Blunt. In the movie, Chris Pratt's wedding is held at this location, and until that time I had no idea this beautiful venue existed. I'm flabbergasted that it's passed under my radar for so long. 

On the weekend we visited there were many couples dressed in wedding attire taking photo's, trying to be oblivious to the gawking crowds that passed. There were also a few couples taking engagement photos. Its safe to say that this is a spot that one would deem as romantic.

I expected that the Roman column's would be cheesy and garish in the midst of the city but I found the space to be very beautiful and serene and it contributes nicely to the San Francisco architecture scene.
author: Oulie T.

description:
As a structure there really isn't much to the Palace of Fine Arts. It's located near where the old exploritorium used to be. It is an impressive structure, and pretty when it lights up at night. 

There's a sort of old charm to it, that definitely makes it one of the must-see places in SF.

However, what most people don't know is that aside from the engagement shooting opportunities and great photo spots, you have this nice concert hall that's attached to the place. There are many concerts throughout the year and I think that's the true value of the Palace of Fine Arts. So if you do come, don't just come for the view, stay for the music as well!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Anything highly rated on yelp makes me suspicious. Is it overhyped? 

In this case, it's just lovely. In fairness, it's a beautiful week day morning, and the only people around are locals and gardeners. 

I took a short walk for views of the harbour and Golden Gate Bridge. A nice spot for a photo. 

Cons: couldn't find a loo anywhere local... And the birds have fouled up the water. Not enough to knock this spot off a five star.
author: Ruth M.

description:
My wife and I visited on a weeknight around 10:00 pm, and goodness is it ROMANTIC!  My wife said it was like I took her to Rome for the evening.

For over an hour, we strolled along the paths, around the lake, past the swans, and through the structures themselves, taking in the architecture and beauty of the entire place.  The best part was that we had everything to ourselves!  It was as if we rented it out for the evening.  Major husband points were earned.

If you have the chance, be sure to check it out.  I can only imagine how wonderful it must be during the day, but my tip is to visit at night . . . and take someone you love.
author: Michael S.

description:
I think I have been to every music venue in San Francisco.

I saw the dead, the who, the stones and many more at winterland.

Keystone corner, Avalon ball room,  the matrix......thanks dad!

To me the palace of fine arts is the greatest place to see shows. No bad seats...small intimate venue...and the acoustics are the bomb....it sounds so friggin good in here you can hear a pin drop...yep that good

The first encounter with this amazing venue was the tubes in 1977....you all remember wpod??? ( http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HxG-sIngsIA )

Every year they hold the harmony sweepstakes here...awesome! I highly recommend.

If you get a chance to see a show here....Run do not walk to get tickets!
author: David G.

description: Stunning architecture and quaint trail/park in the heart of San Francisco! The fact that it's FREE is why I gave it 5 stars. It is nearly impossible to see or do ANYthing in this amazing city for free. Parking alone can cost upwards around $40 in some spots. (Insane, I know!) Parking is free and to walk around the Palace is free. Grab a friend and enjoy the beauty that is this wonderful spot.
author: Heather D.

description:
Reason for visit: San Francisco International Hip Hop Dance Fest
Visit date: November 16, 2014
First time? To the theater, yes.

Ah, the Palace of Fine Arts. Such beautiful architecture; a prime spot for photo taking! And such a pain to drive to! But I digress...

Today I visited the Palace for a show at the theater. The theater is large enough to attract large crowds, but small enough so that you have a great seat anywhere you sit. The seats are comfy, and recline slightly. If you're a fidgety spectator, no worries; if you move, your neighbors generally can't feel it. Also, there's lots of leg room, so if you have to sneak by people in your row, there's plenty of space to get by. It can get a little humid in the theater, so just be prepared.

The lobby area is spacious, and after the show they open up the side wall (yes, pretty much a wall) for easy exit. And though I didn't use the restroom, my friend says there are lots of stalls to accommodate the crowds during intermission and after the show. There is limited parking surrounding the theater, but you can usually find something in the neighboring streets.
author: Erin G.

description:
While I haven't been inside the Palace of Fine Arts since High School, I love just chilling outside. They have this gorgeous expansive architecture that's great to observe and definitely take pictures in front of.  The day I went, I saw at least 3 wedding parties. 

There's also a lake that you can chill by and bring a book or a picnic. The only thing is does get pretty windy, even on nice days so I would bring something warm.
author: Stella Y.

description:
Beautiful place, crappy parking security! Our car was broken into. A camera and my sister's purse with cc's and her marriage license were stolen. There are no security cameras and the Park police was absolutely no help!  She just strolled ever so slowly on her horse enjoying the weather...nice! This obviously happens often as there is glass bits everywhere. Doesn't seem like anyone is doing much about it.

Very disappointed.
author: Tamara T.

description:
Daytime, nighttime, the structures look majestic regardless of what time of day it is. I have yet to see it at night, but I get shivers looking at photos of the lit up architecture. One of my favorite places in the world. Thank you Bernard Maybeck, the architectural genius behind this Fine piece of Art (see what I did there, har har). 

I read up on the history of this place, and I suggest others to do so, too. It'll make you appreciate it that much more.
author: Denise L.

description: The most magical place on earth is no longer Disneyland! Or at least not in SF. How I wish I was a local so I could come here to read, jog or have a picnic on a good day. Places like these we only read about in our architectural textbooks and dream of creating, but getting to experience it is just surreal.
author: K C.

description:
If you're thinking of having your wedding at Palace of a Fine Arts, I would seriously consider an alternative spot!! 

Yesterday, we attended a wedding ceremony here which was something we were looking forward to! Even before the ceremony, we knew the bride and groom had made a terrible choice possibly not thinking of the repercussions.

I NEVER ever wish to attend another wedding here again!!!!  Tourists are so rude and invaded our friends ceremony!!!!! And in the middle of the aisle!! Ugh!!!! They got in the way of an awesome San Francisco wedding photographer whose work we've seen before. 

At one point we counted 80 tourists standing around us at our chairs, in the aisle and 360 degrees of the couple. To make matters worse... No amplification and we heard ZERO from the ceremony! But guess what we could hear? Yes, foreigners chatting and scurrying their way to the aisle to snap their photos!!?? This place needs supervision the ceremony was ambushed to say the least!!!

So not romantic or intimate! I would NEVER recommend this place for a wedding quite the opposite in fact!! City Hall as busy as it is can be loads more romantic and beautiful too!!!

If you MUST have a wedding here, hire a planner who will rope off and supervise each entrance to the the dome!! Yes I said it! No supervision oh well take care of YOU!!! I took pics of tourists also arguing with the official wedding photographer whom had asked them politely to scoot! How dare they??? Oh and then an unknown professional photographer shows up and started to hound and shoot the ceremony with a huge sports field lens and no permission from the bride and groom and no regard for the official photographers hired by the bride and groom.

This place is the worse place a bride and groom should consider for a ceremony!! Not to mention at noon with the worse wind tunnel I've ever sat in during a wedding... Felt like winds were 20 mph or more and no bathrooms due to construction!!! 

No thank you!
author: Bahvee V.

description:
This is a great place to take your friends when they are visiting from out of town.  It's gorgeous to look at and take pictures.  Bring your lunch, sit, and relax while taking in the beautiful architecture.  Go in the spring to look at the little fluffy ducklings swimming around.  

It can get cold so bring a jacket.
author: Lisa G.

description: This is a BEAUTIFUL place. Only a few miles away from the Golden Gate Bridge, this venue is top notch. Absolutely GORGEOUS Greco-Roman pillars outside the front of the venue, with a beautiful man made lake adjacent to it. Seats about 1000 and is extremely comfortable.
author: Rhett B.

description: This is a beautiful spot. Fantastic architecture! Also love that you can see the dome from many spots in the city!
author: Laura D.

description: Beautiful place. If it's a beautiful day outside, go grab some picnic food and a blanket and enjoy the view here. Great location and very close to the Golden Gate Bridge and the Bay.
author: John S.

description:
Built in 1915 for the SF World's Fair - this place is a MUST VISIT! It is located between Fort Mason and the Presidio. Beautiful in both the day and night, it's so much fun to either have a picnic or walk around the area!

If you're interested in the historical elements, there are signs around the entire building explaining the exhibits, construction, architecture, and more. This place is a unique part of the San Francisco skyline, and a great spot to check out if you've never been here before.
author: Teresa C.

description: Nice architecture to appreciate. Kind aah pit-Stop ! If you get parking .
author: Krishna J.

description: I am solely writing this review based on a wedding photoshoot that I had done here once. This is absolutely amazing place to have a wedding shoot or any type of modeling shoot to begin with. There are so many different bland beautiful photos you can acquire from such a beautiful background. The lighting is perfect and there are so many great colors you can capture. If you are a photographer and reading this and looking for your next plane to shoot it is definitely here! If you aren't and just looking to visit, defiantly come check this place out. The only thing that is can get tricky is the parking here. There is a parking lot which is great but street parking is scarce but then again it is the city right? Check this place out! You will be amazed about the beauty it has just like I did in person and through my photos!
author: Anne R.

description:
I was told that I should check the Palace of Fine Arts out while on a trip to SF. It is located near/on the way to the Golden Gate Bridge so if you are seeing one you should also see the other since they are both located quite a ways from the other attractions in the city.

The architecture was very pretty and the area itself was very clean and nice. We went on a cold and foggy day so we didn't get to stay for long but it is a great place to sit and relax with a beautiful background.
author: Courtney D.

description:
Been to Palace of Fine Arts a goodly number of times over the years w/ the most recent visit to see NEIL FINN

We've had seats all over the place, from near the front to the very back row & there's never been a bad view.  Sightlines are outstanding & seats themselves are consistently comfy & provide plenty of legroom

Sound quality has also improved over the years, to the point of perfection.  Loud enough to drown out most neighbors but not to the point of distortion - awesomeness

There is a huge lobby-area where drinkys of all kinds are served, as well as little cakes & cookies.  Best part, is that you can also BRING YOUR OWN FOOD to eat in this little area before the show starts

NO food or drinks inside!

Absolutely lovely venue that offers all the comforts & amenities - doesn't get any better!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Absolutely beautiful and breathtaking. I was originally going to skip Palace of Fine Arts, and I'm so glad I didn't! I can totally imagine a lot of engagement shoots being taken here. If I lived nearby, I totally would have done so myself!

Plentiful street parking available.

Walking distance to Crissy Field, where you can a nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
5 Stars because it's soooo beautiful!

I have lived in the Bay for about a year & whenever I go to the city, I always pass by this place. I finally got around to visiting it last Friday night.

FYI; pictures are like impossible at night. With or without flash, it's just a no-go. 

We got here around 9:45pm, there was a lot of people. I think there was some sort of college gathering for some group or something. 

There are bums sleeping here & there so be careful.
Although it's lit at night, there are some dark areas that are sketch if you ask me.

It's a pretty place to take pictures when it's light-out, I would imagine. 
The place is absolutely GORGEOUS! & Ginormous!

The parking wasn't bad because it was so late at night.
I wish the fountain was lit as well at night, suggestion box anyone?
author: Camille C.

description: Just such a beautiful place. Could spend an entire day just walking around here. Really close to Crissy field as well so if your like me and like to explore a city by walking you can totally fit this in on your way to the golden gate bridge
author: Angel R.

description:
My husband and Brother in Law reenacted the scene from The Rock at this location - where it was filmed. 

The place is GORGEOUS. And FREEEEE! :D

So if you want exterior sites or photo ops... actually... this would be great for engagement or wedding photos. I don't know if there is a fee for professional photos but if you just have a camera and wanna take cute photos, it's perfect. 

PARKING: Street

VIEWS: Gorgeous

Best part: FREEE
author: Laura S.

description: This place was beyond beautiful. Came here with a few friends to walk around at night and its just stunning. The entire palace is lit up with lights and its perfect. The columns and architecture is Romanesque. I hear that they have a tour for the Hunger Games here, but we didn't see it. The structure is very large and very detailed. You can walk around, following a path to get to the other side of the pond where you can see the entire palace from a distance. All I can say is WOW. Gorgeous. We came here a day later to stroll around the area during the morning/day and it was just as amazing. You can see the details and structures much better in the sunlight as you would expect. Also, you get to see all of the animals in the pond that you wouldn't be able to see at night. Definitely check this place out if you're in the area!!
author: Steven P.

description:
This place is gorgeous.  A huge structure that looks like it was plucked out of ancient Rome and dropped in San Francisco.

When I visited five years ago, it looked to have fallen into disrepair.  There was plywood sitting on top of some of the columns.  It looked sad.  Neglected.

But I recently revisited the site as some friends were getting married there.  It looked good as new.  A simply gorgeous throwback to a time when every structure wasn't a stupid cement rectangle.

Bonus: The Palace of Fine Arts makes a cameo in the incredible cinematic masterpiece, The Room.  (Tommy Wiseau walks past it during one of his many sorrowful moments.)
author: Ben B.

description: Another tourist attraction. It's beautiful here! If you're visiting, you need to stop by. Sometimes parking is hard to find. They tow/ticket so just be careful!
author: Karen L.

description:
Is Lucky a Lucky gal or what? Having my wedding reception at AT&T Park and finalized my wedding ceremony under the breathtaking rotunda at Palace of Fine Arts! The venue was actually booked on the day of my wedding, but the timeline worked out and I was able to rent it for a few hours for my ceremony in the late afternoon! Guess how much to rent for a ceremony at POFA? Only $500 for 2 hours! I never thought it would even be possible to have a wedding here so boy do I feel LUCKY! 

If you want to have your wedding here, I suggest you book well in advance in case you're not as lucky as me!
author: Lucky N.

description: Beautiful landmark. Amazing place to take a walk and pictures. Ducks swimming around the pond. If you keep walking down the street, there is a nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Elaine D.

description:
Cool Structure

It is an impressive part of local history, but it probably isn't worth going out of the way to see.
author: Ted Q.

description:
If you are going to the Golden Gate bridge or the yoda fountain at Lucasfilm, this can be nice quick stop either on the way there or on the way back.

My gf had seen this place and really wanted to check it out.  On our way to get a picture at the Golden Gate Bridge we saw it from the road and did a quick U-turn to get to it.  We found a parking spot on the street close to the entrance.  It was a short walk to the area with all the architecture.  We walked around an checked everything out.  I'm not a big architecture person, but it was very cool to see this stuff in the middle of SF.

Make sure to take a picture either in or with the rotunda in the background.  We didn't even realize there was a grassy "picnic" area across from the architecture site.  If we didn't have a previous engagement and were getting pressed for time we would have probably had lunch there.  It didn't seem crowded and was looked clean with the grass well manicured that overlooks the lake/pond.

If your are around Presidio this is a nice stop on a sightseeing tour.  While we were there several tour buses did stop, so this place must be decently popular.
author: Robert A.

description:
This place was built for a World Fair celebrating the opening of Panama Canal. We had the amazing pleasure of learning all about it before showing up. We saw it at night and just had to come back in the day. 

I couldn't even tell what country I was in! So gorgeous.
author: Amanda H.

description: It's certainly beautiful and eye catching. A spot frequented by locals and tourists alike. The structure, while gigantic, appears staged. Regardless, the palace of fine arts is a sweet spot to people watch, feed the ducks, watch the ducks get attacked by seagulls, take a stroll, read a book. It's a nice escape from the tourist crowds along Golden Gate Park. It's unique and worth a visit.
author: Isabella J.

description:
Great spot to take photos! It's a beautiful location. I came here with my boyfriend and took lots of awesome photos. There were also people having little picnics which is a great idea! The area is very clean and well kept. You'll see swans, ducks, turtles and more! 
Parking is a bit hard and I believe there's a time limit.
author: Catherine L.

description: Magnificent!  Truly a site to see while in San Fran.  It appears to be a scene from an old ancient city.  The greenery and swans add to the ambiance.
author: Candi L.

description:
Really lovely afternoon stroll. 

Bring a picnic on a sunny day for a sweet date.

Romantic in the evening.
author: Caroline C.

description: The palace of fine arts. I don't what to say but perhaps wow! It's a beautiful place. A very touristy spot, people take their wedding photos, and people cut through while they run. Go check it out and see what SF has to offer!
author: Anthony C.

description:
I found out about this place while waiting in line at Golden Gate Bakery. A gentlemen showed me pictures he took that day and it looked nice so I bookmarked it and came the next day.

This place is beautiful! I love the architecture, the big green door, and the swans! Beautiful swans in the lagoon. A friend told me that you used to be able to rent small boats here. 
I was awed by the grand dome that I had to take a few pics in front of it. 
I can see this place being a popular spot for engagement/wedding photo shoots.
author: Christine T.

description:
Palace of the Arts is probably one of SF's best hidden gems.  It is like no other place in the city - an oasis of beauty that seems to come from another time and place.

Great place to have a picnic of wine and cheese, walk along the pond filled with ducks and turtles and explore the amazing architecture.  

A place to just stop and take a break.
author: Hieu H.

description:
This place is a MUST see when exploring beautiful San Fran. I had such a lovely experience here! Everything was so beautiful; I'm surprised I hadn't been here before. But, better late than never. I would love to have a picnic here with my boyfriend. 

It's also photography heaven here at the Palace of Fine Arts. If you can't afford a plane ticket to Greece or Italy to take great pics of the monumental pillars, this place is the next best thing. It's perfect for engagement or wedding photos, though I would think twice about holding a wedding ceremony here as tourists can come in and possibly be a distraction.
author: Zandra T.

description:
While we didn't get to explore it much, the building is absolutely stunning. It is one place that is most certainly on my MUST DO list for the next time I'm in San Fran. 

The architecture alone is grand! You can sure see how Steven Spielberg got R2D2 from the shape of the building.
author: Dianna B.

description:
Palace of Fine Arts is a god awful attraction for anyone over the age of 2.  In my opinion, it's worse than Disneyland and I hate Disneyland with the fury of a million modern day, bitter feminists who want to blacklist all who oppose their unilateral agenda while they worship their fair-trade, wooden dildos and comb the fleas out of each other's armpit hair. 

There's nothing exciting about this place, except for maybe some duck or swan droppings you see hanging around the lake.  Normally I am inclined to sugar-coat and wrap my words in frosting in how I vocalize my opinions but our tour would have been far more interesting if I had planted my face into a mound of duck fecal matter instead of continuing the walk.  This is a free tourist attraction, meaning you can waltz in whenever you want at any time of the day.  For no charge.  They don't close it down for events that ought to be private, either. 

So what I do have an issue with is when a couple of assholes decide to hold their wedding, in the main architectural structure, in the middle of the day like it's some circus at which others can gawk and stare.  I don't care who you are but if the voids in your lives are so big that you need to fill it with a wedding on public display, airing your vows through microphones throughout the park, and looking around to see if others are intently watching, you're a fucking tool.  And a cheap one at that. 

Some of the things that occurred on top of the wedding ceremony that no one wanted to see were: children climbing on the buildings thinking they're something more than a turd dressed in a human's costume, a woman posing with her newborn baby looking all sultry as the real reasons behind the photos are most likely for exploitative purposes, and too many families.  You will be hard-pressed to get a clear photo of anything. 

I wouldn't waste your time here.  This attraction is wretched beyond unimaginable proportions and would not even come close to putting this place on a pedestal.  It's trying to be everything that it's not.
author: Whitney B.

description: While on vacation in SF this past weekend I made it a point to stop by the Palace of Fine Arts. It was really amazing to see it up close in detail it's so much larger than it looks in pictures. A lot of people come for weddings I can see why. It's free just parking can be a pain sometimes.
author: Anthony V.

description:
We ain't talking bout the Ceaser's Palace, heck we ain't even talking bout Palace of Versailles...We here to talk about the San Francisco Palace of Fine Arts!!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

So I came here for New Years Eve for the very first time, place is huge, kind of hard to find parking and I would just suggest parking by the Pier or the Park and then just taking a Taxi over to this place as there is construction going on and some of the main roads that lead to this place are closed off.  The architecture of this place is really beautiful.  They have the main area of art work and they also have a theater and that's were the comedy show was help.  It's about the size of 4 movie theaters and the chairs are really comfortable as they allow you to lean back and very well cushioned.  I didn't really check the art work out because that was closed off as we were in the party room but everything looks very elegant and is a must see next time I come back here.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Another side note:  This place also has private rooms for weddings and I took a peak and I can tell you the service and setup that they provided was absolutely exquisite!!!
author: Deep S.

description:
TOURIST SPOT: I love coming here. By far one of my favorite places to go in San Francisco. You can take pictures, like my sister did for her pregnancy shoot. Most people take wedding pictures,  and etc. It's just such a beautiful place to watch the birds fly, have a picnic, and take in the architecture. If you're looking to take pictures, this is the spot to go. If you're looking for a nice walk or place to propose, I recommend this one.

Parking can be challenging sometimes, but if you wait a little, someone usually leaves. There's a nice neighborhood nearby, so parking is generally available for free. Weekends (especially Saturdays) are the worst because this place is packed. But, it will always be my favorite tourist spot in SF.
author: Ameera D.

description:
Me and my friends had so much funs climbing the walls and ish lol I hate heights but we took the most hipster photos ever lol the columns/architecture is quite interesting and captivating! 

I felt like spiderman for the day. If you plan to climb things be careful lol
author: Grace G.

description:
Another spot to check out if you are in the area.

Parking can be tough, but if you are on a tourist bus, no problem.

The water way around the Palace has turtles and geese. 

The place is actually amazing and when you go within, the structure is actually a piece of majestic art.

If you are looking for restrooms and refreshments, you can go inside and I believe it is by donation at the very least. There you find a place to eat and sit, kids play area and even some museum history and amazing photos from the past.

Great photo opportunities.
author: Roger A.

description: Awesome place to visit .  I haven't had a chance to go inside yet but the outside is awsome one of those must see places in San Francisco  . At night it gets even better expecially when no one is around and you can enjoy the palace with a fine cigar
author: Bph B.

description:
Beautiful gardens and so peaceful. If you love photography of nature, walks, or just overall beautiful sounds and surroundings this is the place for you. I did not go inside the Theater so I cannot comment on that. There are benches along the outer boarder so if you get tired or the kids there is somewhere to sit. 

It's such a beautiful place that people were even having photos taken of their wedding party. It's so peaceful and serene there is also grass areas where you can bring a picnic lunch. It's great for the kids, family, photos even the dog. 

The only reason I am not giving 5 stars is. They have teenagers working a stand when you first walk in, not sure what it is some kind of cloud mixer? The time I was there by the stand the teens were obnoxiously loud and never even tried to get peoples attention to ask if they wanted to see the display, I even saw a few people stop to read the sign but the teens were too engrossed in their conversation to even acknowledge them.
author: Lynette C.

description:
All I can say it's free and there's plenty of parking. A lot of people take their special event:: wedding, quinceañera, and prom pictures here. There is plenty of free parking and it's close to the bay front where they wind sail.

All you gotta hope is that you go at the right time where this is no fog and the sun is behind you in most of the pictures you want to take.

It's definitely a must see tourist attraction when you visit SF besides the Golden Gate Bridge, Chinatown, Twin Peaks, and few other spots.
author: Martin N.

description:
One of the best photo spots in the city. The building itself, the lagoon around it, the houses in the surrounding neighborhoods, the city skyline in the distance, the ocean right across the street.. what more can you ask for?

Lots of people take wedding photos around here, so you'll have to dodge a lot of wedding entourages as you walk around. People have weddings inside the rotunda too, so you might get blocked from entering at certain times. If you do get an opportunity to get inside, there really isn't that much to see (the outside is much more impressive) since it's a giant open space, but anyone interested in architecture will get a kick out of it.

Parking isn't always easy. I've been lucky before and got a parking spot right next to the park despite the hundreds of tourists. But if you're having trouble, just park in a nearby residential neighborhood. I've never really had trouble out there. I think all the tourists just stick to the direct vicinity and fight for those spots...
author: Allen C.

description:
I love San Francisco. 

For places like this that leaves you astounded.

A picturesque lake with the swans gently gliding by. 

From the beautiful arches to the magnificent dome. 

Your thoughts will be silenced at the grandness of it all and the only sound you'll be making is an occasional gasp.

And the clicking of your camera.
author: Janice C.

description:
Absolutely gorgeous and breathtaking. I did not get a chance to see any performances here, but my husband and I did come here on a beautiful summer evening this past August. I am so impressed by the atmosphere of this place and the houses around it. it's just so gorgeous and the water just makes it look so special.
I would love to come here and see a show one day.
author: Summer S.

description:
I remember being a kid and going to the Palace of Fine Arts and wondering how the hell they got all the stuff from Rome here... ha.  The imagination of a 12 year old.

Now I have been to the park several times to go to shows at the theatre, to stroll around romantically at night (by myself because most won't claim me in public) and to simply enjoy the city.

I do wish their was a solution for better parking but short of bribing the water gods to stir up the seas and add some more square footage off the ledge and into the bay, there is not much you can do about parking - so do what I do - plan your trip or go in the evening.

I do wish that there was more readable info available about the park, like on little billboards or something, or perhaps there might be - it was dark and I was drinking so I guess I can not quite say there is not some secret smarty pants place to read up on the surrounding structure and area BUT thanks to little things called 4G and wikipedia - problem solved!

All in all, I love this place.
author: Marie B.

description: The architecture is so beautiful! It's free to visit, there is plenty of free parking on the street. It is a beautiful place, there are a lot of parties and weddings here. The view of the surrounding houses is really beautiful!
author: Veronica S.

description: We never went inside the building but we loved the outside architecture. This is probably one of the prettiest structures on the westcoast. Though not as old, it definitely brought me a feel of being in Europe again.
author: Arthur K.

description: Beautiful and a great way to spend the afternoon or get some air and the body moving. Walk across the street and find Chrissy Field with amazing views of just about everything.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Wow. Just wow. What an absolutely beautiful experience 'Palace of the fine arts' is.

We stopped here as part of our bike tour and were captivated by the landscape and design of this incredible monument. 

Make sure you bring a good camera with you (as I only had my iPhone), as you can capture some incredible shots. 

After you pick your jaw up from the ground, take a moment to sit on the grass and just take in the beauty around this area. There was a wedding on when I was there and we just watched people share nuptials whilst the sun beamed down on us.

This place is truly magical.
author: Evan K.

description: Beautiful spot for a nice stroll. The architecture is inspiring (European style), the parks well designed. A bit crowded and touristy, but it's never been so crowded that I wanted to avoid it like some areas in the city. Great place for photos or a picnic as well.
author: Mikkel R.

description:
I love coming here with my kids and walking around the lake, feeding the ducks, and picnic'ing in the grass. As an art historian, I love the architecture, but you don't have to  have a degree to know that it's one of the most beautiful pieces in all of San Fran. I like going in the afternoon when the lighting and sun are just right, but nighttime is also great for photo opts. 

Oh, and if you want to know what's inside: nada for you. It was the Exploritorium but now it's a big auditorium used for private events.

And don't follow Google Maps to the parking lot. Just park on the street or neighborhood in front of the lake.
author: Ashley E.

description: We love living within walking distance from here! This is just such a fantastic part of San a Francisco history. What fun it is to go here and just watch the bird life in the water and trees. Swans on the pond chasing off all the seagulls as to not threaten their swanlings? You'll be sure to always see weddings, or after wedding phot shoots around the palace. This place is just fun to see and enjoy!
author: Kirk M.

description: Amazing architecture,  definitely glad we strolled through this afternoon to stand awestruck at the magnificent concrete structures. If time allows this is a great pit stop to admire in the Bay Area
author: Ben K.

description:
The dome structure is beautiful. The way they have the dome surround by water is beautiful.  The tall columns that surround the dome is beautiful.  I wish I had the words to describe how beautiful the Palace of Fine Arts is but I don't. To know it is to see it.

The structure is located in a residential neighborhood directly across from houses. Parking can be easy to find depending on when you go (we went on a weekday).  There is a lot of turnover since most people come here for pictures and then go. For those that like to stay a little longer, there are benches to absorb the view and the serenity.  A must see in San Francisco.
author: Janet E.

description:
OK, so it's not "authentic" like the historic ruins you see in Europe, but this place is goooorgeous nonetheless. Sure it's got a kind of Disney theme park feel to it, but it's an amazing place to take a leisurely stroll, enjoy the sunshine and absorb that European-Californian cultural fusion that is so unique to SF.

My advice for the perfect day? In this order:
- Visit the Wal Disney Museum in the Presidio
- Hike the (easy) trails of the Presidio
- Explore the Palace of Fine Arts
- Picnic and spend the rest of the day in beautiful Crissy Field
author: Josephine L.

description:
My 1,700th review starts in a darkened theater (somewhere in Mr. Peabody's Wayback Machine) when I was at a Hitchcock retrospective watching "Vertigo" for the very first time. Jimmy Stewart was psycho-obsessed with Kim Novak, so much so that he stalks her when she "dies" as frigid wife Madeleine and comes back to life as insecure shopgirl Judy. On their first date, they stroll wordlessly on Baker Street in front of a gauzy tableau image of the Palace of Fine Arts. I recall thinking what an elaborate set for Hitch to build for such a brief transitional scene. 

Jamie W. and I came back to the Palace this past Saturday because it was a beautiful day, as we haven't visited since all the renovations were completed around the walkways and the lagoon. Bernard Maybeck's Greco-Roman design is ornately classical but softened by the hint of ocher in its finish. While the rotunda dominates the cityscape in this part of the city, the overall effect within this upscale Marina neighborhood is actually quite soothing with the colonnades standing guard over the lagoon festooned with gigantic white swans. The scene is quite lovely, a feeling shared by the dozens of pre-matrimonial couples who pose here for photos every weekend. See my 21-photo tribute for evidence.

The crescent-shaped former exhibit hall complements the curvature of the colonnades and houses the expansive Exploratorium on one side. The kid-friendly museum is moving to the Embarcadero soon, but the 1,000-seat theater remains. A great venue. I've seen a Crowded House reunion concert there as well as the annual Help Is on the Way AIDS benefit performance. Seats are spacious, always a treat when dealing with the inevitability of middle-age spread. Even though the Palace of Fine Arts has been rebuilt several times since it was originally designed as a temporary exhibit during the Panama-Pacific Exposition, it celebrates its centennial anniversary in 2015. Now more than ever, it is a place to savor.
author: Ed U.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is definitely a beautiful sight to visit in SF. Pictures don't do justice of how pretty it is in person!

There are multiple buildings surrounded by gardens and a lake. It has a very European feel, and a duck atmosphere as there are plenty of ducks and a few swans in the adjacent lake. Of course, my boyfriend and I took pictures of this site, as well as photo bombed some of our fellow visitors' pictures. If you see a weird looking couple in the back that's us!
author: Felicia L.

description:
I hope I don't ruin the beauty of the Palace of Fine Arts when I tell you I first admired it from watching 'The Rock'. 

Before knowing anything about the movie business, I always wondered where this beautiful space was where John Patrick Mason (Sean Connery) would meet his daughter Jade (Claire Forlani) for the first time in years. Thankful this wasn't just some elaborate set, I was super stoked to realize this was one of my stops during my trip to San Francisco. 

Obviously it's a big tourist area, but such a pretty one where I don't feel too much like an outsider as I attempt to take a photo that didn't end up coming out (this was 1997, people). So many of these photo opportunities to be taken, and it was evident that even some locals were in on this as well with their engagement, wedding, and family portraits being shot. Almost as beautiful at night, the palace has a golden light that seems to radiate from within. Some of the photos posted on here caught that, but nothing compares to seeing this grand structure in person. 

If was to return today, I'd bring a book and find a bench, but you know I'd probably just people-watch all day. And if the people-watching isn't so great, at least I'll be in beautiful surroundings.
author: Shannon N.

description: Gorgeous place, so stunning. The most impressive at sun set.
author: Larisa M.

description:
Couldn't stop blabbering about this place to everyone I met after coming here.

The first time I saw the dome from a distance and heard about it I thought it was some pretty building with a bunch of boring Renaissance paintings in it and an old security guard gently snoozing under a wall-length fresco of a fat naked lady eating pomegranates.

Boy was I wrong!~

Now, I am too lazy to look any oif this up for you but here's the gist, I apologize if I sound like an idiot.

This place was an exhibition for a World's Fair-type event in 1915, in the time when walking around a nice place was like, THE THING. 

And the architect created a masterpiece for promenading here as the symmetric reflecting lagoon and obscene scale of this Romanesque rotunda (or Naboo State Building for Star Wars fan) is jaw-dropping. 

Beyond being some of the most beautiful grounds in North America, the Palace of Fine Arts has what I think of as an awesome sense of humor as I believe the whole piece is a statement of the hubris of art and the inevitability of death for us all and all we create.

The two-story trophies that line the rotunda are actually urns and after a long while, you finally realize all of the goddess figures atop the dome are facing away from you and seem to be weeping. 

There's lots more symbolism but this is yelp, get off my back!
author: Ryan S.

description:
Took the bus here from Chinatown (I think Route 30), and it dropped off a block or 2 away, which was very convenient. I LOVED it here!!! The structures were absolutely stunning and the area was clean. I'm sure you can stay here for a bit..there were a few people (looked like locals) just hanging out with a blanket. However, you don't need too much time here if you are in a time-crunch. The great part of it is that Crissy field is just a couple steps away (there's a public restroom there). And its near the Golden Gate Bridge so its a nice stop before or after.

I went on a sunny day (still cold though) so I felt like I fully enjoyed it because it was a beautiful day.
author: Kristel B.

description:
Beautiful. just ornately beautiful. :)

This an architectural beauty for sure. It's romantic & just lovely.

I definitely recommend coming here to take pictures, have a picnic with your loved ones, or just for a stroll. :)
author: Amy C.

description:
This place is BEAAUTIFUL.
So many tourists, though...
but whenever I'm in the area, I like to take a little scroll here.
author: Alyssa Z.

description:
Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful!

While I didn't spend much time at this landmark, I was there long enough to know that it's completely unique, special and cool -- definitely a spot worth visiting again and again. You feel like you're wandering through one of the weird scenes from Fantasia with the oversized architecture, flowing river and blooming trees. 

My one complaint is the weird parking -- street only with a lot of restrictions. I guess it might be on of the things keeping this spot from being over-crowded. 

It's the perfect spot for photos, wandering and chatting or chillin' with a book. Love it!
author: Hilary H.

description:
One Ride Only

Walk around, get some great photos in, and then leave as quickly as possible. It's not a place I recommend staying a long period of time cause you keep seeing and fake smiling at the same people you just saw like 2 minutes ago. My friends and I needed to walk off the food we ate at Off The Grid (Picnic in the Park...Presidio) so we ended up here and just did our model thing.( Man, I should have been a photographer!) Like I said don't overstay your welcome, cause the swans and ducks get a little testy as well. A must see at least once!
author: Lauren S.

description:
This Park/Theatre is a beautiful San Francisco attraction, located close by to the golden gate bridge. We were visited San Fran in late March so I think we were pretty lucky that we were the only ones there when we arrived, as I am sure it gets flooded with people in the warmer months. 

The architecture is beautiful, it's free to see, and it would be a lovely place to have a picnic or take engagement pictures at. The swans and ducks are fun to watch as well.  A must see in San Francisco :)
author: Katherine M.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is not only an amazing Photo Op with its Columns, Trees, and Lagoons which many local Swans, and Ducks call home, but its also some what removed from the bustle of San Francisco making it an ideal place for couples to have a quiet moment.

This was part of the 1915 Panama Pacific Exposition , yes it is 100 years old (Check out the Legion of Honor which will be hosting a special exhibition), and past home of the Exploatorium now located along the waterfront,  

Currently being used by the,  
Palace of Fine Arts Theater, with a capacity of nearly 1000, (check out their events calender), and the main shed is being transformed into a contemporary gallery space for the centennial exhibition, and for future events.

FYI , The Rotunda is also a popular Wedding / Reception space that can be reserved via SF Parks & Rec
author: Joseph A.

description:
We meant to visit during the day, but because we got lost (read: construction), we ended up there about a half hour after sunset. The dome is BEAUTIFUL! At night, the dome is all lit up, & there are barely any people around. We took a quiet walk around, taking pictures & admiring the beautiful scene. We had a lot of opportunities to take some creative pictures, working with the lights & angles of the classic dome & the surrounding statues.

But the thing is, I'm not sure what its actual purpose is, other than for taking beautiful pictures. I heard that the bigger building used to house the Exploratorium, but now it's just sitting empty? And it was originally a temporary structure, but they made it permanent. Maybe they use it as a small conference hall or something, but I dunno. It just seemed like wasted space to me. My fiance also told me that people sometimes take engagement or wedding photos there, and I guess I can see that too. But otherwise? It's just a nice thing to see.
author: JoAnna D.

description: Loving taking friends here for photos and lounging around on the grass. Perfect place to impress anyone who comes to town (or a date!)
author: Samantha Y.

description:
This place is really pretty, no matter what time of day you go. The architecture and the scenic waters are gorgeous and so photo worthy. You will oftentimes see people taking their engagement photos around here or even having their weddings under that building. I have only walked around the building but never got the chance to go inside. I am thinking if the outside is impressive, there must be some goodies inside as well. I cant wait to return so I can bust out my DSLR and have my own photoshoots.

Parking is difficult around the place especially if you look for street parking. There is also parking specifically for Palace of Fine Arts and all I have to say is that you just have to keep on searching until there is an opening. It was free but it will be tough finding a spot. Good luck!

**TIPS**
1) Bring your camera. Photo shoot time.
2) Enjoy!
author: Amy H.

description: Easy to get to, must stop. You can spend 10 minutes there, or an hour or 2. BE SURE TO Go earlier in the day! Once the sun dips low, it doesn't have the best lighting!
author: Linds H.

description:
After a long Saturday afternoon of driving around SF and not finding parking spots, this place couldn't have been more relaxing. Although the parking situation is awful here too, we eventually found a spot and were able to enjoy the palace.

The place was not too crowded, with most people either hanging on the grassy areas or walking along the curved paths. I enjoyed that there were many shaded areas, making for a cool time even on a warm day. Be prepared to see a bunch of wedding photo shoots though haha.

If you want to get away from the busyness of the city, this is the place to be. Come walk the paths, chill on the grass and benches, and enjoy the beautiful architecture. I hadn't heard about it before, and I don't think too many tourists have...which is probably the reason it was not overflowed with people (unlike fisherman's wharf). Overall a relaxing and enjoyable time, highly recommended.
author: Kamran M.

description: Good place to take older visitors. Easy walk around the lagoon. Low stress. Opportunity to take nice photos of building, swans, geese, turtles and other wild life. Off street parking but hide valuables. Lots of wedding pics taken here.
author: Clifford W.

description:
I guess its appropriate for a city I'd describe as "otherworldly" and "European" that the one place I just **had** to get to looks like some European ruin aliens decided to drop in amongst the Victorian painted ladies, yachts, and fog that make up the area around the bay. 
A leftover from an early 20th century worlds exposition in SF, the dome and lovely ladies that surround the top of the columns of the palace rise up suddenly from the surrounding area. Theres lots of photo opps, a pond in front with swans, and a promenade that takes you around and through the "palace".  I can honestly say that the 3.5 miles we decided to walk uphill from the tenderloin through Pacific heights to the palace were worth it.  (My traveling companion may disagree but thats why everyone needs their own yelp account.:) Its one of those things you have to really see to believe.
Sure, fishermans wharf and Alcatraz get all the attention. Trust me, this should be on a list of must see attractions while in the bay area, even if you only walk through briefly.
author: Lisa A.

description: Walked around here at night to explore the architecture a bit and it was simply beautiful! It's a bit of a ways away, but well worth the visit :)
author: Bianca C.

description:
A beautiful garden. Great place to walk around with families or friends. 
Parking is a little bit difficult, but wait for some minutes and you should be able to find a parking place soon.
author: Poon D.

description:
I've always seen pictures of this spot posted on the the Instagrams and Facebooks so it was a must for my boyfriend and I to check out when we were up in San Francisco.

We stopped by here on our last day and it was still a bit over cast out for our Easter Sunday.  There was an engagement shoot and wedding shoot going on near by which was so adorable it was gross.

The walk around the pond is gorgeous.  There were cute ducks still sleeping by the water and moms power walking their babies in strollers. 

This is a great photo opportunity.  I have never met so many nice people as in San Francisco.  We never had to ask anyone to take our photo.  People would just volunteer and make nice small talk.  

I'd love to live by the Palace Of Fine Arts.  The view looking at it is breathtaking.  Maybe when I have 5 million to spend on a town house I'll do it.
author: Nicole B.

description:
This has got to be one of the most beautiful and breathtaking places in California. The architecture is amazing and the scenery is gorgeous. If there was a real life Disney Fairy tale, this would definitely be one of the settings in the story.
My only wish is that this place was bigger and that there were even more architecture. You really do feel like you walk into a different world. It is an immersive experience that leaves you touched and moved, but desiring more and more of it. I strongly and happily recommend this place, especially for couples and/or families. It is an ideal place for weddings and dances. Even if you don't like art or architecture, you definitely will not be disappointed by this place.
author: Hu L.

description: You can't miss it. The Palace of Fine Arts is one FINE tourist attraction. Gorgeous architecture and surrounding nature with greenery and fountains. Perfect spot for a photo shoot or wedding. There is street parking nearby (usually with a 2 hour time limit) but if you ever have to park further away and walk, you won't regret it on a sunny San Francisco day. Have a picnic, walk your dog, or take a stroll for a date. So peaceful...
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Made a quick stop here before heading across the bridge. It's a nice quick and beautiful stop to make if you have an extra 30 minutes or so to burn. 

-Parking is Free
- Bring a Camera
- Bring bread or something to feed the ducks/birds
author: Brandon Y.

description:
So beautiful. That's all I can really say about it. I mean how could such a perfect place exist? 

The Palace of Fine Arts is another one of those gems that San Francisco has to offer. You're always going to see photographers with their extensive camera gear here,  couples displaying their love for the whole world to see, families walking around saying hi to the ducks, and even just individuals soaking in the wonder than this place offers. I mean once you're here, you will understand why so many couples choose to take their wedding photographs here. It's something straight out of a movie.

On those rare weekends when my friends and I felt like dealing with the awful public transportation in SF, we would grab our bags and head here. We would grab some candy bars, and food and spend the day here pretending to study. What a perfect way to waste away the day. 5/5
author: Michelle L.

description: I always bring friends who visit up here. I've always managed to find parking here when I visit and it's a great place to park (street parking) to walk around the Palace of Fine Arts and take a stroll over to E Beach where the San Francisco Bay Area Trail goes through. You get a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Wing L.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is a great place for tourists and locals alike!

Pros
1) Free street parking! 
2) Great picture spot
3) Historic landmark (they have a replica in Disney's California Adventure!)
4) Used in Alfred Hitchcock's movie Vertigo! 
5) FREE.99!

Pro tip: Bring a jacket because it gets windy here!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
What a gem!
Grand architectures is grand. The giant dome tower graced by sunlight shining through the trees, sprinkled with white wings flutter back and forth. This place is poetry in motion. San Francisco, being a tourist city, is always in its hustle. The palace here brings peace, the equivalent of New York's Central Park. I was lucky enough to get a picture with the white seagulls (?) herd flying across the pond. I so want to come back and have a picnic here. 
Lovely and romantic, highly recommended for a date.
author: Vy L.

description:
After the 1906 earthquake and fire, San Francisco wanted to show that like a legendary phoenix, they too can rise from the ashes.  Fast-forward some very interesting information and history and to the review!  

This place is gorgeous.  I'm sure everyone can agree what a marvel this place is.  It's great for family, friends, dates, and some quiet self-reflection time.  I've been coming here with my family since I was a kid.  One of my favorite memories about this place was when my uncle and his then-girlfriend, now wife, took me here on a picnic and I was every bit like an Asian Stephanie Tanner with my pink shirt, jean vest, matching jean skirt, and side-ponytail.  I wore a handkerchief around my neck, which I still own, and we spent the day under sunny skies and cool weather.  That had to be the prettiest grassy hill I ever skipped on.  I still have cheesy photos of me standing at the lagoon trying to look cute and sassy at the same time.  Ah, the 90's.  Anyways, it's not unusual to see couple getting engagement photos taken and artists doodling away on paper and canvas on the gorgeous views.  The architecture of the Palace of Fine Arts is stunning and this is definitely a must-see if you're in town!
author: Joyce W.

description:
I see myself visit this place every day if I had the chance. It has everything: lagoon, fine arts, Greek/roman architecture, park, ducks, ample walking space, and much much more. 

Very relaxing space. Loved how the sun reflected off the main structure. Loved how you forgot for a minute you were in a city. 

With the exception of tourists, kids, and parking issues this has become a favorite spot in San Francisco for me. 4 and half stars.
author: Luis D.

description:
One of San Francisco's great spots to see.

Pros
Nice scenery.
Romantic
Chill
Relaxing
Peaceful.
Great place to take pics.
Seen lots of couples take their wedding photos here.

I always recommend this spot when people ask for nice spots in SF to see. Then I get asked "wasnt The Rock filmed here".
author: T C.

description: This place is absolutely beautiful! So peaceful and relaxing! This would make an awesome photo shoot area for any occasion. Will definitely be back again.
author: Bernadette E.

description: Wonderful place for a tour trip!I love it so much! The angel sculptures is awesome! Highly recommend place!
author: Roski L.

description: Beautiful in person. A must see. We saw a wedding happen and a photoshoot for an engagement and quince.
author: Ang M.

description:
Raise your hand if the first time you saw this place it was in "So I Married An Axe Murderer."

I didn't notice unsightly fences or bird poop as some of the other reviewers did. What I did notice is a beautiful pergola and grounds with people enjoying themselves and the weather.

(Some more information on the site can be found here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palace_of_Fine_Arts)

My friend, who was visiting from Texas, and I walked the grounds, took pictures and sat on benches and generally enjoyed our little outing and the surroundings. There are so few places that a built purely for beauty's sake that I now have a soft spot in my heart for this place.

HIGHLIGHT: There were some signs that said "Warning: Aggressive raccoons," and m friend and I wanted so bad to turn them into "Warning" Passive-aggressive raccoons," signs.
author: Tara H.

description:
palace of the fine arts is simply so beautiful! 

even if you're just wondering the area, and you're not necessarily there to see a show/concert, it is still a great attraction for tourists to take cool pictures & look at the structure/art work of the building
author: Brooke W.

description:
Such a beautiful stop while sightseeing through the city.
I can imagine getting married here, or taking prom pictures here, truly a magnificent scene.

Seems to get a bit congested at certain hours (with tourists)...but this place even seems like it would be beautiful when shrouded in that iconic San Francisco mist. Make sure to stop by on your next visit.
author: Carol B.

description: Scenic and peaceful place to take a stroll in one of the nicest neighborhoods in San Francisco.  I have a lot of happy memories visiting the Palace of Fine Arts, and it will always hold a special place in my heart, no matter where I am!
author: Karen W.

description:
Beautiful place!  I was intrigued by its history, since all things Exposition-related pique my interest.  I regret that I didn't have time to walk all the way around it and find all the explanatory plaques that tell you about the history of the pavilion and grounds.  

It was very crowded when we were there on a Sunday - full of wedding parties taking pictures, of course.  A few ceremonies as well.  

One note - if you want to grab food around here, you'll have to walk a few blocks or suffer the prices and selection of the Beach Hut Café.  Come prepared!
author: Johanna K.

description:
We were here to attend the International Ethnic dance festival.

The seating is well designed such that even if you get the seats at the back(which are cheaper) you willl enjoy the show just like the rest of the audience.

 The acoustics are very good too.There was a performance where a musician was using the slightest cymbal effect and you could hear it soo clearly as part of the whole ( I love it when you can hear everything as the artiste intended) adds to making a performance that much more perfect :)

Lisa has mentioned an important point here, the ladies bathroom door does open into the lobby and it may make you uneasy. i avoided using the restroom here just because of it.

There are snacks served which you could buy during the intervals.I found them to be average.
author: Harsha G.

description:
I'll be honest and admit I don't really know any history about this place except it's in the foreground of the Exploritorium (which, if you grew up in the Bay Area, is THE go-to place for educational field trips)!

I came here last night with a friend for my first night time visit and I must say it's so much more gorgeous at night when it's all lit up! Very picturesque! On such a warm SF night, there were several people still out and wandering around the grounds taking pictures.

This definitely a must-see place! I felt like a tourist in my own city, but it's worth the visit!
author: Leana L.

description: This is such a beautiful place! We came here for a family photo shoot, so I didn't have a lot of time to walk around. But I was in awe with the gorgeous architecture and history. There was a wedding in the Rotunda that day and it was very crowded, so it was difficult to enjoy any space without being bumped. Nevertheless, I was able to take nice photos of the structures. The weather was gorgeous (even a little cold in July) and the grassy hill overlooking the Palace was perfect for a picnic. There are a few parking spaces right next to the theater that we were lucky to grab, so it was a quick walk into the premises. This is a great landmark to visit earlier in the morning to beat the crowds. No costs associated with parking or visiting either.
author: Amelinda L.

description:
Scenic but can get crowded.

With a proper theater (large stage, good seating, good lighting/audio, large lobby).
author: Inigo M.

description:
The first thing I thought when I saw this was, "Why would anybody decide to build such a random building here? And where did all this money come from.." I could probably just wiki it but I'm pretty lazy. 

Regardless, this is an amazing area with beautiful architecture. There's not much to do here except to look at how pretty the architecture is, but I feel like it would be great for photo shoots. The lake adds a nice touch to the architecture as well, and I loved how there were swans there! 

If I lived in the area, I would totally come here, bring a book, climb onto one of the stairs stuff on the side and spend a few hours there. It's a very peaceful place, I highly recommend visiting this place :)
author: Helen T.

description:
This place is amazing ! Very beautiful ! A must stop for every visiter coming to SF.
Close to Golden gate bridge and the park. Nice place to take a lot of pictures. Watch out for the suan he bites if you don't have food ! LOL
author: Brent K.

description: Awesome place for a romantic walk.  Stroll around the lake, say hi to the swans.  Take selfies.
author: Stanley W.

description: Ultimately one of my favorite places to go to take a look at the scenery in SF. There is usually a duck lady that comes and to feed right before dusk. It was a total "feed the birds, toppins a bag" Mary Poppins moment when we saw her. We knew she was taking care of the ducks because she was commenting on them individually. There are benches and tons of grass to lay on. We come here about twice for a little picnic. Usually we see people taking wedding pictures or tons of tourists. It is a magnificent place and theres tons of free parking.
author: Lynn C.

description: I was recently a bridesmaid for one of my best friends and she had her wedding ceremony at the Palace of Fine Arts in San Francisco.  It's a beautiful, idyllic location to have a wedding and it seemed like it was straight out of a dream.  The Palace of Fine Arts is an outdoor park with a beautiful large dome and a long row of interconnected columns that go around a lovely lake containing swans, ducks, and other majestic creatures.  It's truly a lovely place to have a wedding.   My friend's wedding took place within the intricately-carved dome.
