Though it's quite literally a wind tunnel, it was such a magnificent place to have a wedding (and to be part of a wedding!).  It's very picturesque and the bride and us bridesmaids (and the rest of the wedding party) had a lot of different spots to choose from for pictures.  The bride rented the location for her wedding for a minimal charge, since it is a public park.  I would highly recommend it if you're getting married in San Francisco and want to get married in a truly picturesque public space.  I had so much fun being a bridesmaid in that wedding!
author: Pegah Y.

description: Well, the OUTSIDE is gorgeous but the area pre-entrance to the theatre is the biggest joke ever.  CASH only saddest excuse for a bar/vending machine quality snack bar.  Huge space with sad little tables and chairs.  I've seen better at a public park.  Oddest little table with tea bags.  WHAT????  I feel like I'm in the Twilight Zone on acid.
author: Lynne P.

description:
What can I say about this heaven on earth place... If you have never been here, make some time during your visit in SF to come walk around and take in this outdoor beauty. Sometimes there are musicians busking which adds some magic to this already beautiful place. 

They have revamped it a lot and I'm so glad to see they are doing their best to conserve this wonder. Day or night, he palace of fine arts is amazing on the eyes. The Exploratorium museum is not there anymore (moved to one of the piers). Still, this place is magic, an absolute must to pay it a visit.
author: D S.

description:
This place is so beautiful...
Before I went, I've always seen pictures of it and didn't expect much when I was going there... but I was blown away! It's sooooooooo grand--much bigger than I imagined in my head. It's so pretty... I didn't feel like I was in SF/California. Wowowowow asdkjweflkjwfklwjeflkwjeflwkefj. Good place to bring friends visiting from out of town.
author: Annie S.

description:
I've got no fiance, but this is where I'm getting married. I don't care if I have to marry a sock puppet. 

This is one of the most beautiful works of human artistry I have ever had the incredible good fortune of being able to witness firsthand. It might take an eye for art to really want to climb the structure and sit and read a book for hours, but I don't think anyone could be immune to the beauty of this place upon beholding it for the first time.

The structure is so enormous that it will blow even the most seasoned adventurer away. It will transport the dorkiest of us straight to Middle Earth and make even the most modest of brides feel like a queen in her palace. 

This building is a place of perpetual summer and perpetual wonder. It is undoubtedly my favorite place in San Francisco, and one of my favorite places in the world.
author: Ren G.

description: Super beautiful lake a grounds around the palace. You'll get to see ducks, geese, and even swans swimming in the waters. The palace itself is very stunning. The architecture is epic. I think that's the best way to describe it. There are grassy areas to sit on and spend some time as well. Great spot right near the bay and beach.
author: Joanna V.

description:
Beautiful spot to spend an hour or so of your day. Take a stroll or nap. Take pictures because they'll turn out gorgeous. Totally different San Francisco scenery.  Admire the dome and architecture! Bring a date. Be romantic and cutesy :) Or not. Up to you! 

There's street parking in the area but read the parking signs!!  We had no problem with parking on a somewhat busy day. The Palace is literally next to the Exploratorium and for some reason, my BF totally missed it when we visited a few years ago. Who knew it was a place you could actually visit/explore/enjoy? But it's there and so pretty!!
author: Christine L.

description: Wow! Saw this while we were driving on the way to Muir woods and had to stop. Glad we did. The architecture is just beautiful and add in the history it is a must see.
author: Jess P.

description:
I just can't say enough about this amazing piece of architecture! It is absolutely breathtaking. Day or night this is the place to walk about and ponder the universe.

Someday when I marry a billionaire (haha) this is where I want the wedding to be! I am so stinking jealous of the people who live in the incredible mansions surrounding the park that I could spit!

But really... If you are only able to visit two places while in SF go to the bridge (naturally) and then the Palace of Fine Arts. (And then if you still have time go to Golden Gate Park)
author: Jill P.

description:
I can't believe I had never been here before. After seeing a friend post some photos of him proposing here I knew I had to stop here on my next trip to San Francisco. 
The location is perfect for a quick walk before driving over the Golden Gate Bridge. The architecture is so beautiful and my son loved all the ducks, swans and birds to look at.
author: Natalie C.

description: This is a beautiful must see site in San Francisco. You will also enjoy the architecture of the homes around the area.
author: Heidi A.

description: A memorable experience for us. The place was amazing and has explicit structures. I will definitely be coming back but the sad part was someone broke our window and stole our things. I guess it's a common thing and happens a lot. According to staff it happens 20 times a week. You would have thought they added extra measures. Paid parking won't be a bad idea if it's for safety of visitors.  Safety first!
author: Ira F.

description: I'm attending old friend, Colin Hay's gig here tonight.  The acoustics in the theater are wonderful!
author: Shirley M. J.

description:
I didn't get a chance to go inside because we only stopped by for a little while before dropping my friend off at his apartment nearby, but...

This place is GORGEOUS! Such a pretty location to take photos. Since we came on a Tuesday evening, there was ample parking. Parking is free btw. :]

My friend told me that it's a really good spot to go running, and I did see some people running around the perimeter while we were there.

Next time I'm in town, I definitely want to check out the actual building. When I do, I'll update my review. As for my first impressions, the Palace of Fine Arts is definitely a spot to hit up. 5 stars!
author: Aizel A.

description:
OMG. THIS IS PRICELESS and is FREE to walk around. 
First of all, the houses surrounding the palace are palaces. Beautiful neighborhood. 
Now, the palace itself. Just breath taking. You see all the birds, turtles and fish in the water makes you feel like you are in Rome. You step back into time and see large pillars, fountains and birds flying. Just magical.
author: Prusha S.

description:
AMAZING!

I can't believe I haven't visited this place before, it's beautiful! Definitely a must visit if you are in SF; the architecture is overwhelming and the lake in front is very beautiful on a nice day =)
author: Sam F.

description: The show we watched here was Potted Potter. I have zero complaints about the theatre area itself. The show was very entertaining!! The restrooms here however could use some improvements. After the show I recommend going elsewhere to use the washroom, for the lines are very long afterwards!
author: Simpson D.

description:
Perfect for your dates.

Its so romantic to come day and night. People in SF are so lucky to have such a place like this :)
author: Ken H.

description: Easily one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen from every angle. A photographers dream and such a lovely place to walk around. Make sure you have a lot of space on your camera and a full battery since you will blow through it taking a crazy amount of pictures.
author: Mikhail H.

description:
For the last day of my vacation I wanted to come here. I have always seen this place in movies and TV shows and actually never knew it was in San Francisco. 

I had to come here. A silent voice was calling for me to come visit. It was as if the women statues were sirens of the city calling out to me. Fortunately it wasn't to my demise but to my complete amazement. 

I want to put on a long flowing gown and run around like a the maiden of the woods. Hide behind pillars and watch people secretly and giggle at my own amusement. I want to pretend a Centaur is chasing me, that Centaur could be my own husband.

I want to take my first born child and ask for the blessing of the Gods of which call this urban temple home. 

If you're as whimsical as I am you will want to do the same and more. Maybe with out the flowing gown part if you're a guy.  

Instead walk around and take tons of pictures. Enjoy the day and the friendly smiles of everyone around. You can even bring your dog if you want to. 

Jealousy is not an attribute I have very often but to all the people who get to live around this gem, I am officially 100% Jealous of you.
author: Ivy R.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for a while now and I finally did. This is a nice place to take a stroll through. It's beautiful, clean and seems to be well maintained.

It's a wonderful place to sit on the grass and talk with friends or read a book with head phones on. You can also just admire the nature all around and the wonderful turtles, ducks and a variety of unique birds on the water.

I'm glad I was able to check this gem out, but the only thing that was not so great is the fact that saturdays get pretty packed. Today's visit was a bit over crowded and rushed, because there were 2 weddings taking place and just way too many people everywhere. 

Overall this place is nice and if your looking to take a quiet stroll I'd suggest you come here on a weekday.
author: V W.

description:
If you've been faithfully following my Yelps, you'd know I love love old time SF buildings!  This takes the cake!  I took some of my wedding photos here and I just love the Palace of Fine Arts. 

The grounds are beautifully well kept. There's also ducks, swans and turtles in the lagoon. A must see!
author: Wendy H.

description: There's a great Hunger Games exhibit here until September! Loved the costumes and interactive elements. The gift shop is better than most and has lots of katness goodies for the ultimate fan. I highly recommend the fire scarf and matching knee socks.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Roman/Greek-inspired architecture in the middle of SF? It's magnificent, beautiful, and a great spot to explore as a tourist, or even as a local new to SF. Even the homes in the vicinity of the Palace have really unique, interesting architecture. Each is vibrant and unique, so it makes for an interesting exploration point. 

It's packed with tourists, so probably best to go on a weekday if possible to avoid the huge tour buses of camera snap-happy tourists.
author: Ellie W.

description:
I love this place.

Came here with Jay M. for our anniversary and it was amazing. This place holds a lot of history not only for San Francisco, but also for both Jay M. and myself.

I proposed to her here.
author: Norbert M.

description:
How does one review such a place, anyway? Perhaps a haiku...

Palace of Fine Arts
What are ladies looking at?
Love spirals downwards

Hmm, maybe you should just look at the photos.
author: Mei B.

description:
A beautiful place to visit and to take pictures! 

The structures are a must see if your ever in the area. It is also a perfect place for a wedding, date, picnic etc!! so lovely!. 

I came here to take some pictures and of course there are a lot of people visiting so it made takings pictures a bit hard but over the place made the pictures look even better. There are really no words to describe this place and how amazing it is. 

A MUST SEE PLACE!!!

only one con: people should not smoke around this area since there are kids and other people around
author: Sheena T.

description: Beautiful place in the city to take pictures. My sister had her engagement photo shoot here and we took pics of her dog as well. It's a gorgeous backdrop and lots of variety. The arches are so unique and I love the color of the doors! I wish there was more going on here though. There's not much to do other than look at the scenery.  It's a very peaceful place - it would be nice to relax on a bench or on the grass here and read a book.  Although there are normally a steady number of visitors, I've never seen it crowded.  The bird poop in the lake can get a little pungent too.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Palace of Fine Arts is a great place to visit. The architecture is truly a work of art. I can just sit in the middle of the dome and stare up at it all day.

It's especially nice to visit at night.
author: Ann S.

description: I can't believe I haven't visited this place and I've lived in the city for 3 years now. It's one of my favorite attractions in the city. It's a great photo op and you can hangout by the lake and feed the swans.
author: Vika N.

description:
My jaw is still on the floor.

What an amazing piece of architecture, not the type of thing you expect to see in the states, but I am very glad it exists.

Wikipedia says: The Palace of Fine Arts in the Marina District of San Francisco, California, is a monumental structure originally constructed for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition in order to exhibit works of art presented there. One of only a few surviving structures from the Exposition, it is the only one still situated on its original site. It was rebuilt in 1965, and renovation of the lagoon, walkways, and a seismic retrofit were completed in early 2009.

But my first thought when I saw it was "Hey, that is where Nicholas Cage catches Sean Connery in the movie The Rock", it is pretty unmistakable and recognizable, I am sure you can pick out a few more movies that feature this magnificent structure.

It may not be original original materials, but it certainly is historic and beautiful and a must see for any tourist.  I am glad I was able to see it after renovations, such beauty they preserved/created/accented.

If I were a native of SF I would probably spend a lot of time here, just watching the swans in the lagoon and taking in the architecture.  

While walking back to our hotel we ran into some natives whose house looks directly at the PFA, how amazing would it be to wake up in the morning and see such a beautiful lagoon and monumental structure?!
author: Jasmine B.

description: To say this place is gorgeous would be an understatement! It's a must-see in SFO especially if you are a person who loves taking pictures. Everything around this masterpiece of a location is picturesque. I say Palace of Fine Arts would be the last stop to go to if one is on his/her SFO trip. There's not much to do here except to view and admire the beauty of the artsy structure and surroundings. It's a one stop place for some great pictures to cap off the entire trip. P.S. There are no restrooms here. One has to cross to the other side of the road where there is a mini park if he/she badly needs to go.
author: Patrizia R.

description:
The architectural variety of San Francisco prepares you to see a place like the Palace of Fine Arts, but it still takes your breath away when you stumble upon it, in the tradition of Bernini/Borromini and the original "finding" of St. Peter's while wandering through that part of Rome (before Mussolini bulldozed that neighborhood and made the street that takes away that surprise).

Walk around, enjoy, and sit in silence.  Best way to enjoy this place.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Absolutely beautiful :) If there's one place besides the GG bridge you must go to in the bay, it is the Palace of Fine Arts!

Tips:

- Go for a stroll around the Palace and be on the lookout for the adorable family of swans! (Went there 6.2.12 and saw 6 baby ducklings hanging out with their papa swan and mama swan... SO CUTE!)

- Bring a jacket. When you're under the dome, it gets crazyyy windy.

- Bathrooms are located around the corner in the Exploratorium.

- Parking is a hassle :( Took at least 30 minutes of circling around to find a spot. Bring your patience or take public transportation instead!
author: Emily C.

description: Truly breathtaking. Bigger than it appears. Peaceful a magnificent piece of architecture. When in San Francisco it is a must see. The cohesion of the building and nature is a perfect balance. My favorite part was the whole place is every single piece of the building.
author: Richard M.

description:
A must stop for all tourists. Built for the Worls's fair in 1929, it's like it fell out of Ancient Rome. 

Tip: bring a jacket, even in Summer!  

Simply awesome park setting. Lots of photo opportunities. Lots of flowers and lake views. The rotunda is amazingly high. Do not skip this spot. Rent a bike or take a quick cab from Fisherman's wharf.
author: Robert C.

description:
after making my first visit to the landmark, I now understand why couples decide to have their weddings at this location. its absolutely stunning. the landmark is incredibly big and is surrounded by a little pond and great walk ways.my boyfriend and I had the chance to walk around during a warm thursday afternoon. 

personally, I don't think it is worth driving out to see. maybe if you were to pack a picnic and bring a blanket, it would be worth it; there is plenty of grass to go around. but, don't drive out of your way to come by. theres not much to do other than walk around for about ten to fifteen minutes.
author: Allyssa P.

description: For some reason the new management of the Innovation Hangar thinks it's cute to play 'closing time' every day at 5pm. What fresh hell is that? It is not cute. This is not a dive bar, it's an amazing venue. Please stop trashing it up with your bad taste in music.
author: Renée D.

description:
Picture perfect.

I can agree with others that this place is picture perfect. After all, when I went there was a wedding photo shoot taking place. Architecture + Nature + Water pool =great place for a photo shoot. 

My friends and I came here during a summer, while I was practically on my death bed from the flu. (I know terrible. A vacay and sick.) Despite my runny nose and sore throat, I took my tea furnace and Tylenol Flu and frolicked around this place. I strolled by and admired the big dome and tall roman columns that made me feel like a midget. I saw the swans swim and admired the beautiful colors of the trees and flowers. I was at complete awe at how they reflected beautifully against the water. And if my flu wasn't so terrible, I would have felt at complete peace, succumbed by mother nature's beauty. 

I'll definite return to this place in good health some day. And I highly recommend you do the same, especially the latter.
author: Marthie D.

description:
I was here in 2008 and stumbled upon it on accident, spent the afternoon there. I came back in 2014 and now knew i was in the Presidio and this was the Palace of Fine Arts. 
Very beautiful scenery! Must be super popular since there were about 6 wedding photos and 2 Quincianeras photo shoots being held at the same time. A wedding was about to happen under the palace dome. Beautiful i'm sure!
The swans and ducks are beautiful. 
Perfect place to stroll and have a picnic.
author: Harlow H.

description: I like to come here a lot. It's very good place to think and relax. This place is beautiful all the time, doing the days and nights, week days or weekends .
author: Mikhail M.

description: Only seen in movies: well not for us! my brother had his wedding ceremony here, under the rotunda.  Beautiful and elegant.  Just like a fairytale wedding.  The photographer took some amazing shots of him and his new bride and also with the wedding party.  This place is a must see 4 everyone!
author: Remie M.

description:
I'm from San Jose, but I've never managed to hit this place until today. It was definitely worth the wait because I was blessed was awesome sunny weather. It's a really nice Greek-inspired piece of architecture, complemented by a splendid lake full of gulls and containing a few swans.

Interesting anecdote: as with most landmarks in SF, there's a lot of houses nearby, and I was telling my friend that looked pretty nice. We started guessing at the house values, and we were thinking they they were around $500k-600k. A quick interwebs search later and we found out that they were million dollar homes. Dang. I guess you get (to view) what you pay for, right?
author: Chris V.

description: Great for pictures, but nothing else to do. It's nice to walk around and read some of the informational boards. Very good for Instagram posts :p it's nice but definitely a one time visit or to bring friends who are visiting from out of town. Not much to do around here as its surrounded by houses. It's very close to the GGB, so stop there as well
author: Jeanne K.

description: Great attraction for all ages. It was build in 1915 but still looks amazingly pretty. Its a hidden gem which I missed for so many years I have been in California. Try to reach when there is sun and then walk around until they turn on the lights after sunset. Looks gorgeous during both times. Note that there are no restrooms near by. For parking , there are spots around the structure which we luckily got last night(sunday night).
author: Manoj N.

description:
Built in 1915  for the Panama-Pacific Exposition, the Palace of Fine Arts is an amazing piece of architecture and monument.  This sort of thing is the reason people go to Europe, to stand and marvel at human triumph and ingenuity.  
Well, if your budget only allows you to go to San Francisco and not Paris or Rome, the Palace of Fine Arts will scratch the itch of culture, class and grandeur.
Honestly, if you live in the Bay Area, go see it.  If you are going to the Bay Area for vacation, business, or whatever, GO SEE IT.  It's absolutely amazing.  There is so much detail, and artistic expression in this monument and public space that it is daunting to try to articulate it in words.
author: Nate R.

description: The palace exterior is gorgeous to take pictures and walk around. We took a short walk around the grounds. I wish i could have gone inside for a visit but didn't have the time and wasn't sure if that was even an option. It is worth visiting just to see the exterior though!
author: Vanessa M.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is a monumental structure originally constructed for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition to exhibit works of art presented there. One of only a few surviving structures from the Exposition, it is the only one still situated on its original site. It was rebuilt in 1965, and renovation of the lagoon, walkways, and a seismic retrofit were completed in early 2009.

It's a popular attraction for me and others and is one of the key landmarks that I look for when I'm in or near San Francisco by land or water. The Palace is also on the top of my bring the tourists list, although I prefer walking here as part of a larger pedestrian tour of the City. And with lunch or dinner in the Marina. 

I love walking around and especially if there's a wedding party on the grounds. I also enjoy watching the swans and ducks, meandering around the columns, gazing up at the dome, relaxing in the park, and counting my blessings for being able to live in the Bay Area.
author: Eric B.

description:
I came here on a day in which it was super cloudy and overcast (70% of the weather in SF is always like this) though I didn't let the weather stop me from the breathtaking scenery that was the Palace of Fine Arts. 

I'm not too big on architecture. I like shiny things and things that move. However, the buildings looked super coooooooooooool and artsy. Pretty water, scenery, and a 6 foot Asian guy by your side. A dream come true.
author: Justin Y.

description:
What more can you say about the Palace of Fine Arts that hasn't already been said? The place is one of the most beautiful landmarks in SF. If you've been, come again. If you haven't visited,  you won't be disappointed. The intimate theater is clean and there really isn't a bad seat in the house.  I am enjoying our fourth row center seats :) 

Today we are here seeing the Smuin Ballet (I'll review the Smuin later.)   I'm on a double date with my friend. Our two 8 year old son's are escorting us out for an afternoon of culture in the city.  So I may be looking at the place through rose colored glasses.
author: Cyd K.

description: What a cool place! My friend wanted to stop here after studying about the place in her art/architecture class. It's actually a very very nice park! We picked a perfect day when the temperature was great and the sun was shining. Lots of folks were exploring the dome, walls, and walkway around the pond. Some people brought their lunches to enjoy in the grass or benches and there were a few people taking advantage of the photo opportunities including a gal celebrating her 15th birthday, a fashion model, and a bride. It was very picturesque. I highly recommend this stop in San Francisco!
author: Jen V.

description: A great place to walk around in the day or night time. I would suggest later in the evening where there is less crowds and the lighting is amazing. Great photo opportunity as well.
author: Jay R.

description:
Okay, so I've never actually been inside the Palace of Fine Arts. But, Wow.

Wow.

The outside is absolutely beautiful. Amazing pond with beautiful swans. Giant columns with lovely architecture. I might just move to San Francisco just so I can frequently indulge in its beauty.

My friend and I came here and had a ball sitting on a bench and talking about life. We acted like children and played hide and seek. We jumped and posed while taking pictures in every-which direction. Options of things to do here are endless.
author: Emily T.

description: If you're a tourist and wants to explore San Francisco, I highly recommend you to visit this place. It's a great photo backdrop for your Facebook profile picture and even for your instagram. No filter needed. I came here on a lovely Friday evening and there was only a couple of people there. I highly recommend people to come during the odd hours because if you come on a busy day, you will have so many random people in your pictures.  Oh yeah, I didn't know that this was just a hollow dome. I thought it was museum haha.
author: Tammy L.

description:
This is THE place to:
~take tourists
~eat lunch after going to the Exploratorium for a field trip
~take wedding pics
author: Kylie L.

description:
I didn't even know about this place until I watched the movie Vertigo a few years ago and noticed it during one of the scenes. After the movie I asked, "I wonder where that scene was shot?" 

Seeing this in person during a recent San Francisco trip repeatedly made me say, "Wow!" The architecture is stunning! You can tell that every detail was thought about, that making it beautiful was a priority. 

You'll feel compelled to look up and down and all around, and please do. There's something interesting in every corner, the ceiling of the dome is incredible, the columns are magnificent, the little lake, trees and other plants add to the peaceful atmosphere, and I could go on forever. 

Honestly, if someone were to ask me to sit here for hours, I really think I could. I'd contemplate life, read, continuously get up and take it all in, draw something, or sing a song.  Basically I'd be happy doing anything because this is the kind of place that grabs your attention and makes you want to stay.

It's exquisiteness is so impressive and inspiring, that it's easy to feel yourself get lost in it, in the best kind of way. 

Oh and did I mention that it's free? FREE. 

So many reasons to visit, and not a single reason not to.
author: Ursula N.

description:
This is a gorgeous place to come and see. The architecture is exquisite and i enjoyed myself immensely. A majority of the time there will be a lot of wedding, engagement, family and birthday photographers. The last time I went there was about 4 different weddings being photographed.

Its a huge place but  parking is quite limited. Your best bet on a crowded day is to find street or neighborhood parking.

A MUST SEE IF IN SF.

:)
author: Joanne H.

description: We stopped here for a potty stop and photo-op before going to the Golden Gate Bridge. Wish we could've explored further. They had some kind of automobile exhibit which looked really interesting. We have 3 little kids who would've really been jazzed to see everything but we just didnt have time. What I wanted to know was why all the statue ladies all had their backs to the wanderers on the ground. The architecture was gorgeous!
author: Corina J.

description: Beautiful buildings for pictures! The night lighting makes it look better. Enjoyed the mini walk
author: Jewels V.

description: Still one of the better venues in San Francisco for indie comedy, sports movies, fundraisers etc. Plenty of parking, short walk from Lombard.
author: Mike V.

description: My favorite POI in San Fran... Must See, and if the weather permits (which it usually does), plan a little picnic if you can.
author: Michelin K.

description:
Going for a walk....

A mindless one...
A peaceful one....
A timeless one...
A time to enjoy....
A time to appreciate...
A Palace of Fine Arts....

Say more....I dare not.....see for yourself.....
author: Alan L.

description: So beautiful! So glad we came across this on my trip to SF. Took a stroll through and got amazing pics
author: Amy J.

description: We love coming here while playing tour guide for friends and fam. Everyone gazes at the place for hours and its such a great photo opportunity. Take advantage of the location and cross the street to the beach. Beautiful ocean/bridge views there too! I wish we could find a plaque saying when and why this place was built. We found out while on a boat tour that it was built in the early 1900's in honor of the panama canala being finished. Random little tip but fun to know for any guests that ask while you're there. Sidebar: the exploratorium has moved to pier 15 so the bathrooms are closed. There is one across the stree at the beach. My one downside would be there is never enough parking.
author: Anastasia B.

description: Awesome venue. You can see from all seats, which are well-spaced out. There's not a ton of really close parking but plenty of free spaces within walking distance. There's a huge lobby area where you can get drinks or snacks before the show and bathrooms with many many stalls. We were in the almost furthest back row (U) for a stand-up comedian and still could see everything completely fine. Meaning you can get discount tix and not have to worry about having a crappy time!
author: Allison M.

description: Even though we live so close and we go constantly! This place never seizes to be just as beautiful as the first time you get to be there. I had an amazing time with my friend and My Jesse that I can't wait to go here for our wedding pictures! It's going to be an amazing place to take so many photos!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
breathless view! 

i don't know how to say it but it was speechless. it such a romantic and quiet and peaceful view with the pond or lake with the reflection of the building during day time and night time as well. 

i can already imagine myself coming here to have a tea party because its so beautiful i can just spend a whole day here have a picnic and have a tea party lol, 
while i was observing here, i seen many people come here and sit down on the lawn area and have lunch or just sun tan or just come here to walk their dogs. there were many cute dogs and all were just relaxing. i also saw a painter painting the building which was very unique and he must have been a big fan of this place.

It is hard to find parking, i was lucky to find a parking as soon i saw the person pulling out. the houses here are unique and are big and the area looks safe. 
This is a perfect scenery to have as a background for pictures. it is a place for artist to be creative as well.
author: Alex T.

description: This place is absolutely amazing. There is so much history going on here. The place is so beautiful you can actually have a picnic here on the grass. So relaxing and the architecture is just wonderful. You ll see a lot of people taking their wedding photos here. The most amazing thing that I saw was a swan !! I will be back to enjoy the scenery some more !
author: Cecilia T.

description:
I'll be honest. I have no idea what this place is for or what it's known for, but we were told by our friend's uncle that we needed to walk over to check it out. 

Boy I was so glad we did because this was such a beautiful structure! There's a trail that circles around the small lake there. This is such a picture perfect spot as we saw several people having photo shoots here. If I lived in SF, I would definitely consider having a wedding ceremony here!
author: Janice S.

description:
I felt like I was in another world.

To my future husband, whoever you may be: This is where you should propose to me if you want a yes!
author: Vicky L.

description: This place is gorgeous! Especially if you are into art. I have been here during the day and night time and both are worth coming for. The parking is free.
author: Lilly T.

description: This place is great. It really lets me feel inner peace.
author: Arthur Z.

description:
SF has so many unique and beautiful things and this place ranks high on that list. The sheer size of this structure is astounding, and I spent a good chunk of time craning my head up to see all the details. In the day time, you get to see the intricate carvings and natural color of the Palace, while at night, the whole thing is lit up. When my boyfriend and I were walking through the dome at night, there weren't many people there, it was quiet, and kind of eerie. People walking past the lights threw up huge shadows and it felt like we were intruding on Zeus's temple.

The Palace and the surrounding pond makes for beautiful pictures.
author: Helen D.

description:
the palace of fine arts is like one of those girls that looks really good with a lot of makeup on. it's absolutely beautiful from afar and amazingly photogenic. however, during daylight and upclose, the dirtyness, the chain link fences, and the patchiness all start to show (although still quite attractive).
it's fantastic for wedding photos, and that seems to be the primary use for the grounds (excluding actual theatre usage).
author: Xander C.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is absolutely Lovely. To find places where calamity meets serenity, well this is one! 

Honestly I'd NEVER take my Wedding photographs here, or the photo shoot for one of my Albums either. This is by fare one of the most common places people come to get photographs taken.

Yes the scenery is beautiful and serene. At nighttime it is almost haunting. I love coming here to meditate, and pray. When there aren't tourists invading this place like pigeons would at fisherman's wharf, otherwise it is quite lovely.

I love the Swans, ducks, turtles, and squirrels. The plants and flowers and grass. The fountains and Structures. I don't care too much for the filthy water or the raccoons that come in at night, or the tourists as I've already mentioned. But this is a very special place that i hold dear to my heart in SF.
author: Julian I.

description: Beautiful place to visit right off the 101 fwy. Great views! I'd recommend stopping by for a quick walk if you're passing through SF.  Parking is free and relatively easy to find.  Sure it's busy on the weekends but people come and go so you don't have to circle around too many times.  Very calming and quiet place to enjoy alone, with a special one or even with your family.
author: Linda C.

description:
When I was in high school, I had the pleasure to be able to perform here when I was apart of a harp group.  Yes, harp group.  Unique for sure.

Now fast forward 13 years later and I found myself here for a hip hop dance show.  I whined a bit when my fiance asked me to go . . .  but I found myself pleasantly surprised,

Parking is always terrible, I just know it will be. But the place is worth the frustration and long walk.  The grounds are beautiful!  Inside the staff kept everything really running smoothly and during the intermission the snacks and drink bar was on top of it.  They were quick and friendly!  The facility itself has a really nice design, the bathrooms were clean and I was overall very happy with my experience.
author: Sabrina A.

description: We were surprised at how huge this place is! Definitely worth taking a stroll along the waterfront, crossing over to the Palace and walking around the lake. Standing under the dome, you feel so in awe of your surroundings. Breathtakingly beautiful and worth checking out.
author: Heather A.

description:
This place makes you want to stop.  Stop in your tracks.  Stop time.  Stop in stillness.  Stop and take in the magnificence of the architecture and surrounding landscape.

My friend and I, the yogis that we are, could not resist dropping our bags and playing yoga postures in front of the lake.

The Palace of Fine Arts inspires.

Go!  You will not regret it.
author: Christine Y.

description: A lot of tourists come to the palace of fine arts every day, so it's important to arrive at the right time to avoid the crowds. I recommend early in the morning just after sunrise until about 830. After that you'll have to compete with folks from all over the world as well as weddings Quncinceras and all kinds of San Francisco special events. But this is a place not to be missed!
author: Michael G.

description: A great place to walk around and unwind. One of the most photographed sites in the city. Parking is accesible when I came by. A few minutes to Golden Gate Bridge and a few walks to yatch road . Don't forget your camera
author: Cecille T.

description: This place definitely leaves you breathless. huge, majestic and intimidating architecture are some of the words that define this place and make it in my opinion, a not to be missed point in san francisco.
author: Erik G.

description: Beautiful free stop in the very expensive city of San Fran. One of the nicest places to take a couple pictures. Not much else to do here except look at the amazing architecture.
author: Nicho D.

description:
Beautiful architecture. Great place for photos.
Definitely a place to see. Take a nice walk, enjoy nature, and say "Hi" to the ducks and geese.
author: Kathy W.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts Theater is probably the worst venue I've ever been to, and I might be including the dive bars. Here are all the things that went wrong at the Palace:

*No obvious signs directing us to the theater. This led to a wrong turn and a detour around the entire building before we found the entrance.

*Will Call line moved slowly. The woman had trouble finding people's tickets. When she got to us, she mis-remembered the name we'd given and spelled out for her. Meanwhile, someone else finally joined her and distributed two sets of tickets while we were getting ours. This problem is fixable--this probably wasn't her usual job and she couldn't adapt to change.

*The ticket-takers were also mysteriously slow. In our line, it looked like the scanner didn't properly register the tickets. So the woman closed down our line and everyone had to merge with the other one. We simply walked through the door during the ensuing confusion. This problem also is fixable.

There are several reasons why you wouldn't want to sit in a theater that lacks a center aisle. I don't think these problems are fixable.

*To reach the middle, you get to walk over 25 other patrons. We could have seated ourselves first if we'd been able to 1) find the theater entrance and 2) get our tickets and enter the theater, all within a reasonable amount of time. Instead, we got to walk over all 25 patrons (maybe there were a few empty seats). For my elderly parents, this seating arrangement is not relevant to their interests.

*At intermission, the ones in the middle are the last to make it to the restroom line. Which makes you more likely to be the last person to return to your seat, after all 25 other patrons have returned as well. I try not to need a restroom at shows, but sometimes it happens.

*(Speaking of which, the restroom accommodations are insufficient. There are a number of stalls, but the line was still super long. This might be a problem for theaters generally, so let's move on.)

*My date didn't make it through the restroom line until after the second half of the performance had begun. It's good that he (and everyone else) could return to his seat (albeit in the dark) during the performance, but obviously it was a disruption for everyone around him. I was worried that I wouldn't get to enjoy the performance with him. It turns out that dancing with the one who brought me accounts for a large portion of my enjoyment.

*If the theater happens to be overheated (which two out of the four Tenors who were performing that night mentioned while on stage, one while he was removing his tie to unbutton his shirt), then you'll love having all those extra bodies in the non-existent center aisle.

I'm going to guess that they filled the center aisle with seats for extra revenue. I predict that they will not use this revenue to install signs directing theater-goers to the entrance.

I couldn't appreciate the intimacy of this setting because it took an unnecessarily long time to get in, I felt trapped by people on all sides, needed to use the restroom at intermission, and couldn't tolerate the heat. Other reviewers liked the sound system, so maybe the sound people for The Tenors didn't use it properly.

I cannot recommend that anyone attend a performance here, even if it's only to say that they've been to the Palace of Fine Arts. I'm sure the staff are all lovely people. But someone designed this place to be patron-unfriendly. You can't really undo that after the fact.
author: Doombunny D.

description: So this is a crazy place. It's a giant structure near the water, that was created for the 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition. It isn't really used for much, sadly, but it is very cool to walk around. And it's right near the beach and the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Ross L.

description: Amazing views at the palace of fine arts! I was with a group of friends driving around the city looking for a spot to sit down and just chill. We ended up here and it was so chill! As we climbed up to the top of the arch we saw tons of glow sticks. About five minutes later we saw a flash mob of roller bladders with music and glow stick. It was so awesome to see! They have a meet up there every Friday and Rollerblade the city streets. This place is gorgeous and quite and experience. Hard to believe it has been around for so long. Great views and architecture.
author: Jess C.

description: A local land mark that you must visit when you're in SF. It's like it's from another time or culture. Bring your camera and practice your photography because there are plenty of subjects to capture. The size of the architecture is massive and filled with small details. Spend the time to admire each pillar and don't forget to enter the dome.
author: David P.

description: Another beautiful spot to visit in SF.  Take a stroll along the little lake, catch some shade behind the tall columns, or take a gazillion different pictures like my cousins and I did. We lucked out on no fog (saturday morning 6/29/13). Just lovely!
author: Christianne F.

description: A must see for all travelers!! I was lucky enough to visit the place on a perfect sunny day and I really enjoyed the beauty and craft of the palace... Rich in history and eye catching architecture this is a great spot to capture some great photos....
author: Miguel T.

description: One of the best photo spots in the city. The building itself, the lagoon around it, the houses in the surrounding neighborhoods, the city skyline in the distance, the ocean right across the street.
author: Gavin M.

description:
Beautiful! I only got a chance to take some quick pics, but pretty nonetheless. It'll still be here when I come back to SF, so I hope to, next time, walk around the inside and check out the beauty of this magnificent historical landmark.

It must be really nice to live around Marina/Cow Hollow. Getting to see the Palace of Fine Arts everyday would be amazing instead of looking at a picture of it on my computer ~50 miles away. Very lucky to those living in the area for sure!
author: Terri L.

description: I love bringing my family here for day trips and taking part of the history of San Francisco. As a photographer this is a great location with the perfect backdrop.
author: Dee R.

description: Amazingly beautiful architecture and landscape. Spectacular as a backdrop for photos day or evening. Great place to stroll around the buildings or pond and reflect on the 100 year old place. A must see in San Francisco.
author: Scott T.

description:
Frequently Asked Questions:

Q: Tracey W., what's your favorite place in the whole wide world?
A: The Palace of Fine Arts

Q: Tracey W., do you want to go to the Palace of Fine Arts for the 300th time?
A: Fuck yes.

Q: Can I get married at the Palace of Fine Arts?
A: Yes. Especially if you are marrying me.

Q: Should I propose to my girlfriend at the Palace of Fine Arts?
A: Yes. But make sure this place has deep significance in your relationship first by screwing her for the first time under one of the trees.

Q: Should I take 3 billion pictures of the Palace of Fine Arts?
A: No. There is no way you can take a better picture than the dude who took the picture that is on the 25 cent postcard you can buy at any store in SF. Buy it. 

Q: Should I ask a stranger to take a picture of me in front of the Palace of Fine Arts?
A: Yes, but make sure they actually know how to take a picture. Look for someone with a DSLR around their neck.

Q: What is the best time of day to come to the Palace of Fine Arts?
A: Every time of day is the best time of day to come here. It's fricking incredible. It's different from every angle in every different light. Put down your camera and just stroll here and gaze at its magnificence.

Q: Is it lame and touristy to go to the Palace of Fine Arts?
A: No, it's awesome and genius.

Q: What is there to do at the Palace of Fine Arts?
A: Take a walk. Bring a picnic. People watch. Feed the birds, which is actually probably frowned upon. Take 5 billion pictures for no reason. Sunbathe. Loathe the billionaires who live on this street. Flash mob.

Q: Is there parking?
A: Sometimes. During a weekday. There is some street parking, and also some diagonal spaces behind the Exploratorium, which also has bathrooms which are sometimes open.

Q: Does it cost money to go to the Palace of Fine Arts?
A: Not technically, but the pain you will feel at having to leave will be priceless. I didn't leave my heart in San Francisco, but I left it at the Palace of Fine Arts.
author: T. M.

description:
I went to see Demetri Martin perform here on his second night.  It was my first time there & I didn't really know what to expect for a comedy show...  

The Palace of Fine Arts is gorgeous at night - its seriously like a painting that you're able to walk into.  Trying to find the main entrance was a mission in itself.  We were seriously walking in circles... and the entrance we went through wasn't that "grand". 

The theater doesn't allow food or drinks inside so all must be finished in the main common area before entering.  The women's restroom was packed (with a line out the door almost).  The theater was so dark when we entered which made it difficult to locate our seats (probably our fault for coming in late - but we had to finish our drinks!).

We had great seats - right in the back center (in line w/ Demetri).  Great show, great location.
author: Allie P.

description: We have been to Palace of Fine Arts several times. Couple times for a fashion blog photo-shoot of my wife and once for the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. The palace is a gem of San Francisco and has great views at different hours a day. You will feel good after spending some time at the palace just by walking around, seeing the pond. It's a must visit if you are in San Francisco.
author: Jay M.

description: FELLOW ON THE WINGS OF LOVE FANS: I made it fam. Lol, this was my first time at the place! Great for photos and just being all touristy. We parked pretty far from the place because parking was just packed..we came around 11am on Friday morning. The water was pretty murky--so do not get too close that you might accidentally fall lol. There were a few swans and ducks, which made the place really nice. Awesome spot for photos, but warning: IT IS WINDY AF, so bring a jacket friends!!!
author: K D.

description:
I absolutely love visiting whenever I find myself in SF.

Have an hour or two to kill?  Head on over and people/swan watch.  

Oogle the architecture.  Kill your camera taking pictures.

It's a beautiful spot to spend a sunny Spring/Summer day!
author: Tiana M.

description:
The only time I'd been here I've walked around outside, it's clearly beautiful.  

Last weekend I saw Tracy Morgan perform there.  The venue feels tiny and it's easy to hear in there.  The lobby has a good assortment of beer, wine and snacks but it's cash only.  The parking was easy, but we did get there early.

Overall, a really neat venue.
author: Kristin G.

description:
This is where every guy should blind fold his girlfriend, drive her to the breathtaking dome structure at night, take off her blindfolds, let her soak in the lite up majesty of the place, get down on one knee and propose to her with the most heartfelt speech that would rival any Hollywood script proposal. 

It's just magical here. The architecture takes you to a romantic mood where things are still beautiful, sweet and innocent, and the beauty of ones surroundings is still important; unlike the concrete world we live in today interspersed with plants growing out of sidewalks.

I always feel like I'm transported to another world here, a world I wished was real.
author: Gigi A.

description: Sooo happy I stumbled on the Palace of Fine Arts on my bike ride from Sausalito to SF (a bike ride that I highly recommend doing!!!) while on one of the first dates with my now boyfriend :) We took a detour to stop here and took pictures. Absolutely beautiful! But unless you have a good camera, pictures might come out bad especially if you're in in the standing in the shadows.
author: Christine L.

description: The Palace of Fine Arts is so beautiful! I stumbled across it on my run from Fort Mason to Crissy Field in the early evening, and there weren't too many people around, so it was quiet and peaceful. The rotunda was stunning and reflected beautifully in the water. It was such a lovely surprise on my run!
author: Kelly R.

description: Gorgeous, abosolutely gorgeous!  That is all.
author: Deana M.

description: I can't believe we've been living in SF for over 6 months and just barely found out about this place. We didn't go inside, but this is THE perfect place for a picnic or to walk around a beautiful area on a nice day. Great photo ops!
author: Sofia M.

description: Definitely do not go out of your way to come here since there isn't much to see or do really, but my Blazing Saddles guided tour stopped off here on our way to the Golden Gate Bridge and I enjoyed most of the five minutes we spent here before getting bored. Saw some funny signs regarding the wildlife at least.
author: Rachel H.

description: Another great tourist attraction for photo ops & to walk around.
author: Jason F.

description:
Absolutely Breathtakingly Beautiful.

The undeniably Roman and Greek inspired architecture is an amazing site located in the heart of the vibrant and modern San Francisco. The gracious colonnades and the central rotunda are surrounded by a lagoon. The beautiful landscape only does more wonders to reflect the magnificent structure. The plant and animal lives give both serenity and liveliness to the lagoon and the palace itself. The images that conjures up in mind is no less wondrous than the palaces resided by the Greek and Roman gods.

Undoubtedly one of the most beautiful place to visit in San Francisco. The Exploratorium is also located adjacent to the Palace, an attraction representing science and technology - clear contrasts and coexists with the artistic and primal beauty of the palace. There is a free bus running from the foot of Golden gate bridge to these attractions.
author: Sharon Z.

description: It's a pretty place to go to take some pictures or just go for a walk. There's always people visiting so no feel of loneliness :)
author: Ritu K.

description: HOMG! This place definitely made the city of San Francisco steal my heart away! The architecture is amaaaazing! I'm at a loss for words trying to explain the beauty of this significant place. Definitely a must see as a tourist in the bay!
author: Maria T.

description: Beauuuutiful ~~ A wedding was taking place on the day I was there so some sections were blocked off, but I'm not surprised! A lot of people were taking engagement photos, landscape photos, any kind of photos! It's beautiful during the day and at night. There were picnic-ers, tourists, swans, and all things of happiness. Definitely a must-see place.
author: Tiffany T.

description: Absolutely love this place. So much to see and the view is romantic, I took my girlfriend (now wife) here and proposed. Everything is within walking distance, which really gives you every reason to go.
author: Pedro F.

description:
Great photo op place. 

Millions of weddings must be shot here. Wedding photographers flock this place and the couples move around the palace seeking the coveted wedding photo.

We, however, also went to those coveted photo op places, and took more crazy pics. The fun part is to follow the bride and groom and then do something totally wacky that blows their picture out of the water. Ours happen to be this annoying Viet couple that didn't know what they wanted, or how to pose. Their photographer was also bad. So we stepped in and did our thing while they watched from the sidelines.

The palace itself is beautiful. The steps are lined with wood, but they shake, so be careful climbing on the steps and don't fall into the hole! I love the old European architecture.
author: Debby L.

description:
I love the Palace of Fine Arts just as I love all other local landmarks that makes San Francisco the picturesque City that it is.  

I had the pleasure of joining my good buddy Johnny W. here during our tourist afternoon out after the Disney Museum on Valentine's Day. 

The last time I had visited the Palace of Fine Arts, the dome was under construction, so it was nice to finally revisit after all of the remodel was finished.  

*  This spot truly is one of the most beautiful spots in all of San Francisco.  But the purpose of my review of this spot isn't about the beauty of the spot which it obviously is, but in remembrance of the true  h i s t o r y  and importance of this grand structure.  

From the good majority of reviews of this spot, I have noticed a lack of knowledge of just why this structure was built in the first place.  

Just after the 1906 Earthquake, S.F was in total ruins.   So in order to reclaim its title of being the "Paris of the West" and a major metropolis, San Francisco put in its bid in 1910 to be the first of the century to host the 1915 World's Fair in honor of the opening of the Panama Canal.  

And boy did S.F. do an amazing job in proclaiming to the world just how strong we were in our ability to rise up out of the rubble from the 1906 Earthquake.

Throughout the World's Fair, the various other exhibits were housed in other European and "Dome" like structures throughout the Marina District toward Van Ness Ave.  But it was the Palace of Fine Arts that stood the test of time because of its beauty.  

I minus One Star off of this review because of the fact that I dislike the fact that there are no information placards dispersed around the Palace of Fine Arts to educate the public of the significance of why this structure was built.  Because of this, a part of San Francisco history is lost.
author: Cass J.

description:
One of the places that people from all over want to visit and you can't disagree with that - it's amazing, it's beautiful, it's unique, it's architecture is a genius's masterpiece!

One of the best calm places to walk in the evening or to enjoy of the incredible exhibitions out there.
author: Olga B.

description:
Two words: Breathtakingly beautiful.

Great park to picnic on a Sunday afternoon.
author: Patty G.

description: Probably my favorite place in SF. Tranquil, beautiful. Swans in the lake. Best escape in the city.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Absolutely beautiful architecture and surrounding scenery. There was a couple having their wedding pictures taken, which I'm sure is a regular occurrence there. We visited during late December so it wasn't very crowded and we got some great photos without fighting a crowd.

Be sure to visit the Exploratorium next door too.
author: Thai Y.

description: Such a divine place to visit! Love this place and definitely recommend it.
author: Yusra N.

description: An amazing place to enjoy theater art along with the natural beauty. Architectural design and beauty catches attention. Better place to select for any get together event and of course a right place for photogaraphy.
author: Aaron W.

description:
My gf from LA was visiting and we went according to a local friend recommendations.  This is a great place to take wedding photos.  There are high pillars, lots of greenery for outdoor wedding shoots.  We saw several wedding shoots being held when we explore round.  

I would also recommend family picnic or even a romantic date.  The weather was a little chilly and lots of people (hence it was July 4th weekend).  Remember to bring a light sweater and camera ready to start shooting.
author: Vivian H.

description: Great for picnics! Also the new paths under the columns are awesome!  They did a wonderful job of cleaning this place up.  It is spectacular at night with the columns lit  up by lights at night.  Beautiful during the day as well for a walk or a picnic.
author: Tyler B.

description: After all these years and countless visits, I am still amazed and in awe! It is so quiet and beautiful here. On can get lost for hours. This is a must see while in SF. Bring some food, some vino (or something in a flask), and explore. Everytime you visit, you are sure to find something new.  Beautiful!
author: Claudine S.

description: Very photogenic area to take photos.  Always peaceful to walk thru if there aren't a ton of tourists.  A little difficult to find parking on the streets.  I went on a Sunday so it was a bit easier to find parking.
author: Trynh K.

description: Okay this place is fantastic.  It's gorgeous, there's free parking, and you get some beautiful nature in the middle of a very busy city.  Take some photos while you're here.  I know several professional photographers were here while I stopped here as well.  I came here during the day with my dog.  Lots of beautiful wildlife including swans.  I want to come back next when it's dark and the dome is all lit up!
author: Cassandra A.

description:
Beautiful place!  

A must see in San Francisco.

So peaceful and serene.  All troubles can go away if for just a minute.  There's this movie that Robin Williams starred in called "what dreams may come".  This place reminds me of this movie.
author: Limzer L.

description:
This is definitely my favorite spot in SF! It isn't too crowded with tourists and it's an architectural beauty. There's a lake nearby with lots of swans and ducks, and it's a lovely place to take pictures.
The Exploratorium is next door, which is a definite plus.
author: Meghana S.

description:
This place is LOVELY!!!  I would love to live in one of those houses across the street from the Palace of Fine Arts.

I came here for a Kollaboration SF the other day, and the show was amazing. It was in the theatre of Palace of Fine Arts.

Great place to take pictures and take your friends who are out of town to see. Not much going on, but great architecture--and the best part is, IT IS FREE!
author: Jen H.

description:
I love the Palace of Fine Arts; such a great way to spend a couple hours strolling around on a date, having a picnic, taking photos etc. Unlike the marina a few blocks down, there are fewer dogs, (slightly) fewer tourists, and less wind. The pond provides a great backdrop for photos as well as the giant pillars that provide that artistic, rustic flare.

The benches and the grass are great for having a snack and some wine. Every so often you will see couples here taking wedding / engagement photos (rightfully so).
author: E E.

description:
This is a great park, very quiet and peaceful.  The buildings and structures are both awesome in its size and beauty.  A nice place to visit and relax.  

This place is so beautiful and romantic.  Many couples have their wedding pictures taken here.
author: Al E.

description: Probably one of the best sites to see in San Francisco. Love the scenery, love the atmosphere and you can't take a bad picture. The only reason I didn't give it a 5 star review is because of the traffi you have to deal with getting here. I live in the city and am still in awe every time I'm here but as the problem of over population, this place being another tourist trap and the never ending traffic jams, it can't get my vote as the perfect place. This is just my opinion. Was here for a comedy show recently and had a good experience.
author: Dave N.

description:
Parking can be difficult if the weather is nice but this is so totally worth a short stroll. As short as a few minutes, as long as an hour.

I often see people take their wedding/quinceanera/what-have-you) photos here because it makes for a lovely backdrop. The swans are cute too.

Romantic in both day and night.
author: Loli L.

description:
Back in college, I thought this place was the most utterly amazing and beautiful location ever.  Whether meandering around in the afternoon, early morning, or romantic early evening, it stays in my mind as an ethereal and magical place.  

This weekend, I dropped by again to show it to the boyfriend, and it was surprisingly different.  First off, it was fenced off, so we couldn't walk around the grounds.  Secondly, there were posts and trash and construction materials everywhere, which really took away from the mood of the place.  Lastly, it was covered in mass numbers of pigeons and seagulls.  It just looked kind of gross overall.  

So sad.
author: Lisa S.

description:
Very cool place to go & simply walk around admiring the architecture & remember that they shot a scene from The Rock there! 

Always thought this place looked a lot like Minas Tirith from the LOTR movies from about 10 yrs ago...
author: Tom T.

description:
Gorgeous! Great place to go on a sunny day. There are a lot of tourists here. 

I would give it 5 stars but I am sad that they are still doing construction which means you can't go under the dome, etc. 

I wouldn't mind just sitting under the sun reading a nice book.
author: Sarah C.

description: Breathtakingly gorgeous.  Made me feel like I was in a different country.  A must see when in San Francisco
author: anissa b.

description:
If you come to SF, you gotta come here.  

It's a really pretty place filled with picture taking opportunities and nice scenery.  

Nothing much more I can add but solidify it's high star rating.  

Have patience with the parking!
author: Dennis C.

description: A nice area to venture to before heading toward Crissy Field/Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Sarah V.

description:
I didn't appreciate the Palace of Fine Arts when I was a kid. Much like I expected the Golden Gate Bridge to be made of solid gold (why wouldn't it be?), I had hopes of actually seeing fine art within the arches of this structure.

Ah, young mind. It searcheth for the trees but doth not see thine forest.

Now, much older and, as I suspect, probably wiser, I recognize the Palace as a work of art in and of itself. I now appreciate the serene nature of its surroundings--calm waters, birds and picnicking couples--framed by columns and statues of an almost amber hue. 

It's as much a solace from the city as it is an escape for the mind.
author: Keane L.

description:
I have come here multiple times for the Ethnic Dance Festival a couple years in a row as well as my girlfriend's college graduation. It's a beautiful place and in the most beautiful location as well. There is a huge fountain, many grassy areas to sit and rest in, as well as lots of beautiful floral plants to see. 

The interior is not humongous as it may look from outside. But it's a pretty good size. Although the graduation was a little cluttered and unorganized. I thought the Ethnic Dance Festival looked great at this venue. Lighting and sound is excellent. And I had no complaints each time I returned to see the same presentation - 3 years in a row.
author: Natasha S.

description: In the evening, it's quiet. It was a clear night, the stars were shining brightly. Walking in such beautiful architecture in the evening, what an amazing sight. It seemed so surreal and romantic. Walk on the grounds and walk around the pillars. Stand in the center of the palace and make a 360 degree turn. Shout out "Happy New Year!" It echos back to you....
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description:
After so many years of remodeling, it is finished and LOOKS magnificent! Gone are most of the trees in front of the dome. New are the Palace of Fine Arts signs on both "entrance", signage about the Palace and it's history (read them before graffiti gets them!) and paved walkways (although a bit narrow especially if you have two way traffic). Parking is decent most days. 

This is one of my favorite places to take a relaxing walk. 

Feed the swans. 

Enjoy a lunch under the dome. 

Read a book under the trees 

Watch the seagulls bathe all day. 

Bask in the sun like the turtles. 

Get air brushed off of newlywed photos :P 

Listen for the ice cream bell!!! 
-- 
During the year you might also: 

Follow the ducklings grow. 

Look for caterpillars on the willow tree. 

Observe the Blue Herons and it's chicks in the trees. 

Enjoy the flowers blooming.
author: Peter L.

description:
I was in awe when I saw this place. I've seen it in almost every movie set in San Francisco. 

In the brochures I've seen, there's swans and it's magical, but when you get there- seagulls... ewe!

This place is perfect beside the seagulls and tourists- easy to get there using the city transit.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
This is my favorite place to bring visitors from out of town. The architecture is something you can't really find in America, and the sheer size of things makes you feel insignificant in a good way. Personally, I find this spot as a place to clear my mind and stare off into oblivion.

I came once during a rainy day and had the whole place to myself. That was magical. Too bad SF is always windy, so that made it slightly miserable. 

I also want to make it a point to come back at night. Pretty sure the lighting will make it just as spectacular as it is during the day.
author: Paul B.

description:
Gorgeous place to take pictures on a sunny day! Too bad its all fenced off; I remember a few years back when it was open to walk around, it was spectacular. 

Now that area has gone to the birds, literally fat off all the tourist's treats! One of the few places you'll see a swan just hanging out in the city and not too far from the Presidio Parrots. Its fun to watch the egrets(?) stalk fish! 

Lots of wedding photos are taken here too, so beware messing up someone's shot! : D

**EDIT 8/20/11** Renovations are completed! Go check this place out on a sunny day-- its worth it if only to accidentally photobomb wedding pictures.
author: Adora S.

description:
I ADORE this theater! I've been to several shows here and have had a great seat every time. Even the back seats feel pretty close to the action, although I hear it's better not to sit in the front row or extreme sides.

My halau (hula school) is performing this weekend and it's the first time I've been backstage. It's pretty roomy even for us 300 students, though we are pretty creative about the changing areas. 

If you can catch a show here, I highly recommend it.  Comfortably intimate and great acoustics.
author: Cathy K.

description: Palace of Fine Arts was one of the routes on our doggie walking cards, and I have to say I'm so glad that we picked that one! The views are pretty and it's a nice walk, however it did get pretty crowded, weddings, prom pictures, people walking their dogs just like us, kids playing with swans, so it's not a quiet-relaxing walk, more of a sightseeing and people watching
author: Anna P.

description: This was a pleasant surprise! I saw this from the yoda fountain and had to discover what it was.  Incredible!
author: Kimberly S.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts' architecture reminds me of my Italy trip (especially Rome). The big Roman Columns and picturesque views here are amazing! This is definitely one of SF's tourist attractions. After walking across the Golden Gate Bridge, we drove over to the Palace of Fine Arts. I was playing tour guide for the day. 

The whole place lights up at night. There were also two white swans floating in the lake. It was beautiful! We were still able to see some stars at night and a full moon. This is a great place during the day time too. You can pack a lunch and just sit on the grass (park area) to enjoy the view. Once again, if you don't like crowds you can avoid this place. This place can get pretty busy during the day. It's really romantic here at night. You can take a stroll with your beau/belle and enjoy the scenary. The parking here is much better in the evenings. 

I've been to the Palace of Fine Arts Theatre once to watch a circus show. I thought the show was pretty entertaining.

In the span of 10 years, I've been to the Exploratorium around 10 times (all for field trips with my class). The Exploratorium is really tiny and we're usually done exploring the place within 2-3 hours. I prefer the CA Academy of Sciences over the Exploratorium. 

Overall, if you haven't seen the Palace of Fine Arts it's definitely worth a trip. I would skip the Exploratorium but definitely come here to take some pictures...many brides and grooms come here for photos.
author: Melanie B.

description:
This is another one of my favorites. I have old pictures that I took  when I was 18. I came here a lot around that time. It wasn't undergoing renovation thus, no fences surrounded it. 

Beautiful, elegant, and featured in many movies set in San Francisco, like "The Bachelor." The ladies and the vases- ah, pleasant memories. Parking was much more difficult to attain, different than I remember. We finally got a makeshift spot, on a dirt hill slope, but we weren't the only ones though.

We walked the grounds, took our time, and saw people we passed on the Golden Gate Bridge- how funny, small world. There was an ice cream cart vendor. There were people snapping pics, walking, looking at the ducks and the swans. It was a nice stroll. 

I've only been here during the day, but many many times. The picture at night (pictured- not mine, another yelper's) is beautiful.
author: Margret C.

description:
Why does this place look so much better in photos? 

The family and I decided to hit up the City for Labor Day holiday and this had been on our Things To Do list for some time. The last time I was here was for the Pink Floyd laser light show (inside the auditorium). So, it's been many-many years!

There's plenty of free parking all around. So it was easy for us. We took the stroller out and began to roll...The weather was sunny and perfect, but the dust from the grounds were dry & dirty! We were amazed by the massive structure. It was awesome, but it looked really worn. Maybe a fresh coat of paint or a quick power wash could bring it back to life! The pond was beautiful, but again, maybe a fresh rain storm or a cleaning would have made it look better.

Anyways, like Sharon T said, great place for people watching and/or act like a wannabe professional photographer. hehehe! 

I love how our photos came out! What a nice day with the family in sunny San Francisco!
author: Ron S.

description:
BEAUTIFUL!  I cannot reiterate that enough.  Bring some nice music to listen to, while walking around.  Great for a picnic.  
I heard that everything you would want to see in San Francisco was within a mile, so it is a great walking city.  True that it is a great walking city...beautiful & fun...but this was 4 miles from the financial district!  I had to call for a taxi back, because I ran out of time...& I ended up running to get there!  Also, there are no taxis around...so is you want one, it does require a call.
author: Chelsea V.

description:
I came here maybe 8 years ago to watch the SF Hip Hop Dance Fest and I vaguely remember coming here as a child for some event as well.  More recently, I was here yesterday for the R16 North America BBoy Championship.  Tickets were easy to purchase online and it was assigned seating so we didn't have to worry about not having anywhere to sit if we arrived late.

There is only one bathroom each for men and women, but there were a ton of stalls in the women's bathroom, so even though it was a long line (as usual), it went fairly quickly.

The theater itself is fairly old, so it's a bit musty, but it serves its purpose.  There isn't a center aisle in the theater, so you have to step over a lot of people to get to your seat.  Luckily, the theater is set up as stadium seating so you don't have to worry about an extremely tall person sitting in front of you and blocking your view.  And the rows are far enough apart that you don't have to step on anyone's toes when going in and out of the rows.  

We sat in Row N Seats 43, 45, 47, which were almost dead center.  The view was great.  I think this is another one of those theaters where the view is great wherever you sit.

They do have a parking lot, which they share with the Exploratorium.  It was packed when we got there, so we had to troll the neighborhood looking for a spot.  The Marina is not the easiest place to find parking, but we managed to find a (tight) spot within 5 minutes of leaving the parking lot and A did an awesomey awesome job of getting his car in there.

Good place for a show and not a bad seat in the house!
author: Kris L.

description:
Simply breathtaking
Majestic, tranquil and well
Worth photo bombing
author: ReviewHaiku F.

description: I like walking around this place and seeing all the beautiful views. The little lake is nice to watch the turtles swimming around. It took them a while to restore the main building, but it is worth the wait. Amazing.
author: Melissa M.

description: One of the most beautiful, picturesque spots in San Francisco.  This is a must-visit if you're in town.  Peaceful, relaxing and expansive.  Perfect location for photos or just eating lunch on the pond.
author: Ashley K.

description: This is just one of the most beautiful structures in SF and that's saying a lot because there are a ton of beautiful structures in SF. There are some ponds there that are home to many fish and birds and lots of pigeons to feed of course. It is so beautiful to look at coming off the bridge at sunset. It is just breathtaking. It's also beautiful at night all light up. The Exploritorium used to be there too, but they moved it. It still is a great park to go to walk and feed the pigeons and relax. I would definitely stop by there real quick just to check it out if you are touring The City. It's really a must see and it can be done quickly. I mentioned the Exploritorium. That is a place you have to go to as well, but that one will take several hours because it's kind of a science museum and it's awesome!
author: Liz C.

description: A quiet escape for San Fran dwellers - located in the nice Marina area, this place doesn't get much tourist crowd compared to others. The place is beautiful for some night photography -- with lights glowing and showcasing the pillars in the dark, it's a perfect hangout spot for say, 20mins. Recommend doing "off the grid" on Friday nights and walk here (a little long walk) to enjoy the place.
author: Ram A.

description: One of my favs in SF.  I must visit.   It was used in "the Rock" and "Vertigo" and so is relatively famous.  Trust me, you will be shocked at how beautiful it is.
author: Michael E.

description:
I am writing this review to alert people who would visit the palace of fine arts by car. 

On October 13, my car was broken in at the parking lot of the palace of fine arts. This parking lot was on the left of the Bay street when you get off from Richardson Avenue. On the scene, there were multiple car burglaries that presumably happened at around the same time. 

There was a constant people flow at the parking lot to and from the palace of fine arts. So it was hard to imagine those criminals would flagrantly break in visitors' cars.

In fact, when I parked my car in the afternoon of that day, I saw broken glasses in the parking lot. I was stupid enough not to be alarmed by that. This suggests that the criminals have committed car burglaries repeatedly at the same location on the same day. 

Researching such cases online, I found that the northern station of the SFPD has reported an increase of car burglaries in and around the palace of fine arts. They managed to make some arrests but obviously they have much more to arrest.

Given that such burglaries have repeatedly happened in and around the palace of fine arts, I also believe that the palace of fine arts management is responsible by not alarming visitors about such ongoing crimes. 

In the end, I just want to alert all visitors who come by car about the ongoing crimes, be sure that you don't leave any valuables in your car under any circumstances, and avoid traveling to the palace by car if possible.
author: H C.

description: Always enjoy walking around the pond here.  Still have never figured out why the water is oddly blue-green or where all of the brides come from but it's beautiful and oddly fitting in this spot, even though it's a mock greco-roman structure.  It's remarkably peaceful.
author: EE S.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is definitely a tourist hot spot, but it's also packed with locals who want to take in the view of the beauty of the place!

It's breathtaking!
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
I love coming here at night with friends for a relax - wandering, sitting, walking along the water.  The grounds are so beautiful - good spot for photography practice too!  Bring your tripod for night shots.

I envy the people who live in those homes across the street!
author: Jen G.

description: One of my favorite places in the city. It's beautiful, idyllic, and pleasant despite being super touristy. Plus you get to photobomb all the weddings and quincereas there :-)
author: Rowena L.
