description: The City (and life) can be overwhelming at times.  And then you come here, and that all dissipates.  Standing outside beneath the grandiose archways and dome, looking onto the lake, you can't help but be present, and still.  Quite possibly my favorite place in this great City!
author: Gev M.

description:
Nice day or night.

Daytime it'll be busy with tourists and locals

Nighttime it'll be less busy.

Romantic either day or night.
author: qirk z.

description:
Transcendent Man ... a film about the life and ideas of Ray Kurzweil.

We went to The Palace of Fine Arts to see Ray Kurzweil.  It was fascinating and I was happy to be there ... in that moment.

Then the next week, we saw him on the Daily Show.  He gets around ... and he is very interesting indeed.

Being at The Palace of Fine Arts Theatre and having access to an icon like Ray K. was a monumental experience and a simple understated one at  the same time.  

I love San Francisco and all of the great experiences it has to offer!  One of my favorite other times I went to the Palace of The Fine Arts was for a very cool Yelp Elite event a few years ago ... back when I had more time to attend Yelp Elite events.  That was Sooooooo much fun and I got to meet some amazing people.  I will never forget that night full of yummy cupcakes and awesome cocktails ...  Yelp sure knows how to throw a Yelpingly-great 5-star p-a-r-t-y-!
author: Lee R.

description: This place is so breathtakingly beautiful, I couldn't even carry on a conversation when we were walking through it. I really can't say much else other than you NEED to see this in person and explore a bit--it's so peaceful and relaxing. I want to set aside time particularly for a walk through here the next time I'm in town, just so I can take it all in again and find new things to love.
author: Kaitlin D.

description:
Magnificent!

Based on the name, I didn't know what to expect, but I fell in love with this place as soon as I saw it. If you an architecture lover, you must see it! It's magnificent! And you don't have to travel to Europe to see a great architecture. Surroundings are very peaceful and great for meditation. Beautiful swans on the water adding to the classic touch of the Palace park.Cannot wait to visit that place again, next time at night.
author: Yelena Z.

description: Awesome little stop before the exploratorium, which is on the same block. There is a beautiful lake too
author: Angela L.

description:
love this place so pretty!! sf landmark for sure, a tourist must visit! The dome is from the worlds fair, and the ambiance is just great. There is a pond where you can feed the ducks and where many people take pictures. sf landmark/gem for sure!

def a must visit!!
author: Diane S.

description: I recommend going at night when the lights are on. Simply breathtaking. Standing in the center of the Palace of Fine Arts looking up, definitely makes you feel really small.
author: Tommy H.

description:
The Other Cafe' 30th Reunion Show 
To Benefit KQED Public Media

I can see why Ronald Reagan was such a true believer in Depends. Last night I came close to wetting myself on more than a few occasions during this almost 6 hour comedy performance.

Host Lineup:
Bob Sarlatte, the voice of the 49'ers, an awesome host and funnier than sh*t. Proof positive that a hometown boy can do better than good.

Bobby Slayton, crazy and messed up in ways that any shrink would see a lifetime payday with issues upon issues. I loved Bobby and his brand of humor.

Paula Poundstone, starting off by talking about the possible drinking problem she had in the past. I have to say that I was most impressed with her as the host and IMHP, she was the best host, sorry guys, but sometimes the best man for the job is a woman. Paula is so freaking talented and can do improv better than any other on stage this night. She went into a dialog with someone from the audience that quickly had everyone in stitches and continues to use and abuse the technical writer who was (un)lucky enough to be chosen. I'm sure that his entire career will be based on this evening. It's all about standards, some were set this evening.

Highlights:
Dana Carvey telling stories about his kids and what it's like trying to reason with teenagers. Considering that his wife of 23 years recently died of breast cancer and he's up doing his act, its was just a poignant moment of truths and irony. Hats off to you Dana!

Some Black Woman, sorry don't remember your name, but I do remember how you mastered a poem, off the cuff, entirely relevant and thought provoking on the subject of France. You were so incredible, smart, quick and full of wit. I wish you were my neighbor. I would bring your freshly baked cookies every sunday afternoon.

Kevin Pollack with his impression of Christopher Walken. Hilarious.

Bobcat Goldwaith, you were my favorite of the night with your poo and the funniest thing in your life. I wont be able to hear a siren without thinking of you and if I ever have the same true life adventure I'll hope for the same special passengers as you. Your ability to set up a story, lead us down the path, take a quick turn, come back, take three steps, make a u-turn and deliver a satisfied ending. 

My ribs are still sore and I'm jonesing for more.

Great performance from everyone! Thanks for being who you are.

Paula, I'll see you when you're back in town.
author: Steve S.

description:
World class.

Built for the 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition world fair. Restructured and redone through the years.

While the infrastructure might have evolved over time the captivating atmosphere has unchanged.

Relax on the grass. Gaze off into the water, Marvel at the structures.

Whatever you do you'll find yourself consumed by beauty and peacefulness. And you'll be thinking to yourself just how lucky you are to call San Francisco home.
author: Jason B.

description: This is a great place to kill an hour when touring the city. It is a beautiful setting. I always stop here on bike rides to the bridge.
author: Danny B.

description:
************************** 541 ****************************

        Historical beautiful theatre, I usually come here for plays, ballets, and other performances. My nieces love it here too. Except the driving here is a drag!
author: Manda Bear B.

description: MY SUPER DUPER FAVORITE PLACE IN SF!  The architecture is the best and a great place to take photos.  I love you long time, Palce of Fine Arts.
author: Criselle O.

description: What an awesome monument in the Marina district.  The greco design, and pond make for a fantastic little walk.
author: Alf O.

description:
The setting here is something right out of a movie. Grand arches. Sun setting over the lake. Swans floundering in the water while smaller ducks graces by. 

Okay okay I'm not nearly as poetic as the other Yelpers but you get the point. PoFA is drop-dead gorgeous and stunningly beautiful. You tend to forget you're still in San Francisco and that you're away from the craziness of the City. It's awesomely tranquil and perfect for those moments when you need to life to just ... slow down.

Whether you're showing out-of-towners around, or you're looking to take your significant other out on that picture-perfect first date (picnic anyone?), the Palace of Fine Arts is the place for you.

Seriously. Stop and stare.
author: Tom P.

description: Beautiful architecture!!! Ugly parking lot!!! it's like Beauty and the Beast!  Parking lot is dirty and small, but once you see the building and cute swans, you'll forget all about the ugly parking lot.  A Great place to take photos and watch birds~
author: Chelsea C.

description:
One of my favorite places in the city.

Though there are times when this place is over crowded with tourists, there are also times when you can catch yourself alone.

Place is particularly great at night and early mornings.

The city has done a great job of maintaining this place.
author: Ayall S.

description: Very, very pretty in the morning or at night. Come here if you got nothing to do or if you want to be inspired by all the big houses around the area and make you work harder the day after!
author: John H.

description: It's gorgeous.  On a perfect SF day, nothing is better than strolling the grounds.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
This is one of those true San Franciscan vistas. You can't really blame all of the people taking their wedding pictures here or using it as backgrounds for talking heads in documentaries. 

It's gorgeous, and it injects cachet into just about every image in which it appears. Amusingly, a group of Asian tourists asked a bride and groom if they could pose with them for a photo and the couple agreed, as though they were costumed characters at Disneyland. 

Just please, do us all a favor and don't yell, "HELLLOOOOO!!" or "ECHOOOOOO!!" when you're under the dome. 

Oh, and the swans - they can be vicious critters. Beautiful, but deadly.
author: Christine A.

description:
A popular photo spot hanging off the eastern edge of  the Presidio, the Palace of Fine Arts was constructed as a major exhibition area for the 1915 world's fair-esque expo called the Panama-Pacific International Exhibition.  What does that mean to you visiting here?  Not much if you don't care about history.  Don't worry though; there's plenty to see and enjoy no matter how much you hate our collective past.

It is pretty easy to get here although you might have trouble finding parking in the Marina area.  I've always parked within Presidio and walked or taken the free shuttle the makes loops around the whole park.  Easy peasy, livin' greasy.

It's a great place to hang out, read, shoot photos or role-play Spartacus. Unsurprisingly there tends to be lots of wedding groups at prime times, and there are a lot of ducks. Oh, and two swans. One swan didn't seem to like the ice cream a bride-to-be was trying to feed it.  Next time try some poppy seed bread, or some other dry carb that will make the bird dependent on humans for survival instead.  Finally, those with a 3rd grade sense of humor (I'm referring to myself) will have minutes of joy taking imaginative photos using the fountain as a photo prop.
author: Cory M.

description:
When in San Francisco as a newbie or with a newbie to The City, this place is definitely a must! 

Anybody that has even a mediocre love of art, architecture, or simply enjoys a nice view will have a great time here. For those that want to know a little bit of it's history there are a few placards in place to enlighten you; but personally I go to Wikipedia for some touristy information. 

As in most places in SF, finding a parking space can be a monumental feat! Drive safe and bring your smallest car!
author: Marvin V.

description: This beautiful structure feels like you've stepped back in time around the turn of the century.  My parents and I were there earlier today -- a rainy day -- and the lagoon, the high pillars, the overall grandeur of the place was amazing.  During a nice sunny day, this would be a perfect place to sit and relax.
author: Mel G.

description:
B E A U T I F U L.

There's not much more to say but that.  Visit and you will see what I mean.
author: Pia V.

description:
What a BEAUTIFUL day to wander the Palace of Fine Arts.

The Exploritorium was packed so we opted to simply wander the gardens.  Very lovely.  Makes you feel that you're really somewhere else.

The only downside is that it's hard to find a cab in the area.
author: Tony S.

description: Gorgeous.  After walking around the city all day playing tourist we almost opted out of this landmark. I'm happy we ended up going as it was worth it.  There was a wedding going on and several wedding photo shoots but who wouldn't with a view and atmosphere like that.   Will come again
author: Ashley P.

description:
I am very familiar with the Palace Theatre since I've been on the stage and have come to watch several performances here and I have to say, I am a fan.

Nearly every seat has a great view! The only reason why I don't give it a full 5 stars is because I am not crazy about the entrance/ticket area/restrooms. For a theatre this nice, they should definitely put the money in to remodel this place. The entry area is very bland...and during intermission, it makes things quite boring when people are waiting 15-20 minutes inbetween the shows.
author: Veronica S.

description:
This place is so beautiful.  I've always wanted to go there and just walk around. 

I always see it when I'm driving and the building is so breathtaking. 

Had lunch in the Marina with the boyfriend and drove here- found street parking and walked around.  Probably spent less than an hour here just admiring all the animals, water, building. 

There were so many different types of birds in the water.  Also some turtles!

I'll want to go to The Exploratorium next time since its right next door.
author: Anya R.

description:
One of the best places to visit when going you're in The City. I love the architectural design and park. Great place to take photos.

Btw, parking can be tough..
author: Kaycie Y.

description:
One of my favorite places to take visitors in San Francisco is the Palace of Fine Art located in the Marina District.

It is a beautiful structure built in 1915 to celebrate the completion of the Panama Canal. It was the site location for Panama-Pacific International Exposition, a world's fair held in San Francisco in 1915.

In 1960, it was reconstructed and stands in its current splendor. Located at the Palace of Fine arts is a wonderful, interactive museum called the Exploratorium. It's a fantastic place to take kids and adults that are young at heart. You can learn about physics, human perception and art. 

In addition to the historical significance, it is also a popular site for meetings, cultural events and wedding photos.
author: Joyce H.

description:
Had heard great things and was looking forward to the visit, however due to construction, poor signage, and the awful weather in the Bay area my view of the Routunda was limited to 200 yards away on consecutive days.  

Browsing the list of events taking place during my 4 day stay I can't say anything was overly impressive, either.

Perhaps for a native the Palace would be a nice place to visit on a sunny day - whether to study, walk, enjoy a picnic - but for a tourist there just isn't much to see here in my personal opinion, especially given the awkward roads surrounding it and ongoing construction.
author: Michael U.

description:
SO BEAUTIFUL! Gorgeous. Spend your sunny days here people! 
This is such an overlooked gem of the city! Trust this.
author: Amanda S.

description: Five stars for being so pretty! lol For sure a "must see" when you are in SF. Parking of course is hard to find... we drove around for 20 minutes until we found parking. I suggest buy sandwich at a local deli and have a lunch picnic at the park.  I can't say anything else about this place you just have to see it.
author: Erica C.

description: such a beautiful place!
author: Maricel J.

description: Absolutely beautiful at night. If I am having a bad day, if I need to think, if I wanna just sit chill and not do anything but admire the water or a great scenery I come here. This place is beautiful from the outside looking in, and it is stunning lying under the dome just staring at the roof of it.
author: Wells Y.

description: The palace theater is a wonderful place to see a show. Very comfortable seats. Very clean and well maintained. But!!! Beware there is no parking facilities near. If you go to see a show you'll have to park in the streets. Almost impossible to find a parking spot.  Some very good shows are coming to the theater but because of the parking problems I'm not going there anymore.
author: Charles C.

description: Beautiful at a distance, but on closer inspection there is an awful lot of bird poop in and around the pond and the structure itself isn't all that exciting. Certainly worth a stroll by for a walking date or after you are done at the Exploratorium, but not in my top ten San Francisco sites...
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Gorgeous, gorgeous, gorgeous. 

I didn't know what to expect - I had hoped (from the name) that it would be some kind of art museum, but instead, right next to the Exploratorium I found the Palace of Fine Arts -- a collection of Greek-style ruins/architecture. 

You can walk through and take pictures or simply gaze and admire. it's a worthy site and very popular. While I was there, two couples were getting quinceanera pictures done and another couple was doing an engagement session. Dozens of people were walking dogs and dozens more were ambling about with their cameras clicking.

My husband and I took tons of photos and then grabbed a nearby bench and enjoyed some snacks. It's a great spot. I wouldn't go to SF just for the Palace of F.A., but it's definitely worth extending your trip.
author: Caitlin S.

description:
This is the place that locked San Francisco in my heart.  I always bring out of town visitors here when I give them a tour of San Francisco.  Don't you just love the random animals that live around the manmade lake?  The dome is the dopest and people usually give that "AHHHH!" or "WOOOOW" sound whenever they get a first glimpse at this.  This is also a popular place for people to take their wedding pictures.

I especially love taking pictures of the random dogwood trees and natural ecosystems that surround the lake.  Take note of random gophers popping in and out of the ground; the turtles forming a line, lifting one of their hind legs up to strike a pose for your picture; the hummingbird flying around the marsh plants; the koi; the swans...

(watch out for the pigeons though.  They like to flock around here because some visitors love to feed them.  I hate pigeons.. they're rats with wings.--don't you come near me with no damn pigeon!  Imma cut you!)

Overall, this is a beautiful, romantic, and picturesque setting, where you can bring your date and enjoy sucking face!
author: Grace M.

description: This is one of my favorite places to visit in San Francisco. It is a beautiful place to hang out, read a book, chat with your friends or bring your family here for a walk. People of all ages are sure to admire it's beauty. Ample free parking, you are free to take pictures and roam about. Of course no entry fees. There are three entrances and all have a magnificent view. There were swans and turtles in the pond, green lush grounds and the colossal Palace of fine arts make the whole scenery picture perfect. This landmark is not to be missed. Across the road (where the play ground is) you may find the restroom and a beautiful view of the Golden gate bridge ...it's rather a cute little spot to take pictures of the golden gate on one side and Alcatraz island on the other.
author: Ritika S.

description:
Besides really, really wanting to see Alcatraz I also wanted to go check out the Palace of Fine Arts.  I've seen it enough time in movies and TV shows that I wanted to see the Greek and Roman inspired architecture.  I trekked from Union Square all the way to the Marina via Cable Car and bus to get there.  I had my camera ready, battery fully charged and I get there and it's underfuckingconstruction and covered in scaffolding, a word I soon learned I could not pronounce.  Can you believe that?!?!  I can't!  I was fuming.  Once I calmed down, OK actually I never calmed down I just accepted the fact that I got punked.  

OK even underfuckingconstruction and covered in scaffolding I could see what a beautiful place it is.  And being the quintessential San Francisco tourist that I was I still took pictures of it in all it's fenced in underfuckingconstruction and covered in scaffolding glory.  However it did put me in a somewhat foul mood for a while, damn you Palace of Fine Arts for getting a face lift while I was in town.
author: Me H.

description:
My cousin was performing in a hula show here recently.  I've never been, so I was quite excited to attend the show.  I have a habit of not researching things, (unless it involves restaurants,) so I didn't know what to expect.  I didn't know how big this place was.  Honestly, I thought it was a museum.  Please don't make fun of me. hahaha.

We parked a few blocks away in a residential area and I was amazed at the entire neighborhood.  Everything was delightfully charismatic, even on a rainy day.  The homes in this neighborhood scream "old money."

Walking up to the theater, the landscape is gorgeous, the birds in the water, the dogs playing fetch, the people having picnics.  I could spend all day here.  Wow, I love it.

We sat about 5 rows away from the stage and not only was it a beautiful show, but the sound was great.  The seats were comfortable too.
author: Christine A.

description: This place is just hands down gorgeous.  The architecture is marvelous, and the whole area is so peaceful and nice.  On a sunny day, this is a great place to come and chill with a friend, lover, book, anything.  The weekends here are a little too crowded because of all the tourists from Asia and Europe that come around, but if you want to enjoy the sun here, come on a weekday when it's not so bustling.  There's always people taking wedding photos here, and my friend actually proposed to his fiancée here as well.
author: Liz W.

description:
This place is so gorgeous it makes me almost sick with jealousy. JK :) But really it is so much fun to walk around the columns and beneath the dome, especially with someone you love or even like. 

I've been there several times, but have never gone inside the Exploratorium. I'm sure it would be fun, but I never want to take away from time spent outside by the ponds and fountain and swans and ducks. 

When we went it was near sunset, so a little chilly, next time we'll go when it's a bit warmer so we can really relax while there. 

One note: It is really close to the Golden Gate bridge entrance on the SF side and it is free to walk the grounds. Don't miss out !!
author: Autumn H.

description: this place is just amazingggg
author: Pritika M.

description:
This is a gem in the city--a cove where you can come and relax and get away from the craziness of the city. When my roommate took me here today, I realized that this is EXACTLY why I moved to San Francisco. The art, the culture, the hidden gems are nothing like New York, Chicago, or any other big city in the US.

Great place to take a girlfriend, boyfriend, or anything in between. Here you get to stop, and enjoy life.
author: Chrissy H.

description: I love this place in the rain or the sun or just under the clouds.  It's a beautiful majesty that the City still has left and has not sold or decided to redesign.  May it always remain that way.
author: Sin F.

description:
Beautiful hidden gem of the city! Another place you must stop at if you're ever in San Francisco. The architecture is amazing. You really feel like you're in a movie. I would love to take my engagement pictures here.  Words cannot describe it! 

Very touristy though, it'd be awesome if this place was more hidden and quiet but oh well, great places cannot be a secret forever. GO! Take pictures!!! LOVE this place!
author: Sara N.

description:
O MY GOSH, I'm so in love....oh oh oh oh oh oh oh ...etc.

After the 7 year remodel (as I found out from a photographer there), it was a complete wipeout of what I remembered it to look like. Granted, I haven't gone for 4 years, I know that the additions were the pond in the back with the trail to walk around the building. PLUS, it was an 80 degree day in SF so what's more beautiful than that. There were tons of birds and geese in the water which made it more elegant as well. They did a great job of cleaning up the area for people to sit, lie down, and even eat and picnic on the grassy areas that overlooks this pond. I love that as you walk on the path, any spot is a great spot to take a picture. You can capture the water and the building in the background, along with nature itself! Going inside the dome is fun too to take good pictures of different points of views of structure. I also see people running and biking through this area, as well as wedding parties taking their pictures. 

Definitely cool to come here too because decades ago, my own parents took their wedding photos at this spot. How different it looked!!! (Maybe the quality of the camera since it was a long time ago :))

Even on this day that I visited, they were having a free meet and greet of Kina Granis, the famous YouTube singer. Great spot, Kina!

I spent almost 1 hour here just taking nice/random/goofy pictures which made for a great day. Something free, yet something memorable! Great spot to relax and enjoy...LIFE. PEACE. LOVE. THANKFULNESS.

I guess you're not suppose to feed the animals, but I saw some families tossing out bread. I think I'll try that next time. 

If you're single, maybe you can find some FINE people here.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
How was the Palace of Fine Arts you ask? I have no idea...it was closed. BUT the park was awesome!! Take a blanket and nap under the trees. If you don't feel like napping, there is plenty to look at including the pond, birds, and yes, the palace itself. If you enjoy people watching as much as I do then this will give you an excuse to plant yourself and do so. Baker Beach (the one under the golden gate) is a short stroll away when you're done messing around here.

Note: If you're using public transportation, bus 35 will pick you up from both near Caltrain or Union Square and drops you off a couple blocks away from the Palace. The bus ride takes a while, but it's a pretty sweet way to see the city.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I've always fantasized about getting married at this beautiful landmark. While that hasn't happened, I've been visiting the palace quite a bit w/the new love of my life. 
Over the past few years I've come here for picnics and such...but not as often for someone who lives three blocks away. 
Ever since I've adopted Nacho, we've been taking walks to the palace at least three days a week. Nacho loves to do his business there...Full of luscious grass and pigeons and ducks he can chase after...and each time I am there, I look up at the dome and imagine myself walking down the isle...with Nacho as my flower dog of course...
author: Mimi T.

description: Amazing.  Love the architecture.  Great place for pictures.  There is a little museum there.  Learned about the history of the place.  Didn't know about it so you learn something new all the time!  It was a little confusing to find the parking as there was construction going on.  Nice place to sit and relax also.
author: Mooki x.

description: For wedding venues, the Palace of Fine Arts tops all other venues for it's beauty, originality, and amazing architecture. It is incredibly gorgeous and the surrounding homes also have beautiful architecture. I would absolutely come back here and bring any visitors that want to see SF to a tour at the Palace.
author: Jackie H.

description: I recently was as the Palace of Fine Arts and the renovating is complete and this place officially went from pretty to gorgeous. Lovely footpaths and well kept lawns and gardens. This is still one of my most favorite places in The City.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
First time here.  Big wide theater with comfy cushioned seats and plenty of leg room.  Wow!  Much wider than it is deep.  Not really decorated at all, but when the lights go down, you appreciate the comfortable seating.  Fairly big lobby, bathrooms ok.  

They sell food and drink in the lobby, but don't allow it inside the theater.  Ushers do not pat search patrons as they enter the theater.  

Parking in the neighborhood is not impossible.  Entrance to the theater is on Lyon Street on the back side of the Palace of Fine Arts (the side NOT facing the lagoon) where Lyon Street curving toward Doyle Drive, about 150 feet from Lyon Street and Bay Street.
author: Doctor G.

description: I used to have a friend who lived in a house that had a direct a view of the Palace. Always looked at it from a distance. It's an amazingly unique and intriguing piece of architecture and even in the rain/mist, it's beauty shines through.
author: Kim N.

description: Randomly walked into this place while exploring the city. Definitely a nice place to take SF in if you're visiting town and the weather is nice. I didn't have a chance to explore the inside since I was short on time, but I could see this being a great place for pictures, etc.
author: Andrew E.

description: This place has some very beautiful outdoor areas with huge pseudo-roman arches.  Its a must see if you are in SF.  Overall you should just sit and relax and enjoy the place.  however there is not much beyond this so plan on an hour here.
author: Greg W.

description: Always impressive...
author: Kislev A.

description: I'm assuming you can actually go IN to the Palace of Fine Arts somewhere...but maybe not.  Maybe it's just the epic buildings.  In any case, if you can, I have yet to find the way...  At any rate, just look at the photos.  This architecture is gorgeous...and you'd never expect it in the middle of all houses in San Francisco.  You're guaranteed to see lots of photographers here.  It's a great place to get wedding shots done.
author: Brian B.

description: I can't describe this place into one word because it's so speechless with the beautiful view. Really OMG my heart is in SFO
author: Lanie S.

description: I come here at least 2-3 times a year for performances and functions. It's a nice space, but the bathroom situation is weird. The ladies' bathroom door just OPENS up into the main lobby.  Ick.
author: Lisa T.

description:
A gorgeous afternoon in the city by the bay.  It's rare to slow down and enjoy the landmarks of the city, but we did just that this weekend.  A lovely walk around the 'lake' area, buying ice cream from the cart, and sitting watching the world go by... all with this beautiful towering art before us.  The structure truly is amazingly beautiful.  I've been to a wedding here before, under the dome.  While beautiful, it was hard to hear everything, and the wind blew right through - so personally, I prefer a different venue.  But imagine the pictures you'd have with this place as the background?  You can't beat that.  

Sadly, some areas of the structure are fenced off for renovation.  I guess that's better than the talk of wanting to tear it down a few years ago.  If there's renovation going on, by all means, do it.  Don't take away great architecture!
author: Denise M.

description: I was amazed by the beautiful structures of the Palace of Fine Arts. It's reminiscent of visiting an old castle or structure over in Europe but is instead in the heart of San Francisco. The structures are filled with intricate stone statues and other artistic expressions. If you find yourself in San Francisco, visiting this place is a must!
author: Frank C.

description:
Absolutely gorgeous. We picnicked on the lawn around the pond and just enjoyed the majestic scenery. There are ducks and swans on the pond and plenty of shade and grass to lounge upon. 

We saw many brides and grooms show with professional photographers for their photos. It was adorable seeing them pose in front of the columns and pond. :)
author: Sharan S.

description:
What a breathtaking and beautiful place! It's like being in Europe without being in Europe (and paying a lot of money to go as well now!). I remember seeing a scene from Vertigo of this place and wanting to go.

I like lying in the grass and watch the swans swim idly in the lake. The architecture, especially the dome is magnificent. And the colors! The reflection of the pinkish palace in the water can't be beat. The Palace of Fine Arts is definitely worth checking out.

At sunset this place is even more gorgeous as they light up the Grecian dome, temples and pillars. It's magic.
author: Helena H.

description: on a nice sunny day, the picnic grass area is a great place to relax and chill with your friends or whoever you came with. in general, it's a nice place with a view of a giant outdoor palace dome. although it says dont step on the area where you arent, it does have great pictures once you are on them, dont destroy the plants in the process though. peaceful place with ducks.
author: Ly V.

description: Breathtaking beautiful.  If I lived in SF, I'd visit the Palace daily!!  What a wonderful place to sit and relax... have a picnic... nap... people watch... observe... contemplate... meditate... decide.  Whenever I visit the Palace, I make sure to bring my SLR and snap away... there's soo many people passing through, you never know what your lens will catch.
author: Gina M.

description: Gorgeous. This is probably my favorite photo spot in the area. It's just absolutely gorgeous.
author: Jackie T.

description: Beautiful place for photo shoots or just taking a walk around the lagoon. I never get tired of the view here!
author: Esther Y.

description:
Great views.  Take pictures.  Have a picnic.  

Been here at night, when you can see the stars, the reflections off the water, and risked falling into a muddy bank.  lol  

Been here in broad daylight, and posed as tourists would...camera in hand and doing silly faces. 

It's a nice kind of fun, and an inexpensive thing to do in this city.  

Some day, will have to find a nice patch, and get some reading done.
author: Fannie S.

description:
I have never been here but came for a concert put on by Jero, Japan's first African-American enka singer. 

This theater had a very intimate feel to it. Walking in, there was a waiting area with drinks and snacks being sold and tables and chairs that you could eat at. 

The ushers helped you find your row (all assigned seating!) and the chairs themselves were extremely comfortable. I could lean back and was tempted to never get out of it. It's one of those seats that just suck you in. 

The acoustics of this theater was great. When Jero sang, I could here his voice clearly as well as the band. There isn't a bad seat in the theater and everyone could see the singer clearly. No stalker binoculars needed!

I had a fantastic time and the venue is definitely a big part of making it a great experience.  It has an intimate feel while having a good number of seats (about a thousand people). 

I'll have to check out more concerts here.
author: Julia W.

description: Gorgeous place for a walk in SF, I would KILL to live in the apartments across the street.
author: Laura D.

description:
From the top of Twin Peaks, or driving across the Golden Gate Bridge there are is myriad of colors and structures (from Victorian to sky high corporate office buildings) saturating the landscape.  One of the first things (and one of the most impressive) that your eyes will gravitate towards is the golden round top of the Palace of Fine Arts.

Somehow the place has managed to slip through the common "squeeze" of crowded space in the city (the kind that makes you want to pull your arms in very close towards your body, then outward to shove that feeling of claustrophobia away) and sits seemingly all alone in its claimed space in the "Marina" District (what I consider part of the Marina anyway).  The property is gorgeous --- beautiful enough even for Sean Connery in the film, "The Rock" haha!

At the theatre I once watched Henry Rollins perform.  I remember he was talking about being in LA where his home is, and how he has this squirrel out back that is one of the most intriguing creatures he's ever seen.  He goes on to describe how this grey squirrel will come right up close to the house and lie on a wood pile on his back and bask in the sun.  Rollins says, "he looks like he's at the beach with his arms behind his head and a leg crossed --- like he needs sunglasses on" and he's so impressed with this animal that he'll sneak through his own house (crawling on the floor over to the window where just the tops of his eyes peak over the ledge and outside) trying to observe this creature, but not disturb him...  The whole crowd was cracking up trying to picture this and at that moment it occurred to me just how solid the sound quality is here.  

It is a perfect spot for a performance (I can only imagine seeing a play that requires less involvement from the audience) --- easy to see the stage from anywhere, sound carries famously throughout the place, etc.

Two thumbs up!
author: Benjamin G.

description:
I love architecture and roaming hours & hours on end at this place was remarkable! 

The design and views were so amazing. Incredibly one of the must see places in the Bay Area!
author: Denise M.

description: Pretty spot to sit on a park bench and feed the ducks.
author: David P.

description: This place is stunning! Great for a peaceful walk or a beautiful backdrop for any photographer. I couldn't get enough photos of this place!
author: Jenn R.

description:
Going to see Tim Minchin! 1st time here. 

Quirky venue with statues going around the lobby area that made me think that they may have been part of the world's faire exhibition from back in the day. I want to see the fireplace lit up sometime cause that was huge! The show was great and it seems like anywhere you sit in this place is going to be a good seat in the house. One concern was when leaving the place, might be kind of dangerous if there was an emergency. We weren't that far from the end of the row and it took forever to get out to the stairs. But maybe it was the crowd we were with. 

I want to come back in the daytime sometime and hang out in the park area for a picnic, but it sure is pretty all lit up at night. The other plus- doesn't seem to be a goose haven.
author: Colleen M.

description:
I have been to the Palace of Fine Arts more times than I can count. It is always a beautiful spot to stop and take in the sites. 

In all of the times I have been there I never come across the column exhibit/demonstration. You go into one of the columns of the Palace. There is a xylophone type sound machine. You hit the notes and can feel the vibration of the sound. There is a model of how each different note wave is heard. Very interesting. It is put on by the Exploratorium. The kids loved it.
author: Jeromy W.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is singularaly one of the most "San Francisco" esque landmarks I have ever seen. Other than the Golden Gate Bridge of course (duh). Without fail, everytime I want to sweep a visitor off of his or her feet, I swing by (getting lost down in the Marina/Cow Hollow area every single time for the love of god) and show them what a fabulous, and gorgeous city we are all lucky to reside in.

My favorite moment was when I saw a bunch of Japanese tourists wandering about and some little kid almost pushed his dad who was taking a photograph into the pond with the swans floating gracefully by.
author: Kathy K.

description:
i love coming here to enjoy the sun.
it's so peaceful and beautiful to sit on the bench or grass just to lounge.
it just got remodeled and is now open.
it's just breath taking.
this is the place that u can ppl watch..always tourist coming around or wedding/quinceanera's parties taking pictures.
author: francis c.

description:
Cool place.  Great for photos.  I saw Spike and Mike's Sick and Twisted festival of Animation here a couple times.  I loved it.  Makes you feel like you are really are in San Francisco.

parking is confusing and driving around there is confusing.  make a wrong turn and you are screwed.  Some parts of the building outside needed to be repaired and a lot of stuff needs to be kept in better condition...seems kinda worn out.  Still a great spot though.
author: Cynthia B.

description: The Wife and I visited this gem a few years ago....and we loved it. The weather was outstanding that day...and since it sits so close to the marina the ocean breezes are really nice. Now this is and indoor and outdoor facility....there is plenty to do and see inside and outside and that is what makes this place so great. The palace fits in so well with the other city landmarks...and the man made lake for the ducks and other wild life is simply beautiful. This is a great place for picnics, romantic walks, and the arts and crafts on display inside are not to be missed as well. While parking in San Francisco can be a nightmare..this location has it's own lot with plenty of parking and you can even park on the street in some areas by the marina and take a nice walk over to the Palace...which i highly recommend on a beautiful San Francisco day. So if your ever in the bay area...run don't walk to The Palace of Fine Arts...you will be glad you did. Eat, Drink, and be Merry my friends!!!!
author: Andre E.

description: Must see spot in San Fran. Beautiful place to walk around and take pictures.
author: Tessa O.

description: If your time is limited in SF skip this, at least until they finish the construction...there are plenty of things to do in SF.  Everything is gated and the pond needs some serious cleaning.  It is disgusting with the feathers and bird poop floating...you're better off walking across the street and looking for the pipe organs.
author: Lai T.

description:
Oh Palace with your alluring arches and dazzling dome.....

almost unfair I can admire you daily from the streets of my home!

I LOVE SAN FRANCISCO!
author: Caroline J.

description:
B-E-A-YOUUU-TIFUL and serene!!

OMG, let's have a picnic here! come on! lunch? chase the ducks? walk around the architecture? photowalk?! cmon!

let's go!
author: Summer R.

description:
I've made it inside yet, but the grounds are very nice! Well kept, and very clean! Just a beautiful place to relax on a sunny Sunday afternoon!  I just started dating a new girl, and we took a blanket and just enjoyed laying down on the grass and talking. After the never ending tourist's groups left, we shared our first kiss... 
bring some bread crumbs and you can feed the swans!
author: C J.

description:
Infamous place to have wedding or cotillion photos taken. Or photos in general. 

I don't know what else I can say that others haven't already. I'll just post pictures.
author: Clarisse C.

description: I wish I had read Yelp before taking the boy here -- we were both super excited to visit and try out the acoustics (something I remembered from an old Exploratorium visit).  We were terribly disappointed to see that the whole area was blocked off -- you couldn't even get close enough to take good pictures, so everyone was slipping and slopping through the muddy grass.  However, there was plenty of parking along the street.
author: Sara C.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts in San Francisco is sadly not the actual house of horror I thought it was when I first heard the name. One of my favorite books is The Devil in The White City by Erik Larsen which tells the story of the serial killer Dr. H. H. Holmes and the 1893 Chicago's World's Fair nicknamed the "White City". At the time of the fair, Dr. Holmes lured an unknown number of helpless women to their death in the World Fair's Hotel and struck fear into the residents and visitors of Chicago (similar to SF's very own Zodiac killer). When I first saw the Palace of Fine Arts in the Marina, I thought "how cool", but my friend pointed out this was built 1915, not 1893 and this is San Francisco's Palace, not Chicago's and I was in the wrong place. 
 
Although it's not a house of horror, it's still one of my favorite spots in the city. San Francisco's Palace of Fine Arts was built for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition to house works of art presented there. Due to its unsiesmically sound structure, the original Palace was demolished in 1964 and a replica rebuilt in its place. The new Palace is almost exactly the same as the old except for the absence of the murals in the dome and a few lesser details. Today, the Palace is also home to the Exploratorium and 1,000 person theater.

 The Palace is popular among locals and visitors. The lagoon and its white geese as well as the manicured green lawns make it a picture perfect picnic spot. On a sunny day in the city, the lawn surrounding the lagoon is teeming with families, couples and friends enjoying a bite to eat, relaxing in the sun, or flying a kite. The Palace is also popular for engagement and wedding party pictures. It's a beautiful old world backdrop in the middle of a modern city. I always make a point to bring out-of-town visitors here to show them the beauty, diversity and history of San Francisco. The spot is so iconic that Disney made a replica of it in Disney's California Adventure Park. Even Disney thinks it's important!
author: Alice S.

description:
My kid brother surprised me by taking me to a place in SF I'd never HEARD of, let alone seen before (I know, I'm terribly uncultured).

What a beautiful, lovely, and amazing place that is hidden away at the tip of SF.

I can't imagine anyone who won't be amazed by this place too.
Take pictures!
author: Nikolina E.

description: Quaint ponds with ducks to feed in palatial architecture backdrops like you've transported to another era, one with quality above all else.
author: Mr B.

description:
One of the first things that impressed me when I came to SF in 1990 was the Palace of Fine Arts, even during renovation, I always looked to it for a place of beauty and peacefulness. I've taken friends and family since and everyone has been impressed.
Parking will be an issue, especially in the summer and during holidays.
author: Jon P.

description:
Dear Palace,

You are gorgeous (with a couple million dollars of renovation), more beautiful than I remember.  Smoother (and cleaner) paths, water's edge lined in some parts with stone to prevent looky loos who may fall into the pond, new benches, and a restored rotunda where stone will not hit you in the head. Birds, tourists and locals will flock to this magnificent watering hole once more. Go while the Exploratorium is still there, until it moves into its new home by the piers in a few years.

Love,
JL
author: Jen L.

description:
nice to walk through, had to find the history later online, wish something would have been there explaining the history while there. ( if there was I never saw it)

free.
author: Drew H.

description: This is a pretty park with a lake and a big decorative concrete structure. It's not a "palace" and there are no "fine arts". That's pretty confusing for us out-of-towners. Sure, the big domed centerpiece is an iconic San Francisco structure and is seen "time after time", but ultimately you're left with a basic park. I feel bad giving only 3-stars, but after a quick 15-minute walk around the park, you're done.
author: Brian U.

description: Cool old buildings left over from a worlds fair. great for photos. then time to move on......
author: Mark B.

description: Great place to chill and take couple pictures. Very pretty at night time!
author: Olga B.

description:
My fav place in the city for a picnic on a sunny day. My bf and I packed some food, grabbed some blankets and headed down here to face the Palace and do some people-watching. It's such a lovely view (despite the renovating that's currently going on) and there's enough grassy area for people to picnic.

P.S: There's even a turtle that swims in the lake!
author: Janel Y.

description:
Red drapes cover all the walls in the auditorium and I dig that. True enough, even for a vertically challenged person all the seats appear to provide a clear view of the stage. Odd thing though, there isn't a center aisle and the rows are very long so those sitting center stage will need to squeeze past a lot of people to get in/out, but there is a decent amount of knee space so those passing by won't need you to suck you legs up unto your seat. Good acoustics and parking. 

I agree with a yelper before me that it is unfortunate that the bathrooms open directly onto the lobby - you open the door and there in front of you are legs under the stall doors ... poor design.
author: Heather M.

description: I envy those people who lives around the area. On second thought, maybe not so much since there are a lot of tourists that would stop by here. But this place is just so magnificently beautiful! And my favorite part, it is an awesome place for photo ops. It is also a very nice place to sit by the pond and read a book on a lazy Sunday afternoon. Perhaps a casual date would work too.
author: Sandy C.

description:
I would give maximum stars allowed to this venue for four reasons.  (1) Superior audio, (2) The cleanliness, (3) Comfortable seats, and (4) View of the stage.  

Each row elevates enough to ensure clear view of the stage.  So, even if someone with HUGE hairdo sits in front of you, you'll be okay here at Palace of Fine Arts Theatre.
author: Kioko O.

description: such a beautiful place. definitely a great photo opportunity. Arrived here around evening time, and there were a few people walking around taking pictures. However many were there for the concert in the theatre. I would highly suggest this place, for those who never experienced it. Nearby, in close proximity, is the exploratorium museum and the palace of fine arts theatre. Also, across the street, yet further down is crissy field and the golden gate bridge.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Very scenic. Cant believe I never checked out this spot after all the SF trips I made. Would be a good spot to have a picnic. Bring a jacket, its pretty cold in the evening. I wouldnt recommend parking off to the side by the theater, I saw several parking spots with broken glass.
author: Oanh L.

description:
This is a great spot for a picnic, all you need to do is grab your honey or some friends spread a blanket out and enjoy the sunshine and sights. 
Which is just what we did... Well minus the blanket, but sitting on the bench was nice enough to enjoy a semi warm sunny day in the yay area.  After we were finished with lunch we decided to walk around and take in the sights of this interesting place.
Walking around (watch out for people taking photos, they are everywhere!)
it was peaceful and beautiful!! The perfect place to just relax and enjoy everything around you. 
Ducks and swans swimming around the large pond, kids running around laughing, ice cream dude selling yummi mexican ice cream and such, a wedding party walking towards the brides final moments of being single. Sounds like a dream sequence of a movie.
Plenty of places to take photos too. The giant columns were amazing, the architecture was just mind blowing. Standing in the middle i felt smaller then i already am.
author: Sarah A.

description: A must stop location for all tourists and a must see for all locals for sure. Beautiful architecture that seems to sit in the middle of a bunch of residential housing. Peaceful setting with a beautiful pond. Always see some type of wedding group taking pictures or some couple taking professional couple photos.
author: Tommy B.

description:
I can't even remember how many shows I've seen here, but the most recent one was Jake Shimabukuro on 3/26/11. He was awesome!

Still, this review is supposed to be about the venue, so here goes. I think the main problem is the setup of things. You can see into the bathrooms from the lobby. The seats are split up in a really strange way; the only walkways are on the sides of the theatre, so you have to walk down your entire row to in or out. Sound quality is great though, and all seats are assigned and very comfortable. The staff is also very helpful. Sometimes I feel like the crowd is a little stuffy here, but I'm a little more used to shows at the Fillmore so that's probably just me (haha).
author: Kiana H.

description:
We used the Palace of Fine Arts Rotunda for our May 26th Wedding. It was absolutely majestic. The area is far enough off the road where there is little to no sound from the streets. The grounds were absolutely beautiful, the only issue is that depending on the day and time of year, the rotunda can be a bit of a wind tunnel and thus cold. However, our guests thought it was epic, and we loved having our ceremony there. 
Thank you to Amanda over at the Main office for all of your help!

Mr. and Mrs. LaBier
author: Daryn L.

description: Palace of Fine Arts is stop #4 after Pier 39/Fisherman Wharf before we head down to Cissy Field. Parking is challenging and you might to wait or drive around the rich folks neighborhood. A perfect place for picnic or just sitting down reading a book. I hope to give it 5 stars after they finish the construction.
author: Sam M.

description:
This place is absolutely breathtaking!

I had seen it before driving by the water... but it wasn't until an impromptu trip to San Francisco this past St. Patty's day with my roomy that I finally experienced this place first hand.

Had a lovely walk in the morning by the lake and enjoyed the sights.  

Took tons of pictures....
(here's one: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u3mX2Hkc0XoCgPxG6xRFkg?select=pRuxWFaZp-g9YUAv1DFJyA)

And was completely overwhelmed by the magnitude of this landmark's size!
author: Andrea Z.

description:
Amazing scenery and architecture.  I see weddings take place here almost all the time.  

I'm not exactly refined enough to be able to identify the structures and sculptures here, but it's always a nice thing to see whenever I'm in the area.  There are very good picture opportunities around the lake that overlook the lovely ancient lookin' architecture.  

Don't forget to chase around all the bird life there... you'll find a strange enjoyment in doing that, heheh..
author: Johnson N.

description:
Never been during the day.

But it is wonderful late late at night. Grab a loaf of bread and go feed some water fowl! 

It's peaceful and quiet with stunning lighting on the dome.

If you're scared of wildlife I'd go during the day. Rats, raccoons, opossums and the occasional skunk have been known to show up at night. I just ignore them and they keep going like I'm not there.

Not to mention the great time I had doing an E.P.W.A. event here that took us into the Exploratorium for a special night in the tactile room.
author: Ashley H.

description:
Has this place been reviewed a million times? Yes.   Do I have anything to say that others haven't said already? No.  Do I still feel compelled to review this place anyway?  Yes.  Why?  I really don't know.  Maybe because I have the urge to yelp and that is something I just cant change.  I don't want to change.

Palace of fine arts.  Beautiful! What a great place to walk to after a fantastic lunch on Chestnut.  I took a few pictures there and they came out so well it would give the illusion that I am a professional photographer.  I love anyplace that makes me look better.  

So if you are in the marina area.  You have a friend or someone whose company you just can't get enough of...take a walk to the palace of fine arts.  And enjoy yourself, the day and one of the things that makes SF so special.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is gorgeous, elegant, and, well, palatial.  It's worth a visit just to gape at the architecture and the scenic surroundings; but even better if you check out the Exploratorium or see one of the many eclectic performances in the Theatre.  

I've been to a few performances here, most recently last night's Whirling Dervishes presented by the California Institute of Integral Studies.  The venue is beautiful, with a smoothly running box office area and a large lobby with snacks and festive decor.  My only complaint is that the air conditioning was a bit intense!
author: Leena K.

description: Taking a taxi to an event here last night was spot on the best decision. Driving to and from events coupled with the parking fees, or simply no parking wasn't on my radar. nice.
author: Christine T.

description: Surreal in its beauty, I was transported back to my days in NYC and DC when you could walk through a park embedded in the heart of the city and feel as if you've gone to another world.  We watched couples mill around and smooch, children duck between the columns playing hide and seek, and a small wedding with a harpist and teary family.  It was glorious of a landmark, with every picture coming out like a postcard.  Surrounding the pond is some serious real estate as well, so if you like looking at magazine-worthy house fronts, there's that too.  I'd love to return here with a picnic lunch and just chill out on the lawn - I see it in my future :)
author: Angela G.

description: This place is truly beautiful and I just love it.  I took my kids here and they were in heaven.  The building is so lovely and the place is a must see for tourists and locals of all ages.  Check it out at night - unbelievable
author: Shirley W.

description:
This place is amazing.

If you come to San Francisco skip all other junk and come here!!!

It's the most marvelous thing I have ever seen.  

In the distance this thing is already spectacular but then when you get close you realize this thing is HUGE.

Then you start to climb it and you're soon a speck in the distance in comparison.

This review is just for the venue itself, no need to watch a concert or anything at all.  Just being able to gaze at this monument was worth 6+ STARS if I could give it.

The golden gate bridge was nice but this puts it to shame.
author: David N.

description: This is probably one of the most picturesque places in SF.  Come here for a stroll or a picnic or just to admire the view.  Parking could be annoying but be patient because this place is worth the wait.
author: Leddee H.

description: Nice palace/park to walk around. Just can't seem to find where Sean Connery sat though in the movie "the rock".
author: Tiffany H.

description: One of the most beautiful spots in San Francisco! A great place for an afternoon picnic, a late night stroll, or a newlywed photo.  Entrance and parking are free!
author: H T.

description:
Bought $30 tix at the last minute to see Melody Gardot tonight at the Palace of Fine Arts Theatre.  What a fantastically romantic and soulful voice...Lots of witty banter sprinkled throughout the show, kept the audience entertained the entire time.  Extremely talented young lady.  L-O-V-E.

P.S. Although we were in the very back left corner of the theater (Row V, Seat 3 and 5), the sound and visual experience was still good - better than expected.
author: Burrito M.

description:
I'm not very girly. 

I watch football, chug beer, play soccer, hate shopping, don't want to give birth, don't own anything with a bow or flower on it, hate the color pink, can change my own tire, lift heavy objects, play poker, drink whiskey, I never hide my weight and I don't cry at sappy movies. 

However...

Even I can't help but think that maybe I'd like a boyfriend so that we can take nighttime walks here.
author: Jay H.

description: Took my friends to the Palace of Fine Arts when they were visiting from out of town. The weather was gorgeous and I hadn't been back here since I was very little, so I couldn't resist. It was a very quiet day, plenty of parking and very few people. I'm so happy I went back! The sunlight, the breeze, the sheer tranquil beauty of the place brought back happy childhood memories. Absolutely beautiful.
author: Sandy B.

description:
I'd been avoiding coming here because somehow it seemed difficult to get to when driving past on my way to the Golden Gate bridge...Not so! It's really easy to get to and there is abundant street parking in front of some of the prettiest houses in the city. 

The palace is fenced off during the "renovation" (how long will that last?) but you can still take lots of unobstructed photos of the beautiful structure, in addition to feeding the birds in the little lake in front of it, strolling around the picture-perfect park, and daydreaming about what it would be like to live in one of the houses nearby.

Plus: The Exploratorium is just next to the palace to the north.
author: Ekin O.

description:
I completely under utilize this spot. This has come to my attention after a strange and brief phone call I just had with my Aunt and Uncle (who I haven't seen in 10 years, and are in town) and my Uncles brother (who I have never met, and is the reason they are in town).  They wanted to meet up with me for lunch. We fumbled, seeing as we don't really know much about each others likes and dislikes, trying to figure out a pre-lunch meeting place suitable for catching up on everything that has happened over the last decade. 

I am quite sure this will be interesting. My mom likes to edit my life into some tidy narrative suitable for public consumption, which is crazy because she should know by now that once I am in front of these people all of the hard work she put into that lovely piece of fiction will be for nothing.

So, anyhow, we all decided to meet here, along with my Uncles brothers girlfriend, who I also have never met. We are going to stroll the grounds, talk, laugh (most likely at me) and decide at that point where to eat. This is a perfect place to do this. It is beautiful, historical, peaceful (well, except for those damn pigeons) and reminds me of why I love living in this city. It also reminds me of what I did at midnight under the dome the last time I was here. I wonder if my mom will approve of me sharing THAT story with my relatives.....
author: Drue C.

description:
Beautiful spot for your outdoor ceremony. You can have your ceremony under the dome, but it's definitely a risk. With SF weather, you will never know how your day will turn out. It can be sunny and warm, but you can also end up with foggy SF weather, which can be a disaster. Under the dome, you can experience serious wind factor and noise. Since SF is unpredictable, we didn't to pass on this spot.

If you are adventurous and want to take a risk.. here were the facts... $500 to rent the space, but you will need to rent chairs and port a potties... You can have your reception in the Exploratorium, which is close by, but can't start your reception til 630. Your guest will have to walk through all the science stations before you get to the reception area. Overall, I thought the space was cool and very unique.
author: Denise L.

description: Another getaway. Totally overrated. You can BART in and then cab or meet a friend and share a ride. Very close to the Golden gate bridge. So many options on how to get there it can be confusing to you or whoever you're talking to. A total tourist trap. Its been there 100 years. To make it exciting you can look for a restaurant(s)  everywhere or even stop in Emeryville on the way and look at a Ferrari . Might be a fun place to enjoy a wedding or hang out and set up and talk about what you should be doing instead of being there .
author: F O.

description:
I was at the Palace of Fine Arts in the Marina a couple of months ago to snap some photos for a friend's web page. It needed some background photos, etc. It had been a while since I had been there. I was surprised to see a chain link fence around the place. Kind of takes away its splendor. 

Sad that so many places that used to be open and free have to be locked up or placed under extra security. I guess that is the way it is now. 

Used to go to the Exploratorium as a kid. That was a fun place. I doubt that people today would find the homespun science exhibits interesting since everything today is video games and digital. Not easy to get people these days to pay attention to much of anything away from their i-Pod or cell phone. 

I see that there was an international dance festival at the Palace's performing arts theater. Perfect place for it, so good to see cultural events there. 

Yet, fence or not, the Palace still is grand and definitely a landmark. I get chills when I walk under the dome and see the angels in the architecture. I call them Maybeck's angels because Bernard Maybeck was the architect. 

See web link: 
http://www.oregoncoast.net/maybeckpalace.html 


Hard to believe that this palace was just one of many elaborate buildings for the Pan-Pacific Exposition of 1915. See web link: 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama-Pacific_International_Exposition_(1915) 

They were only temporary buildings. 

And that like the Mid-Winter Exposition of 1894 that gave birth to the Golden Gate Park, these events were celebrations lasting months to encourage people to visit the city. Yet they were built only for that event and to be taken down. Amazing! 

I know that there was a major effort to make the structure of the Palace more permanent. Just recently the large dome was renovated. It was painted a bright orange for a while. Made the dome really stick out. 

It reminded me of as if someone had a big orange in the mouth. Or as it was a giant ball. And, that the ball would start bouncing out like a big balloon at any second moving skyward. 

One of my favorite photos of the Palace of Fine Arts is the one with singer Janis Joplin and her car parked on the lawn. Classic picture moment! And she was so happy in that photo. 

See web link for photo display: 
http://www.wolfgangsvault.com/dt/janis-joplin-fine-art-print/JMP0042-FP.html 

Would not be able to snap a photo like that today with the chain link fence. Oh well! 

For more info re: The Exploratorium visit: 
http://www.exploratorium.edu/
author: Jonathan F.

description:
This is such a cool place to take photographs or have a picnic on a sunny day. It is still being restored.My photography group came her to take night photographs one evening. I had my camera on a tripod doing long exposures. All of a sudden I heard a squeaking and shrieking. Out of the foliage came a skunk and a very large rat. I tried not to scream. I mean I can deal with wild life. I was just taken off guard by the urban wildlife at the palace of fine arts. Still, I was not about to be skunked. I decided the image really wasn't worth tangling with a skunk or a rat. So I grabbed my gear and ran. 
Yes, it is a romantic spot, just beware of the skunks and rats.
author: Jennifer S.

description: it's a beautiful site to enjoy a lazy afternoon.. take some pics.. sit and feed the birds... and enjoy the green space..
author: Stan L.

description: Great architecture and great place to show out-of-towners. Its right off the golden gate bridge, so its a convenient stop. Good for pictures and possibly for picnics. Inside the palace of fine arts is more artwork basically from what I remember and they have shows in their also.
author: Robert Y.

description: When in need to recenter yourself why not try art. LOVE it! Its amazing! its cheap and realaxing. I think its a great place for a date.
author: Conchita B.

description:
I've walked around the grounds of Palace of Fine Arts, but never knew there was a theater inside! Honestly, I think it's not as well known as a theater because the entrance is somewhat hidden. You have to drive around the place to see the entrance. It's not a grand entrance either, so you might mistake it as a loading area.

However, once you do go inside, it's quite amazing actually. There's a panoramic canvas picture in the lobby area showcasing the area around the Palace of Fine Arts in the early 1900s. It's a real picture! Pass the lobbying area, you enter a huge room with seating, restrooms and food service. 

There's two entrances into the theater. Inside the theater it was vastly decorated in red. I don't know if it is normally like this, but red curtains, red seats, red ceiling. It was a bit overwhelming. The theater seats about 1000 people. The seats are old but still comfortable. There was lots of dust bits on the seats and stains. I think it's time to redo the seat covers!

I attended the inaugural Go!Style concert here last Friday. The theater has an amazing sound system. The lighting was great and we got good seats. What a great venue to host your concert/event!
author: Melissa T.

description:
Pssst guys... well I guess ladies too...if you want to get your well-deserved and long-awaited first kiss from this guy/girl you've been seeing, this is the place to do it.

A very romantic place to take a lovely stroll on a clear night (and with SF fog being notorious, especially out by the Marina district, you better treasure the few clear nights we have!).  The ancient Greek styled pavilion ads a quaint and artsy touch to the serene calmness of the lake.  Sheezus, there's even swans here.  All that's missing is Sebastian the crab singing "Kiss the Girl" (if you don't know what the hell I'm talking about watch Disney's "The Little Mermaid" again)

What's also kind of a double-edged sword about this place is that it's conveniently located.  Within just a few blocks of trendy Chestnut street and its lovely hip restaurants, and literally smack next to the Exploratorium, the Palace of Fine Arts certainly doesn't have problems with foot traffic.  Unfortunately this also means careless visitors leaving more than just footprints behind.  The city's trash crew and park and rec centers, but most of all the visitors,  need to do more to keep this place litter free and enjoyable for everyone.
author: Catherine C.

description:
This iconic picture-perfect must-see San Francisco attraction is nothing short of spectacular.  Built for the Panama-Pacific Exposition in 1919, this Roman Beaux-Arts collonade and fronting water lagoon and fountain along with its hillside park is one of the reasons why San Francisco is so picturesque and worth the trip.  Why it's great:

1.  It's free!:  while the renovations seem to stretch into eternity and I never have seen anyone work on it in the interim, the Rotunda and the colonnade have been a favorite of many SF natives and prefer to take pictures on the green in front of it.  I envy the Marina residents who have such a beautiful "front yard" that they don't have to pay for (although may be it through taxes).  It really is a living room that is outdoor, and accessible to all, although the parking gets a little stifling in the neighborhood.  

2.  One of the key landmark features of San Francisco that is in movies:  it's interesting to know that the Palace of Fine Arts has been the preferred scene of location on choice for filming "The Rock" (with Nicholas Cage), Nash Bridges and Monk.  It's always cool to walk around on a place where they've filmed and see it for free.

3.  Iconic architecture to appreciate in your own backyard:  with the Golden Gate Bridge a minute or so away,  Presidio and the Marina Green, no wonder this gem of architecture instantly is recognized as a SF landmark.  With a picnic lunch and shooing the nasty pigeons away from your feet, the appreciation of the Palace's beauty is really a must-to do list on your SF list of things to do in 24 hours.

Five Yelp Stars for the Palace of Fine Arts!
author: JC K.

description:
I don't mean for there to be a disproportionate amount of positive reviews on here....but there is just so much cool shit in San Francisco.  The Palace of Fine Arts is to the best banana split of all time....with sprinkles, chocolate, peanuts, whipped cream and extra cherries.  

You'd think it would be over-stimulation, but it so isn't.

Getting married and can't think of an original backdrop?  Join the other 5 wedding parties here at 1:00pm on Saturday and take some photos in front of the fountain.

Miss man-eating swans?  Come here.  There are plenty.

Exploritorum much?  This place is the most amazing place on the planet.  I love this place more than a fat kid loves cake.  Sensory overload times a gazillion.

Want to sit under a willow tree and nosh on grapes and cheese in romantic bliss?  Don't forget the checkered blanket....you can make it happen.

Care for a leisurely stroll around a iconic area of SF?  Done, and done.
author: Jenn T.

description: This place is a great photoshoot backdrop, from the fancy shmancy homes nearby and lack of parking its very beautiful. Alot of people come to take pictures of the ancient pillars and dome that I've been looking at since I was a little yelper. It's also right around the corner from THE EXPLORATORIUM museum (which is moving to the piers this year) but can also add to a family outting. I loved visiting and taking pictures of my family by the lake and the dome.
author: Sheryl G.

description:
What a great venue! Not too large in size and there is no bad seat in the house. I never knew that there was a theatre until last night as my fiance got a pair of ticket to see Bryan Adams since I am a big fan :) And my fiance... he gave up his favorite Sharks game that night for my Bryan Adams... awww... what a sweet man!

During the show, Bryan Adams kept mentioning that this place is like a "sponge". Sound must not echo as much compared to other large venue but as an audience, it sounded much more closer and real. I love this sort of mid-sized venue compared to a huge places, where I usually end up with looking at the TV screen to see what is going on the stage.

I really enjoyed the show in terms of sound quality and the view of the stage. We sat almost all the way to the back of the theare but we still were able to have a grand view of the stage and Bryan Adams. His performance, singing and guitor... still amazing :D I would definitely check out other shows at Palace of Fine Arts in the future. 

It has nothing to do with the PoFA but I need to mention this... people who sat next to me kept talking WHOLE THROUGH THE SHOW.... I am not kidding. The whole 2 hours. Never shut up. But they managed to scream "EYEEEE  LUUUUUV  EWWWWW!" to Bryan Adams here and there at very odd moments during the show, and go back to chatting and checking their iPhones... WTF!? If you really "love" the artist, listen to the songs and what he has to say instead of chatting with your friends. Please, have a courtesy to your fellow audience.
author: Tomomi S.

description:
I had never thought of the palace as anything more than a pretty place to walk around, and we're fortunate to have plenty of those in San Francisco, so it never warranted special attention.  On Monday night, we had tickets to see "Revenge of the Book Eaters" a benefit performance to support 826 Valencia.  I asked the Gentleman Caller if I should bring a sleeping bag for us to sit on, and he seemed confused.

There's a concert venue inside!  Who knew?  Not me, after 7 years here.  It was easily the cleanest venue I've been in, with wide seats and armrests that both of our arms fit on comfortably.  Even better, the stadium seating was high and well spaced enough that I didn't have to sit on my knees.  However, the sound was not as expected.  After each artist, a sound engineer came out to adjust, but it didn't have the impact I might have hoped.  The music and the singer sounded like two different entities.  When I came in through another door following a bathroom break, it sounded about 20x better from the steps than it did in our great seats in the 7th row middle.

Five stars for outside X three stars for in=4 stars.
author: Beth V.

description: This place may look fantastic from the outside, but the decor on the inside is pretty underwhelming. They also do not have any sense of quality control. We came here for a New Year's Eve party thrown by a 3rd party and it was TERRIBLE.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Came here Friday night for an API comedy fundraiser night. Nice lobby area and auditorium was spacious. Parking was easy.
author: Holla F.

description:
This is one of those reviews where you get dinged one star simply because you're too good, but too far.

Let me sum this up like a 7th grade love letter:

"Dear Palace of Fine Arts,

Do you love me and want to go out with me? 

circle y or no.

love,

your secret admirer."

... no response because you're on the other side of the city and my carrier pigeon died of avian flu means sad andy. But I still love you for your beautiful architecture and amazing photo ops.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I've been to the Palace of Fine Arts many times, but not for the theater.  I had no idea it existed!

It's pretty dark in the back where the entrance is, and the entrance isn't that grand.  The inside is awesome, and theater itself is really cool.

They have great lighting, sound system is sweet.  The weird thing was there was huge clumps of dust over a few rows of seats.  The dust looked ancient and pretty gross.

My guess is it came from the catwalk above, someone must have been walking up there and knocked tons of dust down onto the seats.

That's the minus 1 star =)

Anyway, beautiful location can't be beat.
author: Art C.

description:
This is a really beautiful place, not only just to take a walk, but a nice theater!!

I came here last night for the Duncan Sheik concert and also was here previously to see Rufus Wainwright.  I like the acoustics, though the chairs are kinda retarded.  They really bounce a lot, but they're not horrible.  The stage is great for artists with a larger band.  Both Duncan and Rufus had a number of folks on stage with various instruments ... pianos and all.

They have a bar where they sell a cheese/fruit platter which is nice and classy.  They also sell wine, soda, tea, coffee, mentos, various mints, pastries and such.  Kinda neat for a concert ... no gross hot dogs or hamburgers ... this place has style, k??  Plus the main lobby's big and has lots of tables and chairs to sit and hang out before a show.  You could be sitting their with your glass of red and cheese/fruit platter.  Niiiiiiiiiiiice.

The thing I like about this theater is it's pretty nice and intimate.  Both artists interacted with the audience as it's a small theater so it's a big plus for fans.  I recall someone in the audience asking how Duncan was ... it was pretty funny.  

Staff was nice.  I don't recall how the bathrooms were but I think they were okay.

The big plus about this venue is there plenty of free parking for shows.  How's that for the Marina, much less San Francisco????  It rocks.  It can be perfect for a concert, but a pain on a nice day if lots of folks are out heading to Exploratorium is located there too.

The architecture's impressive.  It totally reminds me of the Seal video for "Don't Cry" since it was shot here.  People come here to feed the ducks and just hang out.  It's perfect on a sunny day but probably a pain for locals who live across the street.  

Nice spot to hang out or see a live show.
author: imelda j.

description:
Well I feel just like a child...
...yeah I feel just like a child
Well I feel just like a child...
...Well I feel just like a child

From my womb to my tomb, I guess I'll always be a child.

Well some people try and treat me like a man...
...yeah some people try and treat me like a man
Well I guess they just don't understand...
...Well some people try and treat me like a man

They think I know shit
But that's just it
I'm a child.

---

Those lyrics echoed through the Palace of Fine Arts Theatre last Friday, the 7th of September 2007.  Devendra Banhart and many adoring fans danced around on stage as he & his backup band played their final song of the evening--Andy Cabic of Vetiver & renowned producer/songwriter/guitarist Noah Georgeson included.

If it wasn't for Devendra's showmanship, the Palace of Fine Arts would have been a horrible place to see a concert. Ticket prices for the show were all the same, but unfortunately it was assigned seating. About 30 minutes after the concert started, Devendra asked everyone in the back to move to the front. He even apologized about the venue, and jokingly said he would be playing a solo set at Waizema on Divisadero.
