You can drink at the show, but only in the lobby. No food/drinks in the theater, AT ALL. The ticket said NO cameras/video equipment, but nobody checked me...NOT ONCE. Hell, I could have brought a whole major motion picture crew in the damn theater and nobody would have noticed. 

My take on the Palace of Fine Arts Theater goes like this:

-Not so great if you want to enjoy a live concert.
-Much better if you are there to watch a play/opera/etc
-Probably amazing if you are there to view some sort of discussion/debate.

If it wasn't for the performer on the night I visited, this place would get 3 stars. Instead, Devendra and his colleagues helped me to realize that the venue itself is pretty cool...just not the prime location for a live concert with a bunch of stoned neo-hippies.
author: matt m.

description:
I loved this place so much that I couldn't wait to get home and write a review. Apparently I'm not the only one who felt that way. So to re-cap what the other reviewers stated, bring your camera, some bread for the ducks, and someone you love (kid, dog, or S.O.) and enjoy the beauty.
When we were there this past Saturday, they were setting up for a wedding reception, and there were THREE wedding parties taking photos. I think this would be a gorgeous place to take wedding photos, but not so great for a reception, since the wind was knocking down glasses and causing the brides to shiver.
author: Melanie I.

description: This place has a special place in my heart...it's one of the first places my now husband took me to the first time I came to visit him (I was living in Chicago).  It is absolutely gorgeous, and worth at least one visit by anyone who comes to this city.
author: Eileen H.

description:
I admit it: I only wanted to go here because of the scene in So I Married An Axe Murderer where Charlie & Harriet run into the Russian sailors while walking through the giant columns. 

Yes, I am a huge nerd.

But no matter! After hours of walking here from the Ferry Building and getting some serious hurty sunburn on my shoulders, we discovered how beautiful this place is. I mean, like, heartbreakingly beautiful. 

Sadly the main dome building was all blocked off for restoration so we couldn't go in there, but the columns, statues, and lake surrounding it are AMAZING. 

I would definitely, definitely go back!
author: Amie S.

description:
the place has good acoustics and a very comfortable and classic  feel for a theatre. It was clean, the seats were comfortable but kind of old and the employees were very polite.  I was here last night for the "Talking Music with Ben Gibbard" hosted by Daniel Handler of The Magnetic Fields fame and whose also the the Author of the "A Series of Unfortunate Events" children's novels. 

I was (still am) suffering from a cold and the experience was quite rejuvenating. The music was great, the conversations were interesting and since the last time i was here was a LONG time ago for a school field trip, the experience filled me with nostalgic feelings of my John F. Kennedy Elementary days.
author: Jordan A.

description: I just find the Palace a beautyful place. If you look at the photos that some of the Yelp peeps posted its just stunning.......I really enjoy this place its a great back drop to all sorts of occasion...Its romantic for a make out spot.......great for picnic......ect...ect...ect...
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
The last time I came here, it was more or less by accident.  It was some Wednesday night around 9pm, didn't feel like going to a club or bar, and didn't feel going home.  One of those melancholic "Nothing interesting happening there" kind of feeling.  So I hopped on my bicycle, and started pedaling.  From Potrero Hill, I passed through SOMA, up the Embarcadero, through the Marina, and ultimately found myself staring at that beautiful dome structure.

I don't know what it is about architecture as art, but it's moving.  A painting, a song, a novel: these are things you can hold in your hand.  They can literally be grasped.

Architecture is so significantly vast in scale that I almost immediately feel simultaneously small, in awe, and understanding of what can be done in the name of emotion.

Some day I need to get back during the day, so I won't fear getting chased off.
author: Paul B.

description: I love history and my husband and I are fascinated by the World Fairs in Chicago, St. Louis and San Francisco. Looking at photos and other relics of the time just can't give you the proper perspective of something so awe-inspiring. The Palace of Fine Arts is impressive - beautiful - incredible - a must see, esp if you love architecture and the history behind it all. This was one of the sleeper hits of our trip and we really really loved the experience. A trip to San Fran isn't complete without seeing this!
author: Sheila R.

description:
i actually attended a wedding om the groundshere some tine ago. it got windy and a little chilly but didn't rain. this place is flabulous. if one doesn't mind the dirty pond water and dirty walkways.

i would go back if i have a lot of time to look for a parking space.
author: Victor G.

description: A great venue to see live MUSICperformed.
author: Karen F.

description:
When I was a kid, I wanted so badly to be a Solid Gold Dancer.  According to family lore, I would run to my bedroom and put on my Wonder Woman Underoos whenever I heard the theme song.  I would, then, spend the next hour blocking everyone else's view as I shook my groove thang in front of the television set.

I could totally do my old routine at the Palace of Fine Arts if they'd return my calls.  There's not a bad seat in the house, so all of you would have a great view of my Wonder Woman pants.
author: Bert M.

description:
If only I had moved to SF before I got married, I would have had my wedding here, or at least my wedding photos.  Achingly beautiful, especially in the afternoon light when the columns are lit up like gold.  You truly can have a field day here with your camera, what with the flowers and the water and the light.  Glad to see they're taking the effort to renovate it, though I hope the fences around the lagoon have been taken down by now.

Amazingly, for being arguably the most beautiful spot in the city, it's really not that crawling with tourists, and it can actually be very peaceful.  The one flaw is that the columns can look a bit papier-mache-ish up close.  After all, they're not really made of stone.
author: Wes M.

description:
If I get married (again) I want it to be here.  Thank God I didn't waste this awesome location on the first bastard.

Me?  Bitter?  No.....
author: Alexis B.

description: This place hold so many wonderful memories for me. If you've lived in the bay area during your teens you know what I mean (wink , wink). Anyway it's beautiful here and worth making a stop even just for a little stroll or picnic. Don't forget that you can also go check out the Exploratorium which is fun for all ages.
author: Michele H.

description:
This is my favorite building in all of SF. I wish there were more buildings remaining from the World's Fair in the Marina area, because this terra cotta colored beauty is both breathtaking and grounding. They were building a new walkway around the pond, so hopefully the chain link fence goes away before I return to have a look. 

Don't forget to check out the Exploratorium and Tactile Dome at the Palace!
author: tania t.

description:
The grounds, the place... everything about it is so calming, and typically part of a wonderful, proper, incredible SF day.

Wow.  I cannot believe I hadn't reviewed this.  

Also... I can't help but remember silly stuff like movies... The Rock, So I married an axe murderer, Primus' southbound pachyderm ehanced punchbowl Cd.

okay.. enough.  TACTILE DOME!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: On a late February afternoon I came, I saw, I froze to death. But absolutely gorgeous.
author: Lana L.

description:
We saw Jake Shimabukuro (renowned ukulele player from Hawai'i) perform here last night as part of the last night of the 2008 SF Jazz Festival.  Great venue.  I don't think there's a bad seat in this house.  It's quite small  and it is stadium seating.  We were seated in Row L, Seats 1 & 3 (on the far left side of the theatre) and we had a great view and the acoustics sounded perfect.... cannot complain.  You could hear every note Jake strummed even when it was at its quietest.  

The seats were super comfortable, too!  They're rockers and nice and cushy.

The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the musty "old" smell action going on.  Maybe some would call it rustic and historic.  But maybe we can get rustic and historic without the smell?  It didn't smell in the theatre as much as it did in the lobby area.

Jake was phenomenal, btw.
author: Amy T.

description: You have to go to the Palace of Fine Arts when you're in SF.  It's kind of falling apart right now, so it's under construction to prevent it from deteriorating any further.  It's fenced off so you can't walk through it, but you can still walk along the waterfront.  It's very picturesque and makes for a pretty sweet walk after playing at the Exploratorium.
author: jenn l.

description:
Come here for the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival!

http://www.worldartswest.org/

On the second weekend (June 16th & 17th) of this three-weekend event, I'll be one of the drummers in tahitian ponchos playing for the last band.

Why ponchos?  I'm told the drummers usually always perform topless, but because I'm chinese and way too pale in comparison with the rest (I'm barely two shades above clear), they are forced to cover everyone up as to not have me stand out. 

Fo' shame.
author: Andrew P.

description: Why san Fran isn't known for this as much as the bridge blows my mind. I would suggest going here instead of the bridge if you had to pick. Absolutely beautiful and breathtaking!
author: Eric O.

description:
great place for a makeout spot.

but you didnt hear it from me. :)
author: Carol Y.

description:
I am so jealous of my mother for seeing Yo La Tengo here awhile back...without me! I had to work. I love that my mom rocks, but when she goes to better shows than I do, I start to feel a little insecure. 

I have seen Ryan Adams here, and I have seen the Fleet Foxes here. And you know what? Amazing. The acoustics are superb, the venue is small enough for an intimate performance, but can still accommodate a decent crowd. Not a bad seat in the house, really. 

I make it a point to catch performers I love if they play here...But DAMN, I wish I could have seen Yo La Tengo play "The Room Got Heavy" in this most excellent venue. Ah well. Good for you, mom!
author: Eric E.

description: Beautiful place! Definitely a must see in sf. Consider parking at crissy park and walking cause street parking will probably ruin your day but that's sf for you.
author: Ashley J.

description:
San Francisco's Palace of Fine Arts Theatre is by far, my favorite theatre in the city! I saw a play, a musical, and a concert here and I have yet to be disappointed. I love the arrangement of the seats; they are not organized in columns as they are in most theatres. In fact, the seats are spread out through out the entire theatre. I also like that the balcony is not very high up. Lastly, hanging above and at the sides of the large stage are burgundy curtains, which add a lot of grace and calmness to the theatre. It's original, yet very dramatic.

I am in love with the Palace of Fine Arts and its' incredible theatre. Just talking about it encourages me to find out what upcoming shows they are going to have. =)
author: Narina A.

description:
I saw Rufus Wainright here last night and he was fantastic.  So was his opening act, Teddy Thomson, a British country singer.  I was inspired by their talent.  For what, I don't know yet.  Thanks, Helen, for a great birthday present!

Parking was really easy in the free lot.  As I walked to the entrance of the theater, I noticed an inordinate number of really good looking guys.  Then I remembered who I was going to see and realized it was all for naught.  The theater itself looks older but it was comfortable.  We had seats near the center and I felt like we were really close to the stage.  I liked that the chairs rocked and it was also nice having a good amount of leg room.  

i'd definitely go see another show here.
author: Seong P.

description:
I've never been there night, but I just saw Rufus Wainwright perform at the Palace. 

It's a great venue, convenient to get to (and park!) and it's just beautiful all around. I used to enjoy walking through there on early weekend mornings.

The space is a little small, but if you're going for a simple show it suits the scene fine.

It's cozy and romantic, the chairs are kind to your ass and it just smells so damn nice outside.
author: Jessica P.

description:
For anyone visiting San Francisco, this is a great stop for a photo opportunity.  Open to the public, you can freely walk around and through the structure and surrounding grounds.  As you're towards the inner circle of the rotunda, it takes on a more ruinous atmosphere, with dirt paths and a few benches to relax on.

My favorite part is crossing the lake.  Sitting across from the structure, especially with a sunset in the background, is stunning.  The still lake water reflects the rotunda, so you have great opportunities for pictures.
author: Garrett P.

description:
I know it's an artful place, it's architecture and scope are outstanding. But you've never truly appreciated it until you've gotten effed up and clambered around on this structure with a silly friend or nine.

It's a great place to take artsy fartsy or fun pictures. Kids love it because it's like a huge fort.  My daughter had me take emo pix for her myspace. "OMG mom, I feel hella small and insignificant. Wait, wait wait, lemmee make emo face..."

I'd drive to the city every week just to visit here.
author: L.A. W.

description:
came here last night for a charity show.  i like the theater here, but i really hate the seats.  the seats have no resistance to the rocking... so if u sat down hard, it's gonna hit the wall... or if someone kicks ur seat... you'll definitely feel it.

but i do like the cleanliness and the wide spacious mezzanine where people in clusters can be in clusters without being in the way!
author: Kelly H.

description:
My review of the Palace is not focused on the outside, the building or architecture which is really cool. Great history and last building with ties to the Pan Pacific Worlds Fair of 1915 which was the signal to the wold that SF was back as a city after hte 06 quake.

I'm talking about the inside space used for concerts and performances like the Jazz Fest, SF Ethnic Dance Festival (every June) the former ResFest and things like SFNOIR (during Black History Month). The lobby is large and can be utilized in a variety of ways, as a gallery or exhibition area, there's a built in snack bar -- SFNOIR once had the Black Vintners of Napa pouring wine, ResFest would have Apple Demos, and Ethnic Dance Fest tributes to artists past and present. 

While the main theater doesn't look new and flashy, it holds about 1000, it actually has pretty good site lines, and really good sound. I'd much rather hear an SF Jazz event here than the Masonic Auditorium where the sound is horrible. It's a nice space for acoustic music, and large dance troupes fit well on stage.  There's free parking a rarity in SF. Palace is a great place to do or attend an event!
author: R A.

description:
Well I'm just going to say, I've ran by here twice at night.  What a sight!  Amidst the darkness lies a giant ominous structure, tall and foreboding, light and mysterious.  On our way home from my roomie's birthday, I wanted to stop here.  So at night the four of us park by it and walk around the structure and lake next to it.  

We basically goofed around, climbing on structures, taking photos next to statues and random lights that we were easily amused by.  My friends stood in the center of the circular part and enjoyed the night's full moon and Venus dimple right next to it while I planned my future wedding here.
author: Labonee M.

description:
An oasis in SF.  AND there's ample parking!  
Absolutely gorgeous and a lovely walk from Fort Mason.
author: C B.

description: Pretty, wide area in the bright Marina district.  Popular date spot.........I've had several strolls here.  The structures are great photo ops and I've volunteered several grade school kids luncheons here.  The pond allows for interaction between the ducks and geese inhabitants, and the surrounding grass is perfect for a picnic.
author: Miika M.

description: Beautiful! Doesnt look like it belongs in the states. the perfect place for pictures!
author: Kate F.

description:
Growing up in San Francisco, POFA has always been a place where I could turn to to think, to breathe, and to rejuvenate myself.  It's amazingly beautiful here and other than Venice, Italy this is my favorite place in the world.  

There's nothing better spending a sunny afternoon here reading a book, walking Mochi, or eating a light lunch near the edge of the water.  I can spend countless hours here just day dreaming...  *sigh*
author: Chrysantha C.

description:
I have a problem when I go to shows... I do too much people watching. I can go 15 min staring at some old time tripper dancing and realize I haven't heard one second of the music. And I don't think that scenerio is such a bad thing. I enjoy watching people who are really feeling it...
But usually it's not such an innocently beautiful scene. Usually it's someone around me who is waaaay to drunk and I spend the whole freakin show on alert worrying if they are ok. If they are going to pass out. If they are going to potentially puke all over me. I just feel that sense of obligation to make sure everyone is ok. Cause I know I will be the first one to jump on if something goes wrong. I want to be prepared. So I end up feeling like a mother hen-watching out for her chicks. 
The old man brought me to fleet foxes at the palace of fine arts. I had never heard of them before but he wooed me with a sunset bottle of wine around the lake, second row seats and a sit down, mellow show. But after the first song, I realize the girl next to me is wicked effed up. Big time. So I spent the whole show being very aware of her effedupness. Then she started puking.  All over the floor. Inside the palace of fine arts theater. At a show where people were drinking wine and wearing black dresses. She wasn't a hot mess. She was a scorching hot mess. 
tonight we went to see charlotte gainsbourg (daughter of serge gainsbourg) who was amazing.  the opener was johnny larroquette (son of john larroquette- yes- from nightcourt).  i was in the front row...the old man was to my right and no one was to my left.  i was all clear to enjoy the show without having to worry about my neighbors.  until johnny larroquette stepped on stage.  i mean stumbled.  homeboy was so jacked up i was worried i would have to call rock med to make a special run over for the soon to be naked, tripping performer on stage.  luckily- he stopped at ripping his shirt off and letting his hair down  but i spent his whole set cringing- knowing at any moment he was going to lose it and i was going to have to talk his speeding ass off the rafters.  
but then charlotte came on and the only thing to worry about was her forgetting some songs.  but she made up for it in cuteness factor.
author: Katie H.

description:
The Palace of Fine Arts is, quite frankly, one of my favorite places in the world. 

I think I first found this place the first time I came to San Francisco and wanted to check out the Exploratorium.  Boy, was this something I was not expecting.  I remember turning a corner and seeing the rotunda for the first time, and I was completely hooked. 

Now, I never make a trip to San Francisco without visiting the Palace of Fine Arts.  I love the stunning architecture. I love the park and the pond and all the "wildlife" that call it home.  It is so beautiful and so peaceful and relaxing.  And, with the temperate weather that graces San Francisco so much of the time, I can think of no better place to spend a few hours.
author: Elena M.

description: Rivals the ancient ruins of Italy and Greece, though looks like made of concrete vs  marble.  Was designed by Maybeck for a 1915 fair.  I hope they get it restored properly, and find a suitable use for these beautiful  grounds.
author: J. G.

description: This is a beautiful place inside and out.  The only problem is the fact that it's so far out in the city that the only way to get there is to drive or be willing to walk a long distance.  I saw Ryan Adams perform an acoustic show and you could literally hear a pin drop.  The acoustics in the building are amazing.  I felt underdressed going in there cuz it looks so elegant inside.  I can see why it's at the top of a tourist guide though cuz it really is one of the nicest places in the San Francisco area.  Definitely worth visiting whether you're a local or an out of towner.
author: Amy J.

description:
Excellent venue for a music concert! 

But before I elaborate further, I must say that a little bias does creep in based on how the concert/event went and how much you liked the concert. (and maybe even vice versa).

The PoFA is a really beautiful structure. The auditorium is decently sized (not too huge). The chairs are comfortable (though like someone pointed out, they are indeed a little squeaky). Even from slightly distant seats the view of the stage/artistes was really good. Sound quality was amazing. 

Lots of free parking available. Food was good and reasonably priced. Seating was easy to find. So was the stage door (to be able to go backstage and meet the artistes). The stage door is the one with the address of the venue written on the door. 

Make sure you have all the directions to and from the place. An exit from the place takes you straight onto the Golden Gate. If you are heading south, you dont want to get on to the GGB.

Overall a truly excellent experience. Very satisfied with the venue and the concert. (Just FYI: I attended a concert by Ustad Zakir Hussain and Pandit Shiv Kumar Sharma. Indian classical music for the uninitiated).
author: Aniket D.

description:
Great way to end a date.

I surprised my girlfriend with a walk to palace of fine arts. She was so excited and we sat on one of the benches and watched the geese play in the water. It's a beautiful place right at sunset. They light up the palace and the birds play in the water. There are also some really cool plant life around the area too.
author: Adam C.

description:
This is one of the spots where we took our engagement photos for reasons you have to see for yourself to understand. 
For tourists and locals alike, first the Golden Gate, then this. It never grows old.
Don't forget the camera!
author: Nono A.

description: How have I been to San Francisco countless times and never visited the Palace of Fine Arts? Better late than never, because this place should go on any tourist's "must-see" list! A symbol of the never-yielding hope of a city when its people come together, the Palace was originally built for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition, less than a decade after the destruction of the city by the 1906 earthquake and subsequent fires. Originally made of wood and plaster, the structure was completely re-done in the 1960s with steel and cement and has since had numerous structural reinforcements. But beyond that it is such a serene, beautiful place to visit. Nestled in a residential block and fronted by a duck-filled pond, the Palace is a great example of what I admire most about San Francisco: the respect for history and great architecture. If you happen to be staying in the Marina/Cow Hollow District (like we are), it is an easy walk. Go in the morning to avoid crowds and get a full sense of the serenity this place has to offer. There was also a fun display of classic cars hosted by the Academy of Arts when we visited, inside beyond the (much-appreciated) bathrooms. A more-than-worthy stop during a day of sightseeing.
author: Brittany B.

description:
I saw Cat Power here. It's a pretty good sized venue that is still able to set a pretty intimate mood for music listeners. The seats are built so that nobody's head is really blocking your view of the stage, which is a very good thing.

There is a huge stage; sound quality was awesome. It's a pretty venue in a pretty area. Though, it is definitely out of the way when you're coming from Berkeley.
author: Angela H.

description: The Palace of Fine Arts sells tickets through City Box Office.  Then they cancel concerts and assess patrons with service fees which are not refunded.  I will not be a customer again!
author: nancy f.

description:
A really nice place to go for a stroll.  There is always a series of people having wedding pictures taken and if you're lucky they'll invite you in.  

Also:  Sean Connery and Nicolas Cage chilled here in The Rock.  Good stuff.
author: Brian H.

description: this was my first time riding on marina blvd to Sausalito. this place is wonderful. you can relax and then continue to the gg bridge
author: Andrea B.

description: i love this place. great for photographs. there is a exploratorium on the opposite side. great to run or walk around.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I can't decide which I like more, looking at the Palace of Fine Arts from far away or being underneath it. 

Quirks: It's behind a kids' science museum, and I'm pretty sure I observed a drug deal going on here in broad daylight once.
author: Bonnie L.

description:
My friends and I have talked about this before--For some reason, although the Palace of Fine Arts is touristy and attracts wedding parties galore, it always FEELS great.  
Ride your bike around it, stroll through the arches, occasionally quote "The Rock".  All of it just makes me love San Francisco.
author: Robby T.

description:
Love this place - came here as a kid (Exploratorium!), and more recently for an Ani DiFranco interview as part of the SF Arts and Lectures series.

Its definitely got some 'airs' about it, but for good reason - it's a super classy joint,all around.
author: Lauren S.

description:
AMAZING AT NIGHT

I've driven by the Palace of Fine Arts a handful of times (I live downtown so I rarely make it over to that side of the city) but I had never stopped inside before.

The other night, our party bus (and by party bus, I mean some sort of vintage Burning Man conversion bus) made a stop here along our drunken night tour of SF. As I wandered towards the giant dome, I was in complete awe. It looks AMAZING at night! I was suprised there weren't security guards patrolling the area or anyone loitering around.

A definite must see at night. I'll have to come back in the day sometime and check it out. I doubt it can beat the night trip though--there was no one else around but our group.
author: Cindy P.

description:
Great Location for Wedding and Formal photography. Originally built for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition. It is a beautiful garden setting with a small lake and giant structures reminiscent of Greek and Roman architecture complete with columns, colonnades, and a beautiful, imposing dome. Here is a beautiful video that illustrates the kind of beautiful photography / videography that can be captured in this setting. 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RgnmQg8caeg

Many couples have actually been married here, but you can just go here with your wedding photographer and take pictures. It is open to the public. While we filmed the above linked video, a dozen or so parties showed up throughout the day to snap formal photographs--mostly wedding parties and other formal type occasions.

If you are getting married in San Francisco or near by, it would be worth the time to get photographs there.
author: James F.

description: Can't believe I'd not written a review for this wonderful spot! A must see for locals and out-of-towners alike. Beautiful and impressive architecture and definitely a picture perfect spot for weddings or just a day out to capture the sights.
author: Yan M.

description:
Go to the Exploratorium

Bring a sandwich

Eat it in the park with your kids/friends

This is absolutely one of the coolest and best parks in the city. Consider taking a weekend day to walk around the Palace of Fine Arts before heading over to the beach and the lagoon to check out any wildlife. Treck into the Presidio past all the development and wander around the old bunkers. This is a great place to get outside.
author: Sven S.

description: A work event was hosted here. The theater had very good sight lines for each seating area. Plus, it's quite a beautiful  space. Only issue was the sound was sometimes muffled. Not sure if it was our staging or the theater itself. In any case, great venue with good service staff.
author: Eme L.

description:
I visited this gorgeous site just after the rain one day and have unusual images of it at http://www.pbase.com/andrys/palace_fine_arts  -- which wouldn't be seen often.

   As a result I became interested in the history of the place, what it was all about, and on my site I've linked to interesting background information, photos, and 3 "historical movies" of it online.   I hope others will enjoy these too.

   A great respite from the usual tourist spots.
author: Anie B.

description: A must see for any SF visitor.  Currently under construction so no exploring under the dome.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description:
Perfect place for a small, intimate concert.  Went to my first concert here last Saturday for the Hip-Hop Symphony by Adam Theis!  AMAZING show!  I don't think I have ever seen so many talented people on one stage.  The ensemble had RIDICULOUS talent!  They had one dude singing and playing the trumpet.. singers singing, flowing, storytelling... and one dude beat boxing.. I was blown away because you wouldn't think they were THAT diverse with their style!

The venue itself is a landmark.  I mean it was featured in the movie The Wedding Planner with J Lo!  Great, great place to watch a concert!
author: Starleigh H.

description:
For the thirty years I've lived in San Francisco, this is one 
of my favorite landmarks and is always included in my 
tour of the city for guests.  It is so beautiful, with its lovely
columns and graceful architecture, even more so, lit up
at night.  I was delighted, once, to drive by and see a 
wedding in progress...it is such a romantic site for such 
an event - heavens, I may have to consider another one
in this setting!
author: Carmen H.

description:
A breathtaking sight. 

I feel like I'm in the movie Gladiator when I come here.
author: Ninja R.

description: So Beautiful! Such a great environment. Calm and pleasant. Ducks, birds, and swans swim around the lake, and there are trees and flowers all over. The architecture is amazing and doesnt look like it even belongs in the city.  You can get some great pictures here.
author: Melissa W.

description: all i can say is WOW!!!!! i been living in Cali for over 20 years and went to The Palace of Fine Arts for the first time last weekend..its a beautiful place!!!! great place for weddings if you got the $$$$$!!!!!!
author: Allan Y.

description: Another great place for a photoshoot.  I've been here numerous times with different models and they've all loved it.  If you get hungry just walk a couple blocks to chestnut street and you'll be in the middle of the marina where all the shops are.
author: Jeff H.

description: A century-old San Francisco landmark. It is truly captivating. This is one of our favorite family spots to picnic, watch the waterfowls, and for the kids to play around. This is also a great photo opp location when in San Francisco.
author: Thea T.

description: Hauntingly beautiful.
author: Angie C.

description: One of the most beautiful spots in San Francisco, I go here when I need a moment to myself to just think, or to enjoy a quick bite on green grass under the sun. It's so close to everything that you can essentially enjoy a moment of peace and quiet, walk 5 minutes and be in a completely different atmosphere. Love it.
author: Ellen C.

description: We only waited about two stops before we got off at Richardson and Francisco St. to go to the Exploratorium. Sadly, the grounds around the Palace of Fine Arts (the big Grecian-designed Rotunda) were fenced off for renovation and so we couldn't walk around there. We walked around the perimeter of the Palace of Fine Arts, got some great pictures, then got onto a bus back to San Francisco. It's easily accessible by bus, which is not something I can say about the Exploratorium, which is basically next door.
author: Henry T.

description: Good place to catch a show! Been here twice now in six months. Outdoor renovation looks good, now wish they would renovate the inside for the jazz shows and such.
author: Art A.

description: Use to eat lunch/picnic here & feed ducks a lot :) It's totally MY SPOT.
author: Hana G.

description:
Five stars for the outside, four stars as a concert venue. One of my first concerts was here 15 years ago. They tend to book jazz, blues, and classical shows here. I've seen Madeleine Peyroux, Solomon Burke, and Brad Mehldau here. The sound was not good at the Madeleine Peyroux concert, but I think that was a sound engineer problem, not a venue problem. The chairs are better than those at the Masonic Auditorium, maybe a little squeakier. Parking is easy (for San Francisco), which you can't really say about any other concert venue in the City.

There's not much else to say about the facade and the grounds - they're beautiful - one of the best things about San Francisco.
author: Timothy O.

description: Great venue for music. Comfortable  seating. Just wish they served spirits and not just beer/wine.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
What can one say? This place is perfection.

Swans, corinthian colums, weeping willow trees. Ahh, it's just lovely. Sigh....

"You must remember this... A kiss is just a kiss... A sigh is just a sigh..."
author: Risa F.

description:
Personally I think this is the most romantic spot in San Francisco.  This place is absolute beautiful and well maintained.  It's a great place to just relax, have a little picnic, or read a book.  You can also watch various local artists creating their own masterpieces on canvas.

The dome is surrounded by lush gardens and the pond is teeming with fish, turtles, swans, and migrating ducks.  Located just off the Marina, it's a stone's throw away from the Golden Gate Bridge.  The architecture is simply amazing.  

It's a must-see.
author: Vvn W.

description:
After, years, YEARS, of dis-repair, the lagoon is finally fixed and open for visitors!

I've lived a couple of blocks from the palace all of my life. Used to visit every day. I have great memories of multiple friends falling in to the pond when we were kids. But age took its toll. The walk-way fell in to the pond, the pond filled with sticks, trash, and green muck until it was only a foot deep and the landscaping was sad. At first they put up a fence between the sidewalk and the crumbling water's edge. Ok, no more falling in. But it was chain link and really ugly. That was up for maybe 5-6 years (?), then a year and a half ago, they fenced it all off for repairs. 

The Palace of Fine Arts is finally repaired!!! The newly weds are back for their photos, the people feeding the birds, the kids, the tourists. It's wonderful. The new benches are very nice, the walkway is great, heck, the trashcans are even nice. The water is clean, the birds seem happier. The fish are still around. Plus, the new walkway has a little lip which might make it harder for kids to fall in. 

YAY!
author: Jack O.

description:
I ushered last weekend for my friend who is coordinating the Ethnic Dance Festival. I really like this venue, but that could reflect how much I LOVED the festival (I know that's not  this review, but you should go!).

This theater is pretty well layed-out... Every seat has a view (I know because I was there beforehand scoping it out). It also has relatively decent acoustics. The major bonus is the large, comfy, sorta-rocking seats.... nice.
author: Erin M.

description:
Right down the street from my place. Always a beautiful stop-over when I'm out on a romantic walk or a friend comes into town for the first time. Love it, love it, love it. 

For those that don't know, this place was originally built during the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition. What stands now is NOT the original structure, it's a reproduction of the original temporary structure, albeit the exact design and on exactly the same spot. Yeah, I can tell you way too much about this place, I love it! ;)
author: Gregg G.

description:
Ever since I was a kid, I always thought I would get married here (or at least take wedding photos here)....i remember coming here as a kid with my parents, even studying for the LSAT here (in the winter nonetheless, and there are rats that live here...ew..but i digress). 
This is one of my favorite places in the WORLD, so amazingly beautiful, and my mom's late best friend had a home directly across from the park that i would sell my soul for!  All the houses nearby are pretty beautiful, but nothing compares to the palace of the fine arts itself--even on a gross day the palace is fabulous, the swans in the lake are beautiful, all in all just an architectual phenomenon!
author: Danielle J.

description: I've been to the Palace of Fine Arts several times but I never knew there was a theater inside until last weekend.  This is an awesome venue.  I was blessed to get invited to the Tommy Emmanuel concert.  He rocked out!    We were in the 6th row, right in the middle.  I must say that the venue was amazing.  I thought the sound was excellent and the venue had an older, warm feel.  It was an amazing experience.
author: Brent T.

description:
Another beauty in San Francisco (kinda ruined when they added the fencing around the pond, but oh well, glad I was able to enjoy that). Nice place to take a walk with a date. Watch the ducks and the swans. You'll always find couples taking wedding pictures here every weekend, guaranteed.

I'd love to live in this neighborhood one day, with the Palace of Fine Arts right outside my window...
author: Zell C.

description:
There is a reason this is such a great SF landmark - it's such a gorgeous setting, you would hardly realize the busy and bustling Fisherman's Wharf area is just a few blocks away.  Even when there's a lot of tourists there it still feels picturesque and private.  

I am not a fan of the new fence, but what can you do?!   

Also been to the theater for a SF Jazz Festival show - a great little spot and very comfortable auditorium!  

The Exploratorium is also not to be missed!
author: Hayley L.

description:
PoFA needs a bath and a fresh coat of paint! 
I'd rather marvel at the Venetian mansion across the street. I think i saw a for-sale sign?!
author: stephanie r.

description:
Simply gorgeous.

I love to go for runs around here and just take in the loveliness of the entire area.
author: Sophie D.

description:
2 for being under renovation, all ten quinceneras (spelling?), the wedding, and the duck that almost clipped me.

I'll be back when it's done, probably to award it a 4!
author: Michael C.

description: How is this other worldly piece of structural art in San Francisco!?! it's so amazingly beautiful and random! The pond filled with ducks, the ice cream man rolling down the path, the green grass filled with sun bathers, and the ancient looking dome and columns make this place on of my favorite places to visit in San Francisco. Great to relax with a good book!
author: Casi C.

description:
I always love going to this place. It's romantic!

Watched Contemporary Circus: Traces at Palace of Fine Arts Theatre past Sunday. It was a great show, a bit morbid but entertaining.
author: jubi l.

description: A San Francisco institution that is worth a visit after its recent restoration. The Palace of Fine Arts is popular with locals, tourists, and Bridal photographers. The best time to visit is at night where its beauty takes on another dimension. Its also a great place to take on of those typical San Francisco super shots for your photo book with one of the giant planters.
author: Thomas V.

description: Even though it is undergoing construction we still went to check it out. It is amazing in real life. Plus, a construction worker left the gate opened so we walked in and were all alone and got to walk around until they kicked us out. We still took beautiful pictures outside. The architecture is worth going to check out. Beware lots of school groups are there and get in the way!
author: Hayley H.

description:
I just saw Ben Gibbard there last night.  It was my first time to the POFA theatre and from the pictures on the website, it looked huge!  But when we got there we found a fairly small auditorium with very comfy seats that reclined.  We were way in the very back, but still felt close to the stage considering other auditoriums I've been to.  And I could see over the heads of the people in front of me!!!  Many points for that since I'm incredibly short.  :)
It was a great night, a great little venue, and a very intimate setting for such an amazing artist!
author: Kim L.

description:
I've seen maybe four shows here, all of them good, solid shows (well, except when Ryan Adams decided to rock into an inane Grateful Dead jam, the horrors, oh the horrors).

It's a pretty nice venue for a sit-down show. There really isn't a bad seat in the house but God forbid you have to go to the bathroom. If you sit in the middle of a row, you have to climb over 20 people in order to get out. Beck himself pointed out this travesty as some poor soul had to make potty during his show. 

Oh and Hall & Oates here was alternately cheesy and rad. It felt like I was on the Love Boat but they sang "Rich Girl" one of the best songs in the history of Hall & Oates songs.
author: Jackie I.

description:
Rather grand facade,
Interior somewhat austere, 
Drinks stay in lobby.
author: Brian J.

description:
I've been to this theatre a total of two times in my life - once for SF's annual Ethnic Dance Festival a few years ago, and the second time for a Zakir Hussein concert about a week and a half ago.  During the latter time, I was accosted by a young, friendly couple who introduced themselves, asked me my name, and then if I'd like some weed.  

Definitely a great place to meet some interesting people and watch some amazing performances.  Zakir was accompanied by these awesome, acrobatic Manipuri drummers from NE India, along with his older beat/tabla boxing older brother.  Amazing performance.  The venue is breathtaking and the sound quality was one of the best I've ever had an opportunity to observe.
author: Megha S.

description:
The summer before I moved here a friend of mine kept saying to me, TMC, TMC, you can't move to San Francisco, everyone there is dead, and if you move out there you'll be dead, too. I was still living in Ann Arbor, finishing my two year tour of duty in whatever army out there fights only under cover of cloud, and as I packed up to go, as I shoved my books all summer into boxes, as I got up at 6 in the morning to watch Stages of the Tour de France while she burnt grits in my kitchen she kept saying this, almost like an incantation, almost like sorcery. TMC, TMC.... 

Finally I said, Phoebe, what do you mean I'll be dead? I don't get it.

And she said, It's because San Francisco's Heaven, and in order to get into Heaven you have to die, and no one comes back from being dead, and no one ever leaves once they move to San Francisco.

And I said, Ahhh. 

But I didn't get it. Because I didn't know. 

Now I know. 

That Tour de France, burnt-grit, Ann Arbor summer was 2005. I've been out here 6 years now, yeah sure that's not long to you native San Franciscans, or to you middle-aged or even adolescent San Franciscans, but maybe that's like telling a two year old he doesn't know the wonder of walking. I'll spare you the gaudy piffle of when exactly I fell in love with this city, that fateful afternoon walk the following summer, tacking my way up and down hills in the stupefying northeast corner of this city...I'll spare you that for now, and just tell you this: If anyone ever tries to argue with you that this city is not in fact Heaven, take them to the Palace of Fine Arts. I don't care what time of day or night it is, I don't care whether it's cloudy, foggy, drizzly or pouring rain, this place has no business in this city, this place has no business in North America, it's from another century, it's from another millennium as far as I can tell. It should be hanging in a garden in Babylon. But it's not, in fact it's here, in San Francisco, in one of our many littoral neighborhoods, this fair city of ours that sometimes does a very bad job, if you ask me, a quite horrendous job of acting like it's not Heaven.
author: T U.

description:
Want a beautiful place to come to for a morning or evening run, the palace of FA is the place. It is amazingly beautiful, inspiring for the start of a long run, you can stretch with the swans in the foreground and continue onto the Marina green or onto Crissy fields. What better way to start your day......
Great place to hang around on a sunny Saturday afternoon with an ice cream sundae and a book, feels like being in quintessential Europe. Check out the Exploratorium next door if you have time, fun place with lots of cool stuff for kids.
author: Belinda w.

description: breathtaking and relaxing. Just down the road from the Golden Gate bridge. I love this park. I've always seen it in the movies and to go for a visit puts everything into perspective about how wonderful it really is. Worth the trip!
author: Cassandra Jo M.

description:
The San Francisco Hip Hop Dance Festival at the Palace of Fine Arts.... 

Ever heard of this?  It's an incredible dance festival, of a difficult to find dance form.... even your friends who don't dance will have a good time coming to see the Hip Hop Dance Festival.  Some truly fun and inspiring dance. International groups come to throw down in SF!
This Nov 18- 19th.
author: Kamille H.

description: Another one of SF's jewels. I love this place. It's so relaxing just sitting on the grass and staring at the building. There's a pond in front with duckies floating around. The building is just magnificent. So gorgeous. I'm gonna take pictures here when I'm engaged. =)
author: Jenny T.

description:
Everyone AND their MAMAS come here for their wedding photos. It is hilarious! I always stop by here to give my out of town guests a good photo op. One Saturday, there were 3 bridal parties fighting each other for the best photo taking spot. Hilarious.

Its nice to walk around, but I think allotting half an hour to an hour is enough to look around.
author: Retired B.

description: This is by far my most favorite building and area in san francisco. it is elegant,awe inspiring and beautifully designed. The architect,Bernard Maybeck,designed it to eventually fall apart gracefully,the way greek temples were meant to. fortunately,the decison to keep it and restore it was a good idea. I have taken many photos there,had picnics,showed it off to visitors andlove going there when ever I can. it is overlooked as a sightseeing destination,and should not be missed on a trip to san francisco. I will be glad when the renovation is finished and it will be restored to its original 1915 beauty.
author: Melissa M.

description:
i remember going here when I was a kid. makes me feel old, but otherwise it's a great park...great place to walk your dogs, feed ducks, take pictures...or just pass the time. 

my sister got into a 3 hour long conversation with some stranger there who happened to live in the area. 

and I always think of this scene from I Married an Axe Murderer where they dance around like russian ballet dancers....
 "come natasha!"

-1 star because every time I go your are under construction...hmmmm
author: John-Michael C.

description: Amazing location in the city and such a serene place, I've always found the tranquility of this place to be enjoyable. People watching is a given but laying a beach blanket in the grass facing the pond and reading a book over a cool beverage on a warm day is bliss.
author: Brandon H.

description: The one day we decide to do the touristy thing in SF happens to coincide with time the Palace of Fine Arts is fenced off. Oh well. We still had a great time snapping away with the camera and walking around the area. Seeing the Exploratorium brought back memories of elementary school field trips. But now that I'm much older, I finally noticed the rest of the area. It's such a romantic and peaceful part of San Francisco, and parking was free! I would love to live in one of the cute houses in the neighborhood. I can imagine taking leisurely strolls here daily, but I can do without the bird poop. I hope they finish renovating soon.
author: Mary T.

description: This place is beautiful. The inside is so plush with red velvety curtains and a large open lobby area you can drink with actual tables. The seats in the theater were comfortable too. I lasted through a 3 hour concert wihout thinking, "when the hell am I getting out of this damn chair, my ass is killing me".The beers didn't burn a whole in my wallet either. You can get a Stella or Fat Tire bottle for 5 bucks. Try that at the Warfield. Ha! They also have food if you forget to eat before you get there.  The only issue I had was with public transportation. Don't wear heels if you take the bus! It is a little bit of a walk and your feet will hurt.  Also, don't pay too much extra to sit up close. Every seat in this place is a good one.
author: LisaMarie C.

description: It's a lovely place and that's why Maltese Yada Dance Company decided to have their show at Palace of Fine Arts too. Wide stage, very convinient seating. From any seat is a fantastic stage view. It's appropriate for any dancing shows.
author: Ox O.

description: beautiful place for a walk or just sit and watch as nature unfolds... the lake, trees, birds very calm & serene... come here to just relive some beautiful moments... LOVE it
author: Pinku L.

description: It really doesn't get any better than this. Such a beautiful oasis in the city. Even with tourists flocking around somehow it barely mars the amazingness of the structure and its environs. If you look on youtube you can find film footage from the 1915 pan-pacific exposition that was the birth of this little park. Check it out its worth a look. Meanwhile I go here and sit and contemplate every time I'm visiting San Francisco.
author: Amie N.

description: I almost hate to admit my introduction to this theater was a taping of Jerry Springer's talk show. (I hasten to add that this was before it became a melange of toothless trailer trash tramps sleeping with their uncles, oversexed Latino midgets obsessed with tall Asian lesbians, unwed crack whores pregnant with their seventh child, and illiterate bimbos willing to flash their boobs every ninety seconds . . . although the program's subject matter - a 'Beverly Hillbillies' cast reunion - wasn't exactly fodder for Ted Koppel or Charlie Rose). I've been here several times since for all-star AIDS benefits that always pack the place, which has great sightlines and excellent acoustics but, as noted, very long rows unbroken by aisles, which make sitting dead center not as perfect as it sounds. A large area outside the auditorium easily accommodates silent auctions and strolling entertainers even when it's a full house.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Gorgeous, stunning, and a bit confusing. Classically modern.
author: Brianne C.

description:
lovely place to see a mellow concert or attend a lecture.  i went to both in 1 event - ben gibbard for the talking music city arts lecture.  he was interviewed by daniel handler for the first portion, and then sang some songs at the end.  the theatre itself was nice - pretty small, it seemed like all seats were good.  i was towards the back and i could see well and it didn't seem that far from the stage.  the acoustics were fine for hearing music too.  
the event was great - if you are at all a death cab or postal service fan, then you know ben well since he is a lead singer of both.  it was interesting hearing more about his life and experiences as a musician and his musical influences.  one of the highlights for me- one of his all-time favorite breakup songs is "pictures of you" by the cure!  awesome choice!
author: Carolyn B.

description: I love this place.  I used to live up Lyon St. in Pacific Heights (yeah, right off those crazy steep stairs) and would run through the Palace of Fine Arts down to the Marina.  My thighs still burn just thinking of going back up those stairs.  It's still one of my favorite respites in the city, especially on a rare sunny day in SF.  My husband and I like to imagine we will retire in one of the surrounding homes.  Have you looked at those houses?  Beautiful and never to be in our price range.  The closest we'll get is the engagement photos we took here.  *sigh*
author: Kelly I.

description:
funny how i was here only several hours before i found myself in jail for a DUI the same day... that aside, this place is beautiful...

for amateur to professional photographers, its fantastic.  i would strongly suggest a newly wed couple invest for pictures to be taken here... as one of your choices...

a great place to plop down and people watch as well... or picnic if you find yourself in need of a companion.
author: Sharon T.

description: Beautiful from a distance, at night.  But if you get close during the daylight, you can see it needs some TLC, cleaning, take down the unsightly fences.  Still, from a block or so away at night, it truly is beautiful and romantic.
author: Jack H.

description: This beautiful structure in lush surroundings is awe inspiring. I find it completely easy to lose myself in happy upbeat thoughts here. Whether you go here by yourself, with a loved one, family, out of towners, no matter what, its easy to make peace with yourself and your surroundings and take a few pictures while your at it. Cheers!
author: Veronica G.

description: This place is beautiful period.  Came here many years ago to see Spike and Mike's Sick and Twisted.  Those were the days.
author: Chris R.

description:
Beautiful place; recently (around a year) rennovated. Must-see for tourists and those who are permanent residents here. Great photo-ops (Top 5 spot for wedding photos across the lake). Sometimes you can see this one rock artist balancing rocks, on occassion; a goose or geese and maybe a swan if you're lucky. 

Exploratorium is right on the other side of the dome and if you go on the first Wednesday of the month, you get free admission. Though I went there recently and it wasn't as exciting when I first went when I was younger.
author: May S.

description: Before I moved to San Francisco, I saw this surreal place in movies.  It is so beautiful and unique, a standout in the area and it lends to the distinct beauty that every neighborhood in SF has.  I have some wonderful photos from here, before there was digital.  I can picture the glistening ponds with goldfish and leaves adding traces of light to the magnificent colors in my pictures.  Oh, Palace I can't imagine that they almost tore you down.  I love how they light the dome at night.  I have a dream to live across the street from here and look at the Palace every night before bed.
author: apple r.

description:
sitting on the grass by the lake.  facing the big ol rotunda and columns.

my favorite place to sit and think about life in the whole wide world.
author: Kimberly K.

description: The exterior is, of course, amazing.  And the performing arts space is a really great small venue.  It will always be the place where I saw a cat walk a tight rope and for that, 5 stars.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Stunning architecture - phenominal examples of Greek arcades, corinthian columns and relief sculpture! I love picnicing here in the sun watching the swans gracefully float by!
author: Anastasia Beaver Housand J.

description: Beautiful landmark!  Great place to sit and have a picnic lunch.
author: L. A.  W.

description:
it's stunning. they have just removed the chain link fence from whatever work they were doing on the grounds, and it's absolutely stunning, there are even geese and stuff in the water!

and there is always good weekend parking around here.
author: Jessi B.

description: Awesome venue to check out some cool performances! Last year a friend treated me to World Arts West's annual production of the SF Ethnic Dance Fest, and today I took my aspiring little dancer daughter of mine to watch the auditions for this year's show. Stunning performances that touch the heart. The theatre is beautiful, comfortable, and classy, without being overly stuffy. The auditions continue for the rest of this weekend and the next- so check it out if you have some time... (Affordable-I paid only $4 and my daughter attended for free, the performances are world class). I will definitely be on the lookout for more performances at this beautiful Palace.
author: Vicky P.

description:
last night i went and saw mark kozelek and david bazan play here.  although mark was the headliner, david bazan was wayyyyy more amazing.  mark played for way too long and tuned between like every song...quite unnecessary and a little pretentious.  a funny dude though!  anyways, it was a great place to see a show...super comfortable seats and amazing sound.

the only reason i give it 4 stars instead of 5, is because from where we were sitting (row S on the odd # side...and i guarantee at least rows Q-Z on our half would say the same) the sound guy's computer monitor was SOOO DISTRACTING!  the brightness was blaring us in the eyes...and every time he would switch to a different program or something, we could tell.  kinda annoying...the screen should have been dimmed, and not pointed towards the crowd at all...  (he's stationsed in the way back, kinda on the left, but near the center.)

no biggie...great show!
author: Melody H.

description: Absolutely gorgeous - thus the newly married couples taking pictures here every weekend.  At dusk, I get a sort of creepy feeling about this place.  Not ghosts, but definitely something eerie.
author: Melissa Y.

description: The Palace has and always will hold special meaning to me. I look at it everyday from my deck and I've had the most special first date on the Palace's "steps of Rome." I've seen flying owls at the Palace, I've seen ducks mating, I've seen skunks running through the bushes. My dog even jumped in the lake (bad dog!) I see it light up at night and I see it in its natural state during the day. Go visit if you haven't...maybe you'll even catch a Sunday wedding.
author: Julia S.

description: This is still my favorite tourist site in San Francisco. Every time I come here I am awed by its beauty.
author: Kelly S.

description: The architecture is amazing.  The columns have this beautiful golden color to them when the sun hits them.  The waters gives great reflections and gives lots of great opportunities to take some wonderful photos if you are a shutterbug.  Lots of plants, ducks and geese around to help liven the photograph up.  Currently the main "hall" in covered in scaffolding, which is a bummer, but it's still beautiful.  Hopefully the renovations will be completed soon and this place can be enjoyed in in full beauty.  Its a great place to sit, reflect, picnic or even nap.
author: Jen K.

description: Beautiful and peaceful. The perfect place to come to just enjoy a nice day in San Francisco. One of my favorite places to take out of towners and to just go by myself when I need a break.
author: Anita B.

description: Palace of Fine Arts is such an amazing place, it's perfect for a romantic date.  Going for a stroll hand in hand with your sweetie as you take in the beautiful views of the structure, nature, or the water and fountain.   Plenty of grass and shade to lay out a blanket and have a romantic picnic, and every corner is a great photo opp.  In fact, every time I go I see a handful of wedding parties taking wedding pictures.   Ducks and swans take residence here as well.  There's people from all walks of life and every different culture.  It's a great spot to people watch as it stays pretty crowded.  Also, great place to bring kids and doggies for a family outing, you can hit The Exploritorium afterwards too!  Definitely recommend this spot, you won't be disappointed.  The only downfall, is, be prepared to be on the hunt for a parking spot!
author: Candice M.

description: Many a couple remember the good times they had at or near this location.  Heck, if all the women who took their bridal pictures here were to congregate at the same time, they might not all fit into the park.  Yeah, it's that popular, and for good reason.  Maybe it's the way the light hits the dome, the wind breezing through the trees, who knows.  So many people have etched this landmark into their collective memories, that saying The Palace is enough for them to think happy thoughts.  Anyplace that can evoke happy thoughts for SOO many people is a place worth coming to again and again and again.
author: brenda b.

description: One day I shall marry here..........any takers:)?  I want to be surrounded by the tranquil sounds of the waterfalls and in view of the beautiful swans.  All kidding aside, this place is so beautiful and the building is structurally detailed to perfection.  A must see if your in the SF area.  Or.... just make the damn trip down....you can have drinks afterwords.
author: Victoria S.

description: Palace of Fine Arts ~ Albeit a beautiful place to visit, see ~ kids love it.  Dog loves it too, however she has to be on leash and that's a deal breaker for her.
author: Cris B.

description: When I need to get away I can go down to the Palace of Fine Arts and almost instantly I feel as if I'm walking into Ancient Rome.
author: Patrick B.

description: i tried to bring my out of town friend here for a photo op recently and found out it's going through a long overdue refurbishing. i can't wait for the finished product! set in a beautiful part of SF, there is nothing else like this anywhere. The architecture, the pond, the tranquility of a walk through here.
author: Jeff W.

description: The five stars is for the museum,  not the restaurant down stairs which would only get two if I were rating it. I've seen several exhibits here since I was a kid. Its a very special place. Be prepared to stay a while and enjoy it. Its not somthing to inhale in one bite. You wanna savor it, like a small piece of dark chocolate on your tongue that you just let melt and hang out a while. Only you are the chocolate not the tongue. It's not cheap. There are certain days that are free or reduced price. I don't care because it's supporting art and culture, somthing we lack in modern life. But is money is an issue for you, pick a day that will make it easier on your wallet. The special exhibits are usually not considered part of the experience of the regular entry which only gets you a view of the permanent collection and a few other areas. But their special exhibits are Louvre worthy. Some are actually from famous European museums or ancient treasures of the old world like the King Tut exhibit that came through here. Cheaper than a trip to the pyramids.
author: Sara N.

description: An architectural marvel!  The garden and space within the palace is amazing and very peaceful.  Great place to chill out.
author: Alan T.

description: This is a cool place to come if you're in the Marina area and want to enjoy good architecture and a nice walk. They tend to have events here, plus they have the Exploratorium, a cool science-oriented museum best for kids. There is a parking lot but it can get busy. Street parking can be tough during peak hours. Chestnut street is a good bet for restaurants and bars within walking distance. This can be a cool place to visit with a date to talk and enjoy each other.
author: Al B.

description: Absolutely beautiful place! My compadres that came with were not amused that there was nothing here other than this greco roman structure. They must've imagined like a museum with artwork? However. Thought it was a great place for a sunny afternoon picnic.
author: J A M.

description: Duran Duran's "Arena" video opened with dreamy shots of the Palace's striking blue water and stately Roman-Greek architecture. It resembles ancient ruins, though it's less than a century old.  The other day my husband, our six-year-old nephew, and I admired the fearless swans, the angels in the rotunda, and the architecture's reflections in the water.  One of the prettiest spots in the city.
author: angela n.

description:
we sort of ran into this place during our last visit to "the city" and i've always wanted to see this place in person.

the architecture really is beautiful.  however, when we went, the grounds and the structures were sort of in disrepair.  the pond was fenced in and the paint was peeling.  i was sort of unimpressed but hopefully it was only in the midst of much needed tlc and we just came at a bad time.
author: Leni A.

description:
Today was a spectacularly beautiful, warm, blue-skied day; it was a perfect day for being outside. I'd never been to the Palace of Fine Arts before, and I'm so glad I chose today to check it out. It's gorgeous even if there were tourists by the busload milling about. 
The only downside was a bad flashback triggered by some guy feeding the ducks/seagulls/pigeons/other miscellaneous birds. See when I was about 5 I had a bad duck feeding experience. Basically I got surrounded by a bunch of really aggressive geese (damn those birds are crazy!) which caused me to freak out and start running towards the parking lot with the bread still in my hand. Naturally, the crazy, aggressive geese began chasing me through the park while my aunt stood there screaming "Drop the bread!!!! Drop the bread!!!! Aaaaaggghhh!! Oh my God, Megan drop the bread!!!!" So now being around large groups of birds fighting over bread causes me to break out in the cold sweats. But yeah, other than that this place was great.
author: Megan G.

description: The Palace of Fine Arts is such a wonderful SF gem. Many people flock to visit the fountains, feed the duckies or take wedding pictures in front of the Roman and Greek inspired domes. On some really busy days (i.e., Saturday and Sundays), be prepared to do circles just to get parking but it's worth it. You will definitely enjoy the architecture and the goodies that await you if you go specifically to see a show or if you want to visit the Exploratorium.
author: Dorothy S.

description: I came here for the a lecture in the Palace series that has been happening for quite some time, from what I understand. The interviewer was brilliant, and it was one of the best interview/lectures I've ever seen. The theater is quaint, with a kind of modern Greek architectural feel. The auditorium is rather small, and it seems as though there truly is no bad seat in the house. It definitely felt like a laid back, friendly atmosphere, kind of the feeling of a small community local production in many ways.
author: Shannon F.

description: This place is absolutly beautiful!  The architecture is amazing, and at night this couldn't be a better place to take pictures.  They recently finished some construction updates and the pathes around the pond are awesome.  There are benches which line the pathes which are perfect to chill on and enjoy the atmosphere.  Swans and ducks are always swimming around in the water.  And the Exploratorium is there to have fun at as well.  There is some crazy stuff in there!
author: Lauren M.

description: One of the most gorgeous places in SF. The first time I saw it my jaw dropped because it was so beautiful and unexpected. My husband and I had our professional engagement pictures taken here and if you go on the weekend you'll always see newlyweds taking portraits. It's a very romantic area and it's great to dream about owning one of the neighboring houses.
author: Sonia K.

description:
so i was here the other day warming up (after braving the winds at crissy fields). i was, admittedly, wearing my bikini top and shorts - just b/c i had to leave the beach doesn't mean i don't still want to take advantage of the sun - laying on the grass, reading and listening to my ipod.  a group of (i think it was) japanese tourist men came up to me, and clearly didn't speak english very well, and kept pointing and me and the camera, saying, "photo, photo." i assumed they wanted *me* to take their picture.

well, we all know what assuming does.  silly, silly me.  they wanted me to be *in* the picture.  oh my.  well at that point i didn't wanna just walk away and what could i say - they couldn't even understand me.  so i went along with it ... as they gleefully took FIVE pictures with me (one for each person).  well, i guess they were happy to have proof they saw a generic, tall, blonde, white girl.  i hope those pictures don't float around the web.

oh, and i love the palace itself.  kind of random, but really pretty and peaceful.
author: Alexis W.

description: Awesome concert venue inside. I saw Jamie Cullum there this year and he played extra long because he said the sound was so perfect inside he just didn't want it to end! Both he and the opener made jokes about how excited they were to play in a real "palace." Beautiful exterior of course. Minus one star for the awful wind tunnel the curved building creates. At my brother-in-law's wedding reception, which was under the dome, the champagne flutes were literally flying off the tables! And we froze our asses off and the beautiful Indian clothing all stayed under wraps. Boo!
author: Melissa W.

description: I remember back when there wasn't a fence around the pond, it was a much better experience without that ugly chain link that now circumvents it.  They should come up with something a little more classy, I dunno, a picket fence perhaps?    But the palace is still as beautiful as ever, the Exploratorium is fun if you're into it and feeding the ducks and watching the beautiful swans makes it worth a visit.
author: Jonathan B.

description: we had our wedding here- and it was the most amazing venue we could have found.  we were so fortunate to work with Amanda Lee- she was instrumental in making our event happen and making sure we had all of the right permits etc.
author: Shreya S.

description: This is more than just a fierce location for prom photos.  I just went recently and am pretty upset I havn't been going more often.  It is beautiful, and if I read poetry that's where I would do it.
author: Megan M.

description: If you're homeless this is probably one of the best places to sleep - just watch out for the geese, like many residents in the area, they're pretty to look at but they've got a nasty disposition and you don't want to get on their bad side...
author: Quartknee K.

description:
This is a must-see when you are visiting San Francisco. The Palace of Fine Arts is absolutely breathtaking... especially when you go in the evening. 
My best friend and her boyfriend came into town to visit. Little did my best-friend know that her bf was going to propose. We dropped the couple off at Crissy field and told them we had to take care of an "emergency" situation. Of course, her boyfriend knew of the plan and so agreed to meet us later on that evening. We jetted over to the Palace of Fine Arts,under the dome we setup six dozen yellow roses (her favorite flower), put a blanket on the ground, had to champagne glasses with a bottle of sparkling apple cider, and setup a battery powered iPod speaker plying her favorite music. When the couple arrived all he had to do was get down on one knee and pop the big question. This took place at dusk. The lighting was beautiful, the place was magnificent and there weren't many people around. 
Once again, this is a must-see destination in San Francisco
author: B P.

description: Its been such a long while since my last visit to San Francisco, but each time stopping at the Palace of Fine Arts to pay my hommage to beauty and serenity is a sure must!! However on this visit it was fenced off due to some maintenance - still it was worth a few photos!
author: Jeanie H.

description: This building is an architectural masterpiece. I am always in awe of it everytime I see it. It is impossible to give someone an adequate tour of the city and not bring them here.
author: Stacy H.

description:
This place is a photographer's dream...

It's beautiful. I can sit here for hours on end, just taking everything in. It's the perfect place to go to clear your mind, and just appreciate life.

Surprisingly, even though a lot of tourists try to make it out here, it remains quiet and peaceful. Can't ask for much else...
author: Heidi L.

description: I love this place.  Sort of makes me wish I had a time machine to go back and experience the Panama-Pacific Expo with all its other beautiful, but sadly temporary, buildings.  Definitely a place of lovely calm and peace in a city that's usually wonderfully chaotic.
author: Kate M.

description: There are places in San Francisco where you can be surrounded by  so many people and still feel solitude. The Palace of Fine Arts is such a magnificent example of grace and beauty. It's enormous, it's historic and most of all it is here for each and every one of us to enjoy in our own way.
author: Sherie R.

description:
no doubt one of the sf landmarks that come to mind, but i don't think i'd want my wedding photos taken there.
the houses surrounding this lake and park are beautiful so i wouldn't mind it if i owned one of those and therefore had to have a view of this place... :)
one time i saw this really cute gopher popping its head out of its hole in the grass... man that gopher was super cute with its two front teef sticking out... adorable!
author: charlotte s.

description: Hands down my favorite place in the entire city!!!  My date last night took me there for a post-dinner stroll, and I had forgotten just how wonderfully romantic this place was!!
author: kerry l.

description: We had a flickr mixr here recently and it was a great location to mingle, socialize, and of course, take great photos. The kids enjoyed running around and terrorizing the ducks while the folks snapped away. It's a beautiful landmark. I only wished I lived closer.
author: Maricel B.

description: Came here last night to see the Joshua Redman Trio and found this to be a great venue to see a show.  We had awesome seats, front and center, but I don't think there is a bad seat anywhere.  Seat cushions could have been a bit longer, but there is a ton of legroom so you can stretch out.  And tons of free parking!
author: Lisa C.

description: This place reminds me of San Francisco and Benjamin B., my favorite place and my favorite person. I don't have words to express how content the sight of this place makes me feel.
author: Christy M.

description: I went there two weekends ago to see the auditions for the Ethnic Music Festival in June and was pleasantly surprised. Having only seen the Palace of Fine Arts from the outside of the last 20 years of my life, I was pleasantly surprised by the not uncomfortable seats, classic columns in the lobby, and of course, the red theater curtain.  It's classy, but modern enough to be comfortable.  Could have used more women's restrooms during the lunch break though.
author: Cara J.

description: Always a hit with out-of-town visitors.  It is great to walk around there when it isn't so busy, and I love watching the herons and other birds that call it home.
author: Max C.

description: This place is just pure beauty.  The architecture is breathtaking.. A true San Francisco treasure.
author: Trish P.

description: Super romantic wonderful place :D makes you want to fall in love. Its unforgettable, no wonder so many couple take romantic pictures here :D I'm guilty of doing so myself.
author: Kristina S.

description: Lovely spot to have lunch, sit, read, people watch..  it is just great!  I would have liked to sit here much longer than I was able to as a tourist on the go.  Great, great!  Make sure you plan to take a look at your next trip to the Exploratorium.
author: Mina I.

description: This was a fantastic place to see a show -- absolutely stress-free parking, entrance, seating. Decent sound. Based on the other reviews, though, I'm going to have to come back in the daytime just to wander around!
author: Emily C.

description: This place is so pretty. Whenever I go there I always try to lie around and watch clouds. If you are a person who enjoys art and exploration this is one place you should go.
author: F B.

description: Ohhh so THIS is that place near Golden Gate Park...! At least I hope I'm touching on the correct agenda.
author: Carl Z.

description: it's such a beautiful place!  the water, trees, house, buildings, its just amazing.  please take the time to enjoy nature and this amazing location.
author: tony p.

description: The most romantic place in San Francisco.  My husband and I got engaged here and continue to visit to relive our special night.  If you're thinking of popping the question, this is the palce to do it.
author: Lisa B.

description: A good place to walk & free the ducks. Encapsulates the Exploratorium.
author: Eugene G.

description: Still under construction but still a beautiful place. One thing to note --- there is not an art museum here!  we had several people ask where the art museum is! If you plan on stopping in bring lunch and have a picnic.
author: Brian K.

description: The park is nice, as is strolling around the grounds. The theater is also excellent, saw a couple of shows here recently and all the seats seemed great (although we had the ones up front).
author: jen n.

description: If you ever go to San Francisco -- this is a definate must see.  Especially if you want to get a bit of culture while you are here.  I highly recommend spending at least a few hours at the Palace of Fine Arts.
author: Brandon M.

description: One of the survivors of the 1915 Panama Pacific International Exposition celebrating the opening of the Panama Canal and San Francisco's rebirth from the 1906 Earthquake...ok...let me shut up!!! Anyway, if u find a place to get away from the city, personal life, or whatever, this is the place to chill at. By just looking at the gorgeous structure and its pond, I feel the need to mediate or something (even with those swans, pigeons, and those seagulls that like to shit on people...ha!)
author: Chinwe N.

description:
i have another review after this one.. take a peek! :)

***

First impression: Gorgeous! Beautiful! Peaceful!

My impression now?

A total make out place. 

(in my high pitch valley girl voice & doing my lil tricks w/ my pom poms) LIKE TO~~~~TALLY!!! LIKE OMG!!! 

*no wait*

(in my hawaiian surfer guy's voice) LIKE TO~~~~~~TALLY BRA (bro)!!!

'nuff said.
author: Jennifer S.

description: The manatee finally graduated from UCSF!  PRAISE THE LORD!  She can now take me out to dinner and clubbing every night.
