I don't know how they let her graduate cuz if they would just read the manateeisms they would know she needs remediation.  The venue was nice.  Small for a formal graduation.  Masonic center is under construction this year so alot of grad schools are finding new venues.  My grad school is graduating at the Hilton this year.  Suckers.  I would be offended.  The entire time during the commencement I felt like I was being interviewed for admission into UCSF.  They would selectively bring a couple of students and read off their old applications and achievements.  It was weird. These people are obviously nerds so we don't need to know how times per day they take a shit.  It was crazy.  The commencement focused mainly of the top students in the class and not the entire graduating class as a whole.  It was weird.  Obviously the manatee isn't the brightest but she is the best at keg stands.
author: Fatty A.

description: what is there to say about the palace of fine arts?  the view is spectacular, and i can't help but just stare at the architecture when i go running in the area.
author: Helen T.

description: My absolute favorite spot in San Francisco.  Especially on a sunny day when you can see the light poking between the columns.  It's a throwback to ancient Rome and Greece and all things grand.  Swans and ducks sitting on top of a pond.  Makes me want to get in a small rowboat and lay in it on the middle of the pond.  One day I'll go here and take a ton of pictures and put them on my walls.
author: Mary H.

description: This has been one of my favorite parts of the city since I was a little kid.  If I didn't hate the Marina so much, I might live closer by this gem.
author: J B.

description: Seeing Beck here a couple of years ago was sort of surreal--it felt like we were in the best theatre venue in Midland, Michigan.  Beck's show didn't help.  This was the oddly self-reverential (word chosen carefully) acoustic-ish show where he at one point had dinner delivered to him on stage and proceeded to eat it while his companion played.  He was so into himself through the whole set that this show killed the whole Beck thing for me.  Where the Palace of Fine Arts Dome is a wonderful semi-archaeological oddity here along the bayfront, this theatre is more of a semi-theatrical oddity.  It feels like an odd size, largish but not huge, smallish but not intimate.   The seats are one long unbroken row so it's a pain to get into them if you come too late.   However, it's a shallow space from the stage to the back wall, so all the seats are relatively close.   http://www.palaceoffinearts.org/
author: Kevin S.

description: i love this place! it's so pretty! every time i passed by here i always see married couple taking their wedding pictures, so cute! i always dreamed that one day my wedding can be like that too! it's a nice place to take pictures with your love one, family, friends, and whoever. i suggest if you were to come here, come on a sunny day!
author: Valerie N.

description:
when i first arrived here w/my friend, i was beating myself up for never stepping foot on this beautiful place before. it is so gorgeous, w/the lake right in front of the dome. 

i need to come here more often. where have i been all this time?
author: Aiko L.

description: beautiful.  take a nice stroll along the water and bring your camera.  it's located right next to the exporatorium.
author: Immer E.

description: i just love going there to roam, walk and think.  definitely worth a visit or two (or three...)
author: Jill k.

description: So I came to the Palace of Fine Arts expecting this big grandiose sort of...palace.  I figured if you name it the Palace of Fine Arts you expect it to be a palace.  Palaces are supposed to be grandiose.  But anyways, it's not quite like a palace, it's more like a theater which it is.  I came to the PFA as I'd like to call it, last weekend for the Axis of Evil comedy show (which is a group of comedians who are all Arab Americans), by the way, is absolutely hysterical.  Now when you come to a theater of any kind, the seat plays an important role on if you enjoy the show or not.  You never want a creaky or loose chairs but the PFA surprisingly had decently sized chairs that were actually somewhat comfortable.  It was also fairly easy to get out of the theater as well.  I take 1 star away for it not being more palace-like and another star away for the front box office area, too small and gets confusing when you have a line that snakes around the room and you don't know where it starts or ends.  But overall, the experience was good.
author: David C.

description: i saw the ethnic dance festival here this yr and sat third row kinda on the side, but the middle of the side, which i thought pretty much rocked. tajikistan dancing and odissi are mad gorgeous.
author: Lijia X.

description: "the zawinul dome"   a classic san francisco landmark you can see from much of the marina, cow hollow, the presidio...  i've seen two concerts here, so i'm only rating it based on that, and my experiences outside (awesome lake and architecture).   I saw Joe Zawinul (RIP)(w. syndicate) and also Hiromi. two of the best concert experiences of my life. this is a very "mystical" place. to get some "thinking" or "anti-thinking" done.
author: Pflip W.
